text: I want --" he began, but Uncle Vernon was tearing the letters into pieces before his eyes. Uncle Vernon didnt go to work that day. He stayed at home and nailed up the mail slot.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "See," he explained to Aunt Petunia through a mouthful of nails, "if they can't deliver them they'll just give up."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I'm not sure that'll work, Vernon."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Oh, these people's minds work in strange ways, Petunia, they're not like you and me," said Uncle Vernon, trying to knock in a nail with the piece of fruitcake Aunt Petunia had just brought him.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: On Friday, no less than twelve letters arrived for Harry. As they couldn't go through the mail slot they had been pushed under the door, slotted through the sides, and a few even forced through the small window in the downstairs bathroom.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Uncle Vernon stayed at home again. After burning all the letters, he got out a hammer and nails and boarded up the cracks around the front and back doors so no one could go out. He hummed "Tiptoe Through the Tulips" as he worked, and jumped at small noises.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: On Saturday, things began to get out of hand. Twenty-four letters to Harry found their way into the house, rolled up and hidden inside each of the two dozen eggs that their very confused milkman had handed Aunt Petunia through the living room window. While Uncle Vernon made furious telephone calls to the post office and the dairy trying to find someone to complain to, Aunt Petunia shredded the letters in her food processor.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Who on earth wants to talk to you this badly?" Dudley asked Harry in amazement.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: On Sunday morning, Uncle Vernon sat down at the breakfast table looking tired and rather ill, but happy.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "No post on Sundays," he reminded them cheerfully as he spread marmalade on his newspapers, "no damn letters today --"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Something came whizzing down the kitchen chimney as he spoke and caught him sharply on the back of the head. Next moment, thirty or forty

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: letters came pelting out of the fireplace like bullets. The Dursleys ducked, but Harry leapt into the air trying to catch one.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Out! OUT!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Uncle Vernon seized Harry around the waist and threw him into the hall. When Aunt Petunia and Dudley had run out with their arms over their faces, Uncle Vernon slammed the door shut. They could hear the letters still streaming into the room, bouncing off the walls and floor.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "That does it," said Uncle Vernon, trying to speak calmly but pulling great tufts out of his mustache at the same time. I want you all back here in five minutes ready to leave. We're going away. Just pack some clothes. No arguments!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He looked so dangerous with half his mustache missing that no one dared argue. Ten minutes later they had wrenched their way through the boarded-up doors and were in the car, speeding toward the highway. Dudley was sniffling in the back seat; his father had hit him round the head for holding them up while he tried to pack his television, VCR, and computer in his sports bag.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: They drove. And they drove. Even Aunt Petunia didn't dare ask where they were going. Every now and then Uncle Vernon would take a sharp turn and drive in the opposite direction for a while. "Shake'em off... shake 'em off," he would mutter whenever he did this.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: They didn't stop to eat or drink all day. By nightfall Dudley was howling. He'd never had such a bad day in his life. He was hungry, he'd missed five television programs he'd wanted to see, and he'd never gone so long without blowing up an alien on his computer.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Uncle Vernon stopped at last outside a gloomy-looking hotel on the outskirts of a big city. Dudley and Harry shared a room with twin beds and damp, musty sheets. Dudley snored but Harry stayed awake, sitting on the windowsill, staring down at the lights of passing cars and wondering....

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: They ate stale cornflakes and cold tinned tomatoes on toast for breakfast the next day. They had just finished when the owner of the hotel came over to their table.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "'Scuse me, but is one of you Mr. H. Potter? Only I got about an 'undred

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: of these at the front desk."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: She held up a letter so they could read the green ink address:

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Mr. H. Potter

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Room 17

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Railview Hotel

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Cokeworth

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry made a grab for the letter but Uncle Vernon knocked his hand out of the way. The woman stared.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I'll take them," said Uncle Vernon, standing up quickly and following her from the dining room.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Wouldn't it be better just to go home, dear?" Aunt Petunia suggested timidly, hours later, but Uncle Vernon didn't seem to hear her. Exactly what he was looking for, none of them knew. He drove them into the middle of a forest, got out, looked around, shook his head, got back in the car, and off they went again. The same thing happened in the middle of a plowed field, halfway across a suspension bridge, and at the top of a multilevel parking garage.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Daddy's gone mad, hasn't he?" Dudley asked Aunt Petunia dully late that afternoon. Uncle Vernon had parked at the coast, locked them all inside the car, and disappeared.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: It started to rain. Great drops beat on the roof of the car. Dud ley sniveled.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "It's Monday," he told his mother. "The Great Humberto's on tonight. I want to stay somewhere with a television. "

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Monday. This reminded Harry of something. If it was Monday -- and you could usually count on Dudley to know the days the week, because of television -- then tomorrow, Tuesday, was Harry's eleventh birthday. Of course, his birthdays were never exactly fun -- last year, the Dursleys had given him a coat hanger and a pair of Uncle Vernon's old socks. Still, you weren't eleven every day.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Uncle Vernon was back and he was smiling. He was also carrying a long, thin package and didn't answer Aunt Petunia when she asked what he'd bought.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Found the perfect place!" he said. "Come on! Everyone out!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: It was very cold outside the car. Uncle Vernon was pointing at what looked like a large rock way out at sea. Perched on top of the rock was the most miserable little shack you could imagine. One thing was certain, there was no television in there.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Storm forecast for tonight!" said Uncle Vernon gleefully, clapping his hands together. "And this gentleman's kindly agreed to lend us his boat!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: A toothless old man came ambling up to them, pointing, with a rather wicked grin, at an old rowboat bobbing in the iron-gray water below them.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I've already got us some rations," said Uncle Vernon, "so all aboard!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: It was freezing in the boat. Icy sea spray and rain crept down their necks and a chilly wind whipped their faces. After what seemed like hours they reached the rock, where Uncle Vernon, slipping and sliding, led the way to the broken-down house.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The inside was horrible; it smelled strongly of seaweed, the wind whistled through the gaps in the wooden walls, and the fireplace was damp and empty. There were only two rooms.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Uncle Vernon's rations turned out to be a bag of chips each and four bananas. He tried to start a fire but the empty chip bags just smoked and shriveled up.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Could do with some of those letters now, eh?" he said cheerfully.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He was in a very good mood. Obviously he thought nobody stood a chance of reaching them here in a storm to deliver mail. Harry privately agreed, though the thought didn't cheer him up at all.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: As night fell, the promised storm blew up around them. Spray from the high waves splattered the walls of the hut and a fierce wind rattled the filthy windows. Aunt Petunia found a few moldy blankets in the second

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: room and made up a bed for Dudley on the moth-eaten sofa. She and Uncle Vernon went off to the lumpy bed next door, and Harry was left to find the softest bit of floor he could and to curl up under the thinnest, most ragged blanket.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The storm raged more and more ferociously as the night went on. Harry couldn't sleep. He shivered and turned over, trying to get comfortable, his stomach rumbling with hunger. Dudley's snores were drowned by the low rolls of thunder that started near midnight. The lighted dial of Dudley's watch, which was dangling over the edge of the sofa on his fat wrist, told Harry he'd be eleven in ten minutes' time. He lay and watched his birthday tick nearer, wondering if the Dursleys would remember at all, wondering where the letter writer was now.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Five minutes to go. Harry heard something creak outside. He hoped the roof wasn't going to fall in, although he might be warmer if it did. Four minutes to go. Maybe the house in Privet Drive would be so full of letters when they got back that he'd be able to steal one somehow.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Three minutes to go. Was that the sea, slapping hard on the rock like that? And (two minutes to go) what was that funny crunching noise? Was the rock crumbling into the sea?

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: One minute to go and he'd be eleven. Thirty seconds... twenty ... ten... nine -- maybe he'd wake Dudley up, just to annoy him -- three... two... one...

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: BOOM.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The whole shack shivered and Harry sat bolt upright, staring at the door. Someone was outside, knocking to come in.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: CHAPTER FOUR

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: THE KEEPER OF THE KEYS

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: BOOM. They knocked again. Dudley jerked awake. "Where's the cannon?" he said stupidly.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: There was a crash behind them and Uncle Vernon came skidding into the room. He was holding a rifle in his hands -- now they knew what had been in the long, thin package he had brought with them.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Who's there?" he shouted. "I warn you -- I'm armed!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: There was a pause. Then --

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: SMASH!

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The door was hit with such force that it swung clean off its hinges and with a deafening crash landed flat on the floor.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: A giant of a man was standing in the doorway. His face was almost completely hidden by a long, shaggy mane of hair and a wild, tangled beard, but you could make out his eyes, glinting like black beetles under all the hair.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The giant squeezed his way into the hut, stooping so that his head just brushed the ceiling. He bent down, picked up the door, and fitted it easily back into its frame. The noise of the storm outside dropped a little. He turned to look at them all.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Couldn't make us a cup o' tea, could yeh? It's not been an easy journey..."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He strode over to the sofa where Dudley sat frozen with fear.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Budge up, yeh great lump," said the stranger.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Dudley squeaked and ran to hide behind his mother, who was crouching, terrified, behind Uncle Vernon.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "An' here's Harry!" said the giant.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry looked up into the fierce, wild, shadowy face and saw that the beetle eyes were crinkled in a smile.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Las' time I saw you, you was only a baby," said the giant. "Yeh look a lot like yet dad, but yeh've got yet mom's eyes."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Uncle Vernon made a funny rasping noise.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: I demand that you leave at once, sit!" he said. "You are breaking and entering!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Ah, shut up, Dursley, yeh great prune," said the giant; he reached over the back of the sofa, jerked the gun out of Uncle Vernon's hands, bent it into a knot as easily as if it had been made of rubber, and threw it into a corner of the room.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Uncle Vernon made another funny noise, like a mouse being trodden on.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Anyway -- Harry," said the giant, turning his back on the Dursleys, "a very happy birthday to yeh. Got summat fer yeh here -- I mighta sat on it at some point, but it'll taste all right."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: From an inside pocket of his black overcoat he pulled a slightly squashed box. Harry opened it with trembling fingers. Inside was a large, sticky chocolate cake with Happy Birthday Harry written on it in green icing.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry looked up at the giant. He meant to say thank you, but the words got lost on the way to his mouth, and what he said instead was, "Who are you?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The giant chuckled.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "True, I haven't introduced meself. Rubeus Hagrid, Keeper of Keys and Grounds at Hogwarts."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He held out an enormous hand and shook Harry's whole arm.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What about that tea then, eh?" he said, rubbing his hands together. "I'd not say no ter summat stronger if yeh've got it, mind."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: His eyes fell on the empty grate with the shriveled chip bags in it and he snorted. He bent down over the fireplace; they couldn't see what he was doing but when he drew back a second later, there was a roaring fire there. It filled the whole damp hut with flickering light and Harry felt the warmth wash over him as though he'd sunk into a hot bath.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The giant sat back down on the sofa, which sagged under his weight, and began taking all sorts of things out of the pockets of his coat: a copper kettle, a squashy package of sausages, a poker, a teapot, several chipped mugs, and a bottle of some amber liquid that he took a swig from before starting to make tea. Soon the hut was full of the sound and smell of sizzling sausage. Nobody said a thing while the giant was working, but as he slid the first six fat, juicy, slightly burnt

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: sausages from the poker, Dudley fidgeted a little. Uncle Vernon said sharply, "Don't touch anything he gives you, Dudley."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The giant chuckled darkly.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Yet great puddin' of a son don' need fattenin' anymore, Dursley, don' worry."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He passed the sausages to Harry, who was so hungry he had never tasted anything so wonderful, but he still couldn't take his eyes off the giant. Finally, as nobody seemed about to explain anything, he said, "I'm sorry, but I still don't really know who you are."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The giant took a gulp of tea and wiped his mouth with the back of his hand.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Call me Hagrid," he said, "everyone does. An' like I told yeh, I'm Keeper of Keys at Hogwarts -- yeh'll know all about Hogwarts, o' course.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Er -- no," said Harry.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hagrid looked shocked.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Sorry," Harry said quickly.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Sony?" barked Hagrid, turning to stare at the Dursleys, who shrank back into the shadows. "It' s them as should be sorry! I knew yeh weren't gettin' yer letters but I never thought yeh wouldn't even know abou' Hogwarts, fer cryin' out loud! Did yeh never wonder where yet parents learned it all?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "All what?" asked Harry.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "ALL WHAT?" Hagrid thundered. "Now wait jus' one second!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He had leapt to his feet. In his anger he seemed to fill the whole hut. The Dursleys were cowering against the wall.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Do you mean ter tell me," he growled at the Dursleys, "that this boy -- this boy! -- knows nothin' abou' -- about ANYTHING?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry thought this was going a bit far. He had been to school, after all, and his marks weren't bad.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I know some things," he said. "I can, you know, do math and stuff." But Hagrid simply waved his hand and said, "About our world, I mean. Your world. My world. Yer parents' world."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What world?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hagrid looked as if he was about to explode.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "DURSLEY!" he boomed.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Uncle Vernon, who had gone very pale, whispered something that sounded like "Mimblewimble." Hagrid stared wildly at Harry.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "But yeh must know about yet mom and dad," he said. "I mean, they're famous. You're famous."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What? My -- my mom and dad weren't famous, were they?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Yeh don' know... yeh don' know..." Hagrid ran his fingers through his hair, fixing Harry with a bewildered stare.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Yeh don' know what yeh are?" he said finally.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Uncle Vernon suddenly found his voice.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Stop!" he commanded. "Stop right there, sit! I forbid you to tell the boy anything!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: A braver man than Vernon Dursley would have quailed under the furious look Hagrid now gave him; when Hagrid spoke, his every syllable trembled with rage.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You never told him? Never told him what was in the letter Dumbledore left fer him? I was there! I saw Dumbledore leave it, Dursley! An' you've kept it from him all these years?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Kept what from me?" said Harry eagerly.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "STOP! I FORBID YOU!" yelled Uncle Vernon in panic.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Aunt Petunia gave a gasp of horror.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Ah, go boil yet heads, both of yeh," said Hagrid. "Harry -- yet a wizard."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: There was silence inside the hut. Only the sea and the whistling wind could be heard.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "-- a what?" gasped Harry.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "A wizard, o' course," said Hagrid, sitting back down on the sofa, which groaned and sank even lower, "an' a thumpin' good'un, I'd say, once yeh've been trained up a bit. With a mum an' dad like yours, what else would yeh be? An' I reckon it's abou' time yeh read yer letter."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry stretched out his hand at last to take the yellowish envelope, addressed in emerald green to Mr. H. Potter, The Floor, Hut-on-the-Rock, The Sea. He pulled out the letter and read:

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: HOGWARTS SCHOOL of WITCHCRAFT and WIZARDRY

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Headmaster: ALBUS DUMBLEDORE

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: (Order of Merlin, First Class, Grand Sorc., Chf. Warlock, Supreme Mugwump, International Confed. of Wizards)

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Dear Mr. Potter,

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: We are pleased to inform you that you have been accepted at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry. Please find enclosed a list of all necessary books and equipment.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Term begins on September 1. We await your owl by no later than July 31. Yours sincerely,

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Minerva McGonagall,

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Deputy Headmistress

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Questions exploded inside Harry's head like fireworks and he couldn't decide which to ask first. After a few minutes he stammered, "What does it mean, they await my owl?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Gallopin' Gorgons, that reminds me," said Hagrid, clapping a hand to his forehead with enough force to knock over a cart horse, and from yet

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: another pocket inside his overcoat he pulled an owl -- a real, live, rather ruffled-looking owl -- a long quill, and a roll of parchment. With his tongue between his teeth he scribbled a note that Harry could read upside down:

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Dear Professor Dumbledore,

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Given Harry his letter.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Taking him to buy his things tomorrow.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Weather's horrible. Hope you're Well.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hagrid

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hagrid rolled up the note, gave it to the owl, which clamped it in its beak, went to the door, and threw the owl out into the storm. Then he came back and sat down as though this was as normal as talking on the telephone.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry realized his mouth was open and closed it quickly.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Where was I?" said Hagrid, but at that moment, Uncle Vernon, still ashen-faced but looking very angry, moved into the firelight.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "He's not going," he said.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hagrid grunted.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I'd like ter see a great Muggle like you stop him," he said.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "A what?" said Harry, interested.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "A Muggle," said Hagrid, "it's what we call nonmagic folk like thern. An' it's your bad luck you grew up in a family o' the biggest Muggles I ever laid eyes on."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "We swore when we took him in we'd put a stop to that rubbish," said Uncle Vernon, "swore we'd stamp it out of him! Wizard indeed!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You knew?" said Harry. "You knew I'm a -- a wizard?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Knew!" shrieked Aunt Petunia suddenly. "Knew! Of course we knew! How

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: could you not be, my dratted sister being what she was? Oh, she got a letter just like that and disappeared off to that-that school-and came home every vacation with her pockets full of frog spawn, turning teacups into rats. I was the only one who saw her for what she was -- a freak! But for my mother and father, oh no, it was Lily this and Lily that, they were proud of having a witch in the family!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: She stopped to draw a deep breath and then went ranting on. It seemed she had been wanting to say all this for years.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Then she met that Potter at school and they left and got married and had you, and of course I knew you'd be just the same, just as strange, just as -- as -- abnormal -- and then, if you please, she went and got herself blown up and we got landed with you!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry had gone very white. As soon as he found his voice he said, "Blown up? You told me they died in a car crash!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "CAR CRASH!" roared Hagrid, jumping up so angrily that the Dursleys scuttled back to their corner. "How could a car crash kill Lily an' James Potter? It's an outrage! A scandal! Harry Potter not knowin' his own story when every kid in our world knows his name!" "But why? What happened?" Harry asked urgently.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The anger faded from Hagrid's face. He looked suddenly anxious.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I never expected this," he said, in a low, worried voice. "I had no idea, when Dumbledore told me there might be trouble gettin' hold of yeh, how much yeh didn't know. Ah, Harry, I don' know if I'm the right person ter tell yeh -- but someone 3 s gotta -- yeh can't go off ter Hogwarts not knowin'."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He threw a dirty look at the Dursleys.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Well, it's best yeh know as much as I can tell yeh -- mind, I can't tell yeh everythin', it's a great myst'ry, parts of it...."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He sat down, stared into the fire for a few seconds, and then said, "It begins, I suppose, with -- with a person called -- but it's incredible yeh don't know his name, everyone in our world knows --"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Who? "

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Well -- I don' like sayin' the name if I can help it. No one does."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Why not?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Gulpin' gargoyles, Harry, people are still scared. Blimey, this is difficult. See, there was this wizard who went... bad. As bad as you could go. Worse. Worse than worse. His name was..."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hagrid gulped, but no words came out.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Could you write it down?" Harry suggested.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Nah -can't spell it. All right -- Voldemort. " Hagrid shuddered. "Don' make me say it again. Anyway, this -- this wizard, about twenty years ago now, started lookin' fer followers. Got 'em, too -- some were afraid, some just wanted a bit o' his power, 'cause he was gettin' himself power, all right. Dark days, Harry. Didn't know who ter trust, didn't dare get friendly with strange wizards or witches... terrible things happened. He was takin' over. 'Course, some stood up to him -- an' he killed 'em. Horribly. One o' the only safe places left was Hogwarts. Reckon Dumbledore's the only one You-Know-Who was afraid of. Didn't dare try takin' the school, not jus' then, anyway.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Now, yer mum an' dad were as good a witch an' wizard as I ever knew. Head boy an' girl at Hogwarts in their day! Suppose the myst'ry is why You-Know-Who never tried to get 'em on his side before... probably knew they were too close ter Dumbledore ter want anythin' ter do with the Dark Side.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Maybe he thought he could persuade 'em... maybe he just wanted 'em outta the way. All anyone knows is, he turned up in the village where you was all living, on Halloween ten years ago. You was just a year old. He came ter yer house an' -- an' --"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hagrid suddenly pulled out a very dirty, spotted handkerchief and blew his nose with a sound like a foghorn.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Sorry," he said. "But it's that sad -- knew yer mum an' dad, an' nicer people yeh couldn't find -- anyway..."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You-Know-Who killed 'em. An' then -- an' this is the real myst'ry of the thing -- he tried to kill you, too. Wanted ter make a clean job of it, I suppose, or maybe he just liked killin' by then. But he couldn't

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: do it. Never wondered how you got that mark on yer forehead? That was no ordinary cut. That's what yeh get when a Powerful, evil curse touches yeh -- took care of yer mum an' dad an' yer house, even -- but it didn't work on you, an' that's why yer famous, Harry. No one ever lived after he decided ter kill 'em, no one except you, an' he'd killed some o' the best witches an' wizards of the age -- the McKinnons, the Bones, the Prewetts -- an' you was only a baby, an' you lived."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Something very painful was going on in Harry's mind. As Hagrid's story came to a close, he saw again the blinding flash of green light, more clearly than he had ever remembered it before -- and he remembered something else, for the first time in his life: a high, cold, cruel laugh.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hagrid was watching him sadly.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Took yeh from the ruined house myself, on Dumbledore's orders. Brought yeh ter this lot..."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Load of old tosh," said Uncle Vernon. Harry jumped; he had almost forgotten that the Dursleys were there. Uncle Vernon certainly seemed to have got back his courage. He was glaring at Hagrid and his fists were clenched.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Now, you listen here, boy," he snarled, "I accept there's something strange about you, probably nothing a good beating wouldn't have cured -- and as for all this about your parents, well, they were weirdos, no denying it, and the world's better off without them in my opinion -- asked for all they got, getting mixed up with these wizarding types -- just what I expected, always knew they'd come to a sticky end --"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: But at that moment, Hagrid leapt from the sofa and drew a battered pink umbrella from inside his coat. Pointing this at Uncle Vernon like a sword, he said, "I'm warning you, Dursley -I'm warning you -- one more word... "

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: In danger of being speared on the end of an umbrella by a bearded giant, Uncle Vernon's courage failed again; he flattened himself against the wall and fell silent.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "That's better," said Hagrid, breathing heavily and sitting back down on the sofa, which this time sagged right down to the floor.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry, meanwhile, still had questions to ask, hundreds of them.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "But what happened to Vol--, sorry -- I mean, You-Know-Who?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Good question, Harry. Disappeared. Vanished. Same night he tried ter kill you. Makes yeh even more famous. That's the biggest myst'ry, see... he was gettin' more an' more powerful -- why'd he go?

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Some say he died. Codswallop, in my opinion. Dunno if he had enough human left in him to die. Some say he's still out there, bidin' his time, like, but I don' believe it. People who was on his side came back ter ours. Some of 'em came outta kinda trances. Don~ reckon they could've done if he was comin' back.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Most of us reckon he's still out there somewhere but lost his powers. Too weak to carry on. 'Cause somethin' about you finished him, Harry. There was somethin' goin' on that night he hadn't counted on -- I dunno what it was, no one does -- but somethin' about you stumped him, all right."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hagrid looked at Harry with warmth and respect blazing in his eyes, but Harry, instead of feeling pleased and proud, felt quite sure there had been a horrible mistake. A wizard? Him? How could he possibly be? He'd spent his life being clouted by Dudley, and bullied by Aunt Petunia and Uncle Vernon; if he was really a wizard, why hadn't they been turned into warty toads every time they'd tried to lock him in his cupboard? If he'd once defeated the greatest sorcerer in the world, how come Dudley had always been able to kick him around like a football?

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Hagrid," he said quietly, "I think you must have made a mistake. I don't think I can be a wizard."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: To his surprise, Hagrid chuckled.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Not a wizard, eh? Never made things happen when you was scared or angry?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry looked into the fire. Now he came to think about it... every odd thing that had ever made his aunt and uncle furious with him had happened when he, Harry, had been upset or angry... chased by Dudley's gang, he had somehow found himself out of their reach... dreading going to school with that ridiculous haircut, he'd managed to make it grow back... and the very last time Dudley had hit him, hadn't he got his

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: revenge, without even realizing he was doing it? Hadn't he set a boa constrictor on him?

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry looked back at Hagrid, smiling, and saw that Hagrid was positively beaming at him.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "See?" said Hagrid. "Harry Potter, not a wizard -- you wait, you'll be right famous at Hogwarts."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: But Uncle Vernon wasn't going to give in without a fight.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Haven't I told you he's not going?" he hissed. "He's going to Stonewall High and he'll be grateful for it. I've read those letters and he needs all sorts of rubbish -- spell books and wands and --"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "If he wants ter go, a great Muggle like you won't stop him," growled Hagrid. "Stop Lily an' James Potter' s son goin' ter Hogwarts! Yer mad. His name's been down ever since he was born. He's off ter the finest school of witchcraft and wizardry in the world. Seven years there and he won't know himself. He'll be with youngsters of his own sort, fer a change, an' he'll be under the greatest headmaster Hogwarts ever had Albus Dumbled--"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I AM NOT PAYING FOR SOME CRACKPOT OLD FOOL To TEACH HIM MAGIC TRICKS!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: yelled Uncle Vernon.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: But he had finally gone too far. Hagrid seized his umbrella and whirled it over his head, "NEVER," he thundered, "- INSULT- ALBUS- DUMBLEDORE- IN- FRONT- OF- ME!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He brought the umbrella swishing down through the air to point at Dudley -- there was a flash of violet light, a sound like a firecracker, a sharp squeal, and the next second, Dudley was dancing on the spot with his hands clasped over his fat bottom, howling in pain. When he turned his back on them, Harry saw a curly pig's tail poking through a hole in his trousers.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Uncle Vernon roared. Pulling Aunt Petunia and Dudley into the other room, he cast one last terrified look at Hagrid and slammed the door behind them.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hagrid looked down at his umbrella and stroked his beard.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Shouldn'ta lost me temper," he said ruefully, "but it didn't work anyway. Meant ter turn him into a pig, but I suppose he was so much like a pig anyway there wasn't much left ter do."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He cast a sideways look at Harry under his bushy eyebrows.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Be grateful if yeh didn't mention that ter anyone at Hogwarts," he said. "I'm -- er -- not supposed ter do magic, strictly speakin'. I was allowed ter do a bit ter follow yeh an' get yer letters to yeh an' stuff -- one o' the reasons I was so keen ter take on the job

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Why aren't you supposed to do magic?" asked Harry.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Oh, well -- I was at Hogwarts meself but I -- er -- got expelled, ter tell yeh the truth. In me third year. They snapped me wand in half an' everything. But Dumbledore let me stay on as gamekeeper. Great man, Dumbledore." "Why were you expelled?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "It's gettin' late and we've got lots ter do tomorrow," said Hagrid loudly. "Gotta get up ter town, get all yer books an' that."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He took off his thick black coat and threw it to Harry.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You can kip under that," he said. "Don' mind if it wriggles a bit, I think I still got a couple o' dormice in one o' the pockets."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: CHAPTER FIVE

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: DIAGON ALLEY

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry woke early the next morning. Although he could tell it was daylight, he kept his eyes shut tight.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "It was a dream, he told himself firmly. "I dreamed a giant called Hagrid came to tell me I was going to a school for wizards. When I open my eyes I'll be at home in my cupboard."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: There was suddenly a loud tapping noise.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: And there's Aunt Petunia knocking on the door, Harry thought, his heart sinking. But he still didn't open his eyes. It had been such a good

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: dream.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Tap. Tap. Tap.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "All right," Harry mumbled, "I'm getting up."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He sat up and Hagrid's heavy coat fell off him. The hut was full of sunlight, the storm was over, Hagrid himself was asleep on the collapsed sofa, and there was an owl rapping its claw on the window, a newspaper held in its beak.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry scrambled to his feet, so happy he felt as though a large balloon was swelling inside him. He went straight to the window and jerked it open. The owl swooped in and dropped the newspaper on top of Hagrid, who didn't wake up. The owl then fluttered onto the floor and began to attack Hagrid's coat.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Don't do that."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry tried to wave the owl out of the way, but it snapped its beak fiercely at him and carried on savaging the coat.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Hagrid!" said Harry loudly. "There's an owl

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Pay him," Hagrid grunted into the sofa.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "He wants payin' fer deliverin' the paper. Look in the pockets." Hagrid's coat seemed to be made of nothing but pockets -- bunches of keys, slug pellets, balls of string, peppermint humbugs, teabags... finally, Harry pulled out a handful of strange-looking coins.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Give him five Knuts," said Hagrid sleepily.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Knuts?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "The little bronze ones."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry counted out five little bronze coins, and the owl held out his leg so Harry could put the money into a small leather pouch tied to it. Then he flew off through the open window.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hagrid yawned loudly, sat up, and stretched.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Best be Off, Harry, lots ter do today, gotta get up ter London an' buy all yer stuff fer school."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry was turning over the wizard coins and looking at them. He had just thought of something that made him feel as though the happy balloon inside him had got a puncture.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Um -- Hagrid?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Mm?" said Hagrid, who was pulling on his huge boots.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I haven't got any money -- and you heard Uncle Vernon last night ... he won't pay for me to go and learn magic."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Don't worry about that," said Hagrid, standing up and scratching his head. "D'yeh think yer parents didn't leave yeh anything?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "But if their house was destroyed --"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "They didn' keep their gold in the house, boy! Nah, first stop fer us is Gringotts. Wizards' bank. Have a sausage, they're not bad cold -- an' I wouldn' say no teh a bit o' yer birthday cake, neither."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Wizards have banks?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Just the one. Gringotts. Run by goblins."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry dropped the bit of sausage he was holding.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Goblins?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Yeah -- so yeh'd be mad ter try an' rob it, I'll tell yeh that. Never mess with goblins, Harry. Gringotts is the safest place in the world fer anything yeh want ter keep safe -- 'cept maybe Hogwarts. As a matter o' fact, I gotta visit Gringotts anyway. Fer Dumbledore. Hogwarts business." Hagrid drew himself up proudly. "He usually gets me ter do important stuff fer him. Fetchin' you gettin' things from Gringotts -- knows he can trust me, see.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Got everythin'? Come on, then."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry followed Hagrid out onto the rock. The sky was quite clear now and the sea gleamed in the sunlight. The boat Uncle Vernon had hired was still there, with a lot of water in the bottom after the storm.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "How did you get here?" Harry asked, looking around for another boat. "Flew," said Hagrid.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Flew?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Yeah -- but we'll go back in this. Not s'pposed ter use magic now I've got yeh."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: They settled down in the boat, Harry still staring at Hagrid, trying to imagine him flying.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Seems a shame ter row, though," said Hagrid, giving Harry another of his sideways looks. "If I was ter -- er -- speed things up a bit, would yeh mind not mentionin' it at Hogwarts?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Of course not," said Harry, eager to see more magic. Hagrid pulled out the pink umbrella again, tapped it twice on the side of the boat, and they sped off toward land.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Why would you be mad to try and rob Gringotts?" Harry asked.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Spells -- enchantments," said Hagrid, unfolding his newspaper as he spoke. "They say there's dragons guardin' the highsecurity vaults. And then yeh gotta find yer way -- Gringotts is hundreds of miles under London, see. Deep under the Underground. Yeh'd die of hunger tryin' ter get out, even if yeh did manage ter get yer hands on summat."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry sat and thought about this while Hagrid read his newspaper, the Daily Prophet. Harry had learned from Uncle Vernon that people liked to be left alone while they did this, but it was very difficult, he'd never had so many questions in his life.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Ministry o' Magic messin' things up as usual," Hagrid muttered, turning the page.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "There's a Ministry of Magic?" Harry asked, before he could stop himself.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "'Course," said Hagrid. "They wanted Dumbledore fer Minister, 0 '

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: course, but he'd never leave Hogwarts, so old Cornelius Fudge got the job. Bungler if ever there was one. So he pelts Dumbledore with owls every morning, askin' fer advice."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "But what does a Ministry of Magic do?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Well, their main job is to keep it from the Muggles that there's still witches an' wizards up an' down the country."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Why?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Why? Blimey, Harry, everyone'd be wantin' magic solutions to their problems. Nah, we're best left alone."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: At this moment the boat bumped gently into the harbor wall. Hagrid folded up his newspaper, and they clambered up the stone steps onto the street.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Passersby stared a lot at Hagrid as they walked through the little town to the station. Harry couldn't blame them. Not only was Hagrid twice as tall as anyone else, he kept pointing at perfectly ordinary things like parking meters and saying loudly, "See that, Harry? Things these Muggles dream up, eh?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Hagrid," said Harry, panting a bit as he ran to keep up, "did you say there are dragons at Gringotts?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Well, so they say," said Hagrid. "Crikey, I'd like a dragon."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You'd like one?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Wanted one ever since I was a kid -- here we go."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: They had reached the station. There was a train to London in five minutes' time. Hagrid, who didn't understand "Muggle money," as he called it, gave the bills to Harry so he could buy their tickets.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: People stared more than ever on the train. Hagrid took up two seats and sat knitting what looked like a canary-yellow circus tent.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Still got yer letter, Harry?" he asked as he counted stitches. Harry took the parchment envelope out of his pocket.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Good," said Hagrid. "There's a list there of everything yeh need."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry unfolded a second piece of paper he hadn't noticed the night before, and read:

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: HOGWARTS SCHOOL of WITCHCRAFT and WIZARDRY

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: UNIFORM

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: First-year students will require:

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: 1. Three sets of plain work robes (black)

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: 2. One plain pointed hat (black) for day wear

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: 3. One pair of protective gloves (dragon hide or similar)

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: 4. One winter cloak (black, silver fastenings)

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Please note that all pupils' clothes should carry name tags

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: COURSE BOOKS

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: All students should have a copy of each of the following:

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The Standard Book of Spells (Grade 1) by Miranda Goshawk

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: A History of Magic by Bathilda Bagshot

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Magical Theory by Adalbert Waffling

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: A Beginners' Guide to Transfiguration by Emetic Switch

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: One Thousand Magical Herbs and Fungi by Phyllida Spore

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Magical Drafts and Potions by Arsenius Jigger

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them by Newt Scamander The Dark Forces: A Guide to Self-Protection by Quentin Trimble OTHER EQUIPMENT

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: OTHER EQUIPMENT

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: wand cauldron (pewter, standard size 2) set

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: glass or crystal phials

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: telescope set

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: brass scales

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Students may also bring an owl OR a cat OR a toad

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: PARENTS ARE REMINDED THAT FIRST YEARS ARE NOT ALLOWED THEIR OWN BROOMSTICKS

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Can we buy all this in London?" Harry wondered aloud.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "If yeh know where to go," said Hagrid.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry had never been to London before. Although Hagrid seemed to know where he was going, he was obviously not used to getting there in an ordinary way. He got stuck in the ticket barrier on the Underground, and complained loudly that the seats were too small and the trains too slow.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I don't know how the Muggles manage without magic," he said as they climbed a broken-down escalator that led up to a bustling road lined with shops.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hagrid was so huge that he parted the crowd easily; all Harry had to do was keep close behind him. They passed book shops and music stores, hamburger restaurants and cinemas, but nowhere that looked as if it could sell you a magic wand. This was just an ordinary street full of ordinary people. Could there really be piles of wizard gold buried miles beneath them? Were there really shops that sold spell books and broomsticks? Might this not all be some huge joke that the Dursleys had cooked up? If Harry hadn't known that the Dursleys had no sense of humor, he might have thought so; yet somehow, even though everything Hagrid had told him so far was unbelievable, Harry couldn't help trusting him.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "This is it," said Hagrid, coming to a halt, "the Leaky Cauldron. It's a famous place."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: It was a tiny, grubby-looking pub. If Hagrid hadn't pointed it out,

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry wouldn't have noticed it was there. The people hurrying by didn't glance at it. Their eyes slid from the big book shop on one side to the record shop on the other as if they couldn't see the Leaky Cauldron at all. In fact, Harry had the most peculiar feeling that only he and Hagrid could see it. Before he could mention this, Hagrid had steered him inside.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: For a famous place, it was very dark and shabby. A few old women were sitting in a corner, drinking tiny glasses of sherry. One of them was smoking a long pipe. A little man in a top hat was talking to the old bartender, who was quite bald and looked like a toothless walnut. The low buzz of chatter stopped when they walked in. Everyone seemed to know Hagrid; they waved and smiled at him, and the bartender reached for a glass, saying, "The usual, Hagrid?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Can't, Tom, I'm on Hogwarts business," said Hagrid, clapping his great hand on Harry's shoulder and making Harry's knees buckle.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Good Lord," said the bartender, peering at Harry, "is this -- can this be --?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The Leaky Cauldron had suddenly gone completely still and silent.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Bless my soul," whispered the old bartender, "Harry Potter... what an honor."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He hurried out from behind the bar, rushed toward Harry and seized his hand, tears in his eyes.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Welcome back, Mr. Potter, welcome back."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry didn't know what to say. Everyone was looking at him. The old woman with the pipe was puffing on it without realizing it had gone out. Hagrid was beaming.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Then there was a great scraping of chairs and the next moment, Harry found himself shaking hands with everyone in the Leaky Cauldron.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Doris Crockford, Mr. Potter, can't believe I'm meeting you at last."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "So proud, Mr. Potter, I'm just so proud."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Always wanted to shake your hand -- I'm all of a flutter."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Delighted, Mr. Potter, just can't tell you, Diggle's the name, Dedalus Diggle."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I've seen you before!" said Harry, as Dedalus Diggle's top hat fell off in his excitement. "You bowed to me once in a shop."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "He remembers!" cried Dedalus Diggle, looking around at everyone. "Did you hear that? He remembers me!" Harry shook hands again and again -- Doris Crockford kept coming back for more.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: A pale young man made his way forward, very nervously. One of his eyes was twitching.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Professor Quirrell!" said Hagrid. "Harry, Professor Quirrell will be one of your teachers at Hogwarts."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "P-P-Potter," stammered Professor Quirrell, grasping Harry's hand, "c-can't t-tell you how p- pleased I am to meet you."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What sort of magic do you teach, Professor Quirrell?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "D-Defense Against the D-D-Dark Arts," muttered Professor Quirrell, as though he'd rather not think about it. "N-not that you n-need it, eh, P-P-Potter?" He laughed nervously. "You'll be g-getting all your equipment, I suppose? I've g-got to p-pick up a new b-book on vampires, m-myself." He looked terrified at the very thought.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: But the others wouldn't let Professor Quirrell keep Harry to himself. It took almost ten minutes to get away from them all. At last, Hagrid managed to make himself heard over the babble.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Must get on -- lots ter buy. Come on, Harry."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Doris Crockford shook Harry's hand one last time, and Hagrid led them through the bar and out into a small, walled courtyard, where there was nothing but a trash can and a few weeds.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hagrid grinned at Harry.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Told yeh, didn't I? Told yeh you was famous. Even Professor Quirrell

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: was tremblin' ter meet yeh -- mind you, he's usually tremblin'."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Is he always that nervous?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Oh, yeah. Poor bloke. Brilliant mind. He was fine while he was

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: studyin' outta books but then he took a year off ter get some firsthand experience.... They say he met vampires in the Black Forest, and there was a nasty bit o' trouble with a hag -- never been the same since. Scared of the students, scared of his own subject now, where's me umbrella?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Vampires? Hags? Harry's head was swimming. Hagrid, meanwhile, was counting bricks in the wall above the trash can.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Three up... two across he muttered. "Right, stand back, Harry."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He tapped the wall three times with the point of his umbrella.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The brick he had touched quivered -- it wriggled -- in the middle, a small hole appeared -- it grew wider and wider -- a second later they were facing an archway large enough even for Hagrid, an archway onto a cobbled street that twisted and turned out of sight.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Welcome," said Hagrid, "to Diagon Alley."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He grinned at Harry's amazement. They stepped through the archway. Harry looked quickly over his shoulder and saw the archway shrink instantly back into solid wall.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The sun shone brightly on a stack of cauldrons outside the nearest shop. Cauldrons -- All Sizes - Copper, Brass, Pewter, Silver -- Self-Stirring -- Collapsible, said a sign hanging over them.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Yeah, you'll be needin' one," said Hagrid, "but we gotta get yer money first."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry wished he had about eight more eyes. He turned his head in every direction as they walked up the street, trying to look at everything at once: the shops, the things outside them, the people doing their shopping. A plump woman outside an Apothecary was shaking her head as they passed, saying, "Dragon liver, seventeen Sickles an ounce, they're mad...."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: A low, soft hooting came from a dark shop with a sign saying Eeylops Owl Emporium -- Tawny, Screech, Barn, Brown, and Snowy. Several boys of about Harry's age had their noses pressed against a window with broomsticks in it. "Look," Harry heard one of them say, "the new Nimbus Two Thousand -- fastest ever --" There were shops selling robes, shops selling telescopes and strange silver instruments Harry had never seen before, windows stacked with barrels of bat spleens and eels' eyes, tottering piles of spell books, quills, and rolls of parchment, potion bottles, globes of the moon....

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Gringotts," said Hagrid.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: They had reached a snowy white building that towered over the other little shops. Standing beside its burnished bronze doors, wearing a uniform of scarlet and gold, was -

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Yeah, that's a goblin," said Hagrid quietly as they walked up the white stone steps toward him. The goblin was about a head shorter than Harry. He had a swarthy, clever face, a pointed beard and, Harry noticed, very long fingers and feet. He bowed as they walked inside. Now they were facing a second pair of doors, silver this time, with words engraved upon them:

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Enter, stranger, but take heed

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Of what awaits the sin of greed,

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: For those who take, but do not earn,

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Must pay most dearly in their turn.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: So if you seek beneath our floors

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: A treasure that was never yours,

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Thief, you have been warned, beware

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Of finding more than treasure there.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Like I said, Yeh'd be mad ter try an' rob it," said Hagrid.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: A pair of goblins bowed them through the silver doors and they were in a

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: vast marble hall. About a hundred more goblins were sitting on high stools behind a long counter, scribbling in large ledgers, weighing coins in brass scales, examining precious stones through eyeglasses. There were too many doors to count leading off the hall, and yet more goblins were showing people in and out of these. Hagrid and Harry made for the counter.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Morning," said Hagrid to a free goblin. "We've come ter take some money outta Mr. Harry Potter's safe."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You have his key, Sir?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Got it here somewhere," said Hagrid, and he started emptying his pockets onto the counter, scattering a handful of moldy dog biscuits over the goblin's book of numbers. The goblin wrinkled his nose. Harry watched the goblin on their right weighing a pile of rubies as big as glowing coals.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Got it," said Hagrid at last, holding up a tiny golden key.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The goblin looked at it closely.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "That seems to be in order."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "An' I've also got a letter here from Professor Dumbledore," said Hagrid importantly, throwing out his chest. "It's about the YouKnow-What in vault seven hundred and thirteen."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The goblin read the letter carefully.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Very well," he said, handing it back to Hagrid, "I will have Someone take you down to both vaults. Griphook!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Griphook was yet another goblin. Once Hagrid had crammed all the dog biscuits back inside his pockets, he and Harry followed Griphook toward one of the doors leading off the hall.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What's the You-Know-What in vault seven hundred and thirteen?" Harry asked.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Can't tell yeh that," said Hagrid mysteriously. "Very secret. Hogwarts business. Dumbledore's trusted me. More'n my job's worth ter tell yeh that."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Griphook held the door open for them. Harry, who had expected more marble, was surprised. They were in a narrow stone passageway lit with flaming torches. It sloped steeply downward and there were little railway tracks on the floor. Griphook whistled and a small cart came hurtling up the tracks toward them. They climbed in -- Hagrid with some difficulty -- and were off.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: At first they just hurtled through a maze of twisting passages. Harry tried to remember, left, right, right, left, middle fork, right, left, but it was impossible. The rattling cart seemed to know its own way, because Griphook wasn't steering.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry's eyes stung as the cold air rushed past them, but he kept them wide open. Once, he thought he saw a burst of fire at the end of a passage and twisted around to see if it was a dragon, but too late - - they plunged even deeper, passing an underground lake where huge stalactites and stalagmites grew from the ceiling and floor.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: I never know," Harry called to Hagrid over the noise of the cart, "what's the difference between a stalagmite and a stalactite?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Stalagmite's got an 'm' in it," said Hagrid. "An' don' ask me questions just now, I think I'm gonna be sick."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He did look very green, and when the cart stopped at last beside a small door in the passage wall, Hagrid got out and had to lean against the wall to stop his knees from trembling.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Griphook unlocked the door. A lot of green smoke came billowing out, and as it cleared, Harry gasped. Inside were mounds of gold coins. Columns of silver. Heaps of little bronze Knuts.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "All yours," smiled Hagrid.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: All Harry's -- it was incredible. The Dursleys couldn't have known about this or they'd have had it from him faster than blinking. How often had they complained how much Harry cost them to keep? And all the time there had been a small fortune belonging to him, buried deep under London.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hagrid helped Harry pile some of it into a bag.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "The gold ones are Galleons," he explained. "Seventeen silver Sickles to

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: a Galleon and twenty-nine Knuts to a Sickle, it's easy enough. Right, that should be enough fer a couple o' terms, we'll keep the rest safe for yeh." He turned to Griphook. "Vault seven hundred and thirteen now, please, and can we go more slowly?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "One speed only," said Griphook.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: They were going even deeper now and gathering speed. The air became colder and colder as they hurtled round tight corners. They went rattling over an underground ravine, and Harry leaned over the side to try to see what was down at the dark bottom, but Hagrid groaned and pulled him back by the scruff of his neck.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Vault seven hundred and thirteen had no keyhole.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Stand back," said Griphook importantly. He stroked the door gently with one of his long fingers and it simply melted away.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "If anyone but a Gringotts goblin tried that, they'd be sucked through the door and trapped in there," said Griphook.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "How often do you check to see if anyone's inside?" Harry asked.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "About once every ten years," said Griphook with a rather nasty grin.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Something really extraordinary had to be inside this top security vault, Harry was sure, and he leaned forward eagerly, expecting to see fabulous jewels at the very least -- but at first he thought it was empty. Then he noticed a grubby little package wrapped up in brown paper lying on the floor. Hagrid picked it up and tucked it deep inside his coat. Harry longed to know what it was, but knew better than to ask.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Come on, back in this infernal cart, and don't talk to me on the way back, it's best if I keep me mouth shut," said Hagrid.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: One wild cart ride later they stood blinking in the sunlight outside Gringotts. Harry didn't know where to run first now that he had a bag full of money. He didn't have to know how many Galleons there were to a pound to know that he was holding more money than he'd had in his whole life -- more money than even Dudley had ever had.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Might as well get yer uniform," said Hagrid, nodding toward Madam Malkin's Robes for All Occasions. "Listen, Harry, would yeh mind if I

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: slipped off fer a pick-me-up in the Leaky Cauldron? I hate them Gringotts carts." He did still look a bit sick, so Harry entered Madam Malkin's shop alone, feeling nervous.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Madam Malkin was a squat, smiling witch dressed all in mauve.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Hogwarts, clear?" she said, when Harry started to speak. "Got the lot here -- another young man being fitted up just now, in fact. "

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: In the back of the shop, a boy with a pale, pointed face was standing on a footstool while a second witch pinned up his long black robes. Madam Malkin stood Harry on a stool next to him) slipped a long robe over his head, and began to pin it to the right length.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Hello," said the boy, "Hogwarts, too?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Yes," said Harry.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "My father's next door buying my books and mother's up the street looking at wands," said the boy. He had a bored, drawling voice. "Then I'm going to drag them off to took at racing brooms.
