I don't see why first years can't have their own. I think I'll bully father into getting me one and I'll smuggle it in somehow."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry was strongly reminded of Dudley.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Have you got your own broom?" the boy went on.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "No," said Harry.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Play Quidditch at all?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "No," Harry said again, wondering what on earth Quidditch could be.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I do -- Father says it's a crime if I'm not picked to play for my house, and I must say, I agree. Know what house you'll be in yet?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "No," said Harry, feeling more stupid by the minute.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Well, no one really knows until they get there, do they, but I know I'll be in Slytherin, all our family have been -- imagine being in Hufflepuff, I think I'd leave, wouldn't you?" "Mmm," said Harry, wishing he could say something a bit more interesting.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I say, look at that man!" said the boy suddenly, nodding toward the front window. Hagrid was standing there, grinning at Harry and pointing at two large ice creams to show he couldn't come in.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "That's Hagrid," said Harry, pleased to know something the boy didn't. "He works at Hogwarts."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Oh," said the boy, "I've heard of him. He's a sort of servant, isn't he?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "He's the gamekeeper," said Harry. He was liking the boy less and less every second.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Yes, exactly. I heard he's a sort of savage -- lives in a hut on the school grounds and every now and then he gets drunk, tries to do magic, and ends up setting fire to his bed."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I think he's brilliant," said Harry coldly.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Do you?" said the boy, with a slight sneer. "Why is he with you? Where are your parents?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "They're dead," said Harry shortly. He didn't feel much like going into the matter with this boy.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Oh, sorry," said the other,. not sounding sorry at all. "But they were our kind, weren't they?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "They were a witch and wizard, if that's what you mean."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I really don't think they should let the other sort in, do you? They're just not the same, they've never been brought up to know our ways. Some of them have never even heard of Hogwarts until they get the letter, imagine. I think they should keep it in the old wizarding families. What's your surname, anyway?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: But before Harry could answer, Madam Malkin said, "That's you done, my dear," and Harry, not sorry for an excuse to stop talking to the boy, hopped down from the footstool.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Well, I'll see you at Hogwarts, I suppose," said the drawling boy.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry was rather quiet as he ate the ice cream Hagrid had bought him (chocolate and raspberry with chopped nuts).

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What's up?" said Hagrid.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Nothing," Harry lied. They stopped to buy parchment and quills. Harry cheered up a bit when he found a bottle of ink that changed color as you wrote. When they had left the shop, he said, "Hagrid, what's Quidditch?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Blimey, Harry, I keep forgettin' how little yeh know -- not knowin' about Quidditch!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Don't make me feel worse," said Harry. He told Hagrid about the pate boy in Madam Malkin's.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "--and he said people from Muggle families shouldn't even be allowed in."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Yer not from a Muggle family. If he'd known who yeh were -- he's grown up knowin' yer name if his parents are wizardin' folk. You saw what everyone in the Leaky Cauldron was like when they saw yeh. Anyway, what does he know about it, some o' the best I ever saw were the only ones with magic in 'em in a long line 0' Muggles -- look at yer mum! Look what she had fer a sister!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "So what is Quidditch?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "It's our sport. Wizard sport. It's like -- like soccer in the Muggle world -- everyone follows Quidditch -- played up in the air on broomsticks and there's four balls -- sorta hard ter explain the rules." "And what are Slytherin and Hufflepuff?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "School houses. There's four. Everyone says Hufflepuff are a lot o' duffers, but --"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I bet I'm in Hufflepuff" said Harry gloomily.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Better Hufflepuff than Slytherin," said Hagrid darkly. "There's not a single witch or wizard who went bad who wasn't in Slytherin. You-Know-Who was one."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Vol-, sorry - You-Know-Who was at Hogwarts?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Years an' years ago," said Hagrid.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: They bought Harry's school books in a shop called Flourish and Blotts where the shelves were stacked to the ceiling with books as large as paving stones bound in leather; books the size of postage stamps in covers of silk; books full of peculiar symbols and a few books with nothing in them at all. Even Dudley, who never read anything, would have been wild to get his hands on some of these. Hagrid almost had to drag Harry away from Curses and Countercurses (Bewitch Your Friends and Befuddle Your Enemies with the Latest Revenges: Hair Loss, Jelly-Legs, Tongue- Tying and Much, Much More) by Professor Vindictus Viridian.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I was trying to find out how to curse Dudley."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I'm not sayin' that's not a good idea, but yer not ter use magic in the Muggle world except in very special circumstances," said Hagrid. "An' anyway, yeh couldn' work any of them curses yet, yeh'll need a lot more study before yeh get ter that level."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hagrid wouldn't let Harry buy a solid gold cauldron, either ("It says pewter on yer list"), but they got a nice set of scales for weighing potion ingredients and a collapsible brass telescope. Then they visited the Apothecary, which was fascinating enough to make up for its horrible smell, a mixture of bad eggs and rotted cabbages. Barrels of slimy stuff stood on the floor; jars of herbs, dried roots, and bright powders lined the walls; bundles of feathers, strings of fangs, and snarled claws hung from the ceiling. While Hagrid asked the man behind the counter for a supply of some basic potion ingredients for Harry, Harry himself examined silver unicorn horns at twenty-one Galleons each and minuscule, glittery-black beetle eyes (five Knuts a scoop).

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Outside the Apothecary, Hagrid checked Harry's list again.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Just yer wand left - A yeah, an' I still haven't got yeh a birthday present."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry felt himself go red.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You don't have to --"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I know I don't have to. Tell yeh what, I'll get yer animal. Not a toad, toads went outta fashion years ago, yeh'd be laughed at - an' I don' like cats, they make me sneeze. I'll get yer an owl. All the kids want

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: owls, they're dead useful, carry yer mail an' everythin'."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Twenty minutes later, they left Eeylops Owl Emporium, which had been dark and full of rustling and flickering, jewel-bright eyes. Harry now carried a large cage that held a beautiful snowy owl, fast asleep with her head under her wing. He couldn't stop stammering his thanks, sounding just like Professor Quirrell.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Don' mention it," said Hagrid gruffly. "Don' expect you've had a lotta presents from them Dursleys. Just Ollivanders left now - only place fer wands, Ollivanders, and yeh gotta have the best wand."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: A magic wand... this was what Harry had been really looking forward to.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The last shop was narrow and shabby. Peeling gold letters over the door read Ollivanders: Makers of Fine Wands since 382 B.C. A single wand lay on a faded purple cushion in the dusty window.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: A tinkling bell rang somewhere in the depths of the shop as they stepped inside. It was a tiny place, empty except for a single, spindly chair that Hagrid sat on to wait. Harry felt strangely as though he had entered a very strict library; he swallowed a lot of new questions that had just occurred to him and looked instead at the thousands of narrow boxes piled neatly right up to the ceiling. For some reason, the back of his neck prickled. The very dust and silence in here seemed to tingle with some secret magic.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Good afternoon," said a soft voice. Harry jumped. Hagrid must have jumped, too, because there was a loud crunching noise and he got quickly off the spindly chair.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: An old man was standing before them, his wide, pale eyes shining like moons through the gloom of the shop.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Hello," said Harry awkwardly.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Ah yes," said the man. "Yes, yes. I thought I'd be seeing you soon. Harry Potter." It wasn't a question. "You have your mother's eyes. It seems only yesterday she was in here herself, buying her first wand. Ten and a quarter inches long, swishy, made of willow. Nice wand for charm work."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Mr. Ollivander moved closer to Harry. Harry wished he would blink. Those

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: silvery eyes were a bit creepy.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Your father, on the other hand, favored a mahogany wand. Eleven inches. Pliable. A little more power and excellent for transfiguration. Well, I say your father favored it -- it's really the wand that chooses the wizard, of course."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Mr. Ollivander had come so close that he and Harry were almost nose to nose. Harry could see himself reflected in those misty eyes.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "And that's where..."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Mr. Ollivander touched the lightning scar on Harry's forehead with a long, white finger.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I'm sorry to say I sold the wand that did it," he said softly. "Thirteen-and-a-half inches. Yew. Powerful wand, very powerful, and in the wrong hands... well, if I'd known what that wand was going out into the world to do...."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He shook his head and then, to Harry's relief, spotted Hagrid.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Rubeus! Rubeus Hagrid! How nice to see you again.... Oak, sixteen inches, rather bendy, wasn't it?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "It was, sir, yes," said Hagrid.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Good wand, that one. But I suppose they snapped it in half when you got expelled?" said Mr. Ollivander, suddenly stern.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Er -- yes, they did, yes," said Hagrid, shuffling his feet. "I've still got the pieces, though," he added brightly.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "But you don't use them?" said Mr. Ollivander sharply.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Oh, no, sit," said Hagrid quickly. Harry noticed he gripped his pink umbrella very tightly as he spoke.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Hmmm," said Mr. Ollivander, giving Hagrid a piercing look. "Well, now -- Mr. Potter. Let me see." He pulled a long tape measure with silver markings out of his pocket. "Which is your wand arm?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Er -- well, I'm right-handed," said Harry.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Hold out your arm. That's it." He measured Harry from shoulder to finger, then wrist to elbow, shoulder to floor, knee to armpit and round his head. As he measured, he said, "Every Ollivander wand has a core of a powerful magical substance, Mr. Potter. We use unicorn hairs, phoenix tail feathers, and the heartstrings of dragons. No two Ollivander wands are the same, just as no two unicorns, dragons, or phoenixes are quite the same. And of course, you will never get such good results with another wizard's wand."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry suddenly realized that the tape measure, which was measuring between his nostrils, was doing this on its own. Mr. Ollivander was flitting around the shelves, taking down boxes.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "That will do," he said, and the tape measure crumpled into a heap on the floor. "Right then, Mr. Potter. Try this one. Beechwood and dragon heartstring. Nine inches. Nice and flexible. just take it and give it a wave."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry took the wand and (feeling foolish) waved it around a bit, but Mr. Ollivander snatched it out of his hand almost at once.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Maple and phoenix feather. Seven inches. Quite whippy. Try --"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry tried -- but he had hardly raised the wand when it, too, was snatched back by Mr. Ollivander.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "No, no -here, ebony and unicorn hair, eight and a half inches, springy. Go on, go on, try it out."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry tried. And tried. He had no idea what Mr. Ollivander was waiting for. The pile of tried wands was mounting higher and higher on the spindly chair, but the more wands Mr. Ollivander pulled from the shelves, the happier he seemed to become.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Tricky customer, eh? Not to worry, we'll find the perfect match here somewhere -- I wonder, now - - yes, why not -- unusual combination -- holly and phoenix feather, eleven inches, nice and supple."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry took the wand. He felt a sudden warmth in his fingers. He raised the wand above his head, brought it swishing down through the dusty air and a stream of red and gold sparks shot from the end like a firework, throwing dancing spots of light on to the walls. Hagrid whooped and

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: clapped and Mr. Ollivander cried, "Oh, bravo! Yes, indeed, oh, very good. Well, well, well... how curious... how very curious... "

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He put Harry's wand back into its box and wrapped it in brown paper, still muttering, "Curious... curious..

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Sorry," said Harry, "but what's curious?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Mr. Ollivander fixed Harry with his pale stare.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I remember every wand I've ever sold, Mr. Potter. Every single wand. It so happens that the phoenix whose tail feather is in your wand, gave another feather -- just one other. It is very curious indeed that you should be destined for this wand when its brother why, its brother gave you that scar."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry swallowed.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Yes, thirteen-and-a-half inches. Yew. Curious indeed how these things happen. The wand chooses the wizard, remember.... I think we must expect great things from you, Mr. Potter.... After all, He- Who-Must-Not-Be-Named did great things -- terrible, yes, but great."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry shivered. He wasn't sure he liked Mr. Ollivander too much. He paid seven gold Galleons for his wand, and Mr. Ollivander bowed them from his shop.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The late afternoon sun hung low in the sky as Harry and Hagrid made their way back down Diagon Alley, back through the wall, back through the Leaky Cauldron, now empty. Harry didn't speak at all as they walked down the road; he didn't even notice how much people were gawking at them on the Underground, laden as they were with all their funny-shaped packages, with the snowy owl asleep in its cage on Harry's lap. Up another escalator, out into Paddington station; Harry only realized where they were when Hagrid tapped him on the shoulder.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Got time fer a bite to eat before yer train leaves," he said.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He bought Harry a hamburger and they sat down on plastic seats to eat them. Harry kept looking around. Everything looked so strange, somehow.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You all right, Harry? Yer very quiet," said Hagrid.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry wasn't sure he could explain. He'd just had the best birthday of his life -- and yet -- he chewed his hamburger, trying to find the words.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Everyone thinks I'm special," he said at last. "All those people in the Leaky Cauldron, Professor Quirrell, Mr. Ollivander... but I don't know anything about magic at all. How can they expect great things? I'm famous and I can't even remember what I'm famous for. I don't know what happened when Vol-, sorry -- I mean, the night my parents died."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hagrid leaned across the table. Behind the wild beard and eyebrows he wore a very kind smile.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Don' you worry, Harry. You'll learn fast enough. Everyone starts at the beginning at Hogwarts, you'll be just fine. just be yerself. I know it's hard. Yeh've been singled out, an' that's always hard. But yeh'll have a great time at Hogwarts -- I did -- still do, 'smatter of fact."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hagrid helped Harry on to the train that would take him back to the Dursleys, then handed him an envelope.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Yer ticket fer Hogwarts, " he said. "First o' September -- King's Cross -- it's all on yer ticket. Any problems with the Dursleys, send me a letter with yer owl, she'll know where to find me.... See yeh soon, Harry."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The train pulled out of the station. Harry wanted to watch Hagrid until he was out of sight; he rose in his seat and pressed his nose against the window, but he blinked and Hagrid had gone.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: CHAPTER SIX

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: THE JOURNEY FROM PLATFORM NINE AND THREE-QUARTERS

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry's last month with the Dursleys wasn't fun. True, Dudley was now so scared of Harry he wouldn't stay in the same room, while Aunt Petunia and Uncle Vernon didn't shut Harry in his cupboard, force him to do anything, or shout at him -- in fact, they didn't speak to him at all. Half terrified, half furious, they acted as though any chair with Harry in it were empty. Although this was an improvement in many ways, it did become a bit depressing after a while.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry kept to his room, with his new owl for company. He had decided to call her Hedwig, a name he had found in A History of Magic. His school books were very interesting. He lay on his bed reading late into the night, Hedwig swooping in and out of the open window as she pleased. It was lucky that Aunt Petunia didn't come in to vacuum anymore, because Hedwig kept bringing back dead mice. Every night before he went to sleep, Harry ticked off another day on the piece of paper he had pinned to the wall, counting down to September the first.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: On the last day of August he thought he'd better speak to his aunt and uncle about getting to King's Cross station the next day, so he went down to the living room where they were watching a quiz show on television. He cleared his throat to let them know he was there, and Dudley screamed and ran from the room.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Er -- Uncle Vernon?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Uncle Vernon grunted to show he was listening.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Er -- I need to be at King's Cross tomorrow to -- to go to Hogwarts."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Uncle Vernon grunted again.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Would it be all right if you gave me a lift?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Grunt. Harry supposed that meant yes.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Thank you."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He was about to go back upstairs when Uncle Vernon actually spoke.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Funny way to get to a wizards' school, the train. Magic carpets all got punctures, have they?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry didn't say anything.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Where is this school, anyway?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I don't know," said Harry, realizing this for the first time. He pulled the ticket Hagrid had given him out of his pocket.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I just take the train from platform nine and three-quarters at eleven o'clock," he read.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: His aunt and uncle stared.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Platform what?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Nine and three-quarters."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Don't talk rubbish," said Uncle Vernon. "There is no platform nine and three-quarters."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "It's on my ticket."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Barking," said Uncle Vernon, "howling mad, the lot of them. You'll see. You just wait. All right, we'll take you to King's Cross. We're going up to London tomorrow anyway, or I wouldn't bother."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Why are you going to London?" Harry asked, trying to keep things friendly.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Taking Dudley to the hospital," growled Uncle Vernon. "Got to have that ruddy tail removed before he goes to Smeltings."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry woke at five o'clock the next morning and was too excited and nervous to go back to sleep. He got up and pulled on his jeans because he didn't want to walk into the station in his wizard's robes -- he'd change on the train. He checked his Hogwarts list yet again to make sure he had everything he needed, saw that Hedwig was shut safely in her cage, and then paced the room, waiting for the Dursleys to get up. Two hours later, Harry's huge, heavy trunk had been loaded into the Dursleys' car, Aunt Petunia had talked Dudley into sitting next to Harry, and they had set off.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: They reached King's Cross at half past ten. Uncle Vernon dumped Harry's trunk onto a cart and wheeled it into the station for him. Harry thought this was strangely kind until Uncle Vernon stopped dead, facing the platforms with a nasty grin on his face.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Well, there you are, boy. Platform nine -- platform ten. Your platform should be somewhere in the middle, but they don't seem to have built it yet, do they?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He was quite right, of course. There was a big plastic number nine over one platform and a big plastic number ten over the one next to it, and

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: in the middle, nothing at all.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Have a good term," said Uncle Vernon with an even nastier smile. He left without another word. Harry turned and saw the Dursleys drive away. All three of them were laughing. Harry's mouth went rather dry. What on earth was he going to do? He was starting to attract a lot of funny looks, because of Hedwig. He'd have to ask someone.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He stopped a passing guard, but didn't dare mention platform nine and three-quarters. The guard had never heard of Hogwarts and when Harry couldn't even tell him what part of the country it was in, he started to get annoyed, as though Harry was being stupid on purpose. Getting desperate, Harry asked for the train that left at eleven o'clock, but the guard said there wasn't one. In the end the guard strode away, muttering about time wasters. Harry was now trying hard not to panic. According to the large clock over the arrivals board, he had ten minutes left to get on the train to Hogwarts and he had no idea how to do it; he was stranded in the middle of a station with a trunk he could hardly lift, a pocket full of wizard money, and a large owl.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hagrid must have forgotten to tell him something you had to do, like tapping the third brick on the left to get into Diagon Alley. He wondered if he should get out his wand and start tapping the ticket inspector's stand between platforms nine and ten.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: At that moment a group of people passed just behind him and he caught a few words of what they were saying.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "-- packed with Muggles, of course --"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry swung round. The speaker was a plump woman who was talking to four boys, all with flaming red hair. Each of them was pushing a trunk like Harry's in front of him -- and they had an owl.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Heart hammering, Harry pushed his cart after them. They stopped and so did he, just near enough to hear what they were saying.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Now, what's the platform number?" said the boys' mother.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Nine and three-quarters!" piped a small girl, also red-headed, who was holding her hand, "Mom, can't I go... "

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You're not old enough, Ginny, now be quiet. All right, Percy, you go

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: first."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: What looked like the oldest boy marched toward platforms nine and ten. Harry watched, careful not to blink in case he missed it -- but just as the boy reached the dividing barrier between the two platforms, a large crowd of tourists came swarming in front of him and by the time the last backpack had cleared away, the boy had vanished.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Fred, you next," the plump woman said.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I'm not Fred, I'm George," said the boy. "Honestly, woman, you call yourself our mother? CarA you tell I'm George?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Sorry, George, dear."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Only joking, I am Fred," said the boy, and off he went. His twin called after him to hurry up, and he must have done so, because a second later, he had gone -- but how had he done it?

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Now the third brother was walking briskly toward the barrier he was almost there -- and then, quite suddenly, he wasn't anywhere.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: There was nothing else for it.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Excuse me," Harry said to the plump woman.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Hello, dear," she said. "First time at Hogwarts? Ron's new, too."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: She pointed at the last and youngest of her sons. He was tall, thin, and gangling, with freckles, big hands and feet, and a long nose.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Yes," said Harry. "The thing is -- the thing is, I don't know how to --"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "How to get onto the platform?" she said kindly, and Harry nodded.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Not to worry," she said. "All you have to do is walk straight at the barrier between platforms nine and ten. Don't stop and don't be scared you'll crash into it, that's very important. Best do it at a bit of a run if you're nervous. Go on, go now before Ron."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Er -- okay," said Harry.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He pushed his trolley around and stared at the barrier. It looked very solid.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He started to walk toward it. People jostled him on their way to platforms nine and ten. Harry walked more quickly. He was going to smash right into that barrier and then he'd be in trouble -- leaning forward on his cart, he broke into a heavy run -- the barrier was coming nearer and nearer -- he wouldn't be able to stop -- the cart was out of control -- he was a foot away -- he closed his eyes ready for the crash --

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: It didn't come... he kept on running... he opened his eyes. A scarlet steam engine was waiting next to a platform packed with people. A sign overhead said Hogwarts Express, eleven O'clock. Harry looked behind him and saw a wrought-iron archway where the barrier had been, with the words Platform Nine and Three-Quarters on it, He had done it.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Smoke from the engine drifted over the heads of the chattering crowd, while cats of every color wound here and there between their legs. Owls hooted to one another in a disgruntled sort of way over the babble and the scraping of heavy trunks.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The first few carriages were already packed with students, some hanging out of the window to talk to their families, some fighting over seats. Harry pushed his cart off down the platform in search of an empty seat. He passed a round-faced boy who was saying, "Gran, I've lost my toad again."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Oh, Neville," he heard the old woman sigh.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: A boy with dreadlocks was surrounded by a small crowd.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Give us a look, Lee, go on."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The boy lifted the lid of a box in his arms, and the people around him shrieked and yelled as something inside poked out a long, hairy leg.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry pressed on through the crowd until he found an empty compartment near the end of the train. He put Hedwig inside first and then started to shove and heave his trunk toward the train door. He tried to lift it up the steps but could hardly raise one end and twice he dropped it painfully on his foot.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Want a hand?" It was one of the red-haired twins he'd followed through

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: the barrier.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Yes, please," Harry panted.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Oy, Fred! C'mere and help!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: With the twins' help, Harry's trunk was at last tucked away in a corner of the compartment.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Thanks," said Harry, pushing his sweaty hair out of his eyes.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What's that?" said one of the twins suddenly, pointing at Harry's lightning scar.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Blimey," said the other twin. "Are you

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "He is," said the first twin. "Aren't you?" he added to Harry.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What?" said Harry.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Harry Potter, "chorused the twins.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Oh, him," said Harry. "I mean, yes, I am."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The two boys gawked at him, and Harry felt himself turning red. Then, to his relief, a voice came floating in through the train's open door.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Fred? George? Are you there?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Coming, Mom."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: With a last look at Harry, the twins hopped off the train.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry sat down next to the window where, half hidden, he could watch the red-haired family on the platform and hear what they were saying. Their mother had just taken out her handkerchief.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Ron, you've got something on your nose."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The youngest boy tried to jerk out of the way, but she grabbed him and began rubbing the end of his nose.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Mom -- geroff" He wriggled free.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Aaah, has ickle Ronnie got somefink on his nosie?" said one of the twins.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Shut up," said Ron.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Where's Percy?" said their mother.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "He's coming now."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The oldest boy came striding into sight. He had already changed into his billowing black Hogwarts robes, and Harry noticed a shiny silver badge on his chest with the letter P on it.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Can't stay long, Mother," he said. "I'm up front, the prefects have got two compartments to themselves --"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Oh, are you a prefect, Percy?" said one of the twins, with an air of great surprise. "You should have said something, we had no idea."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Hang on, I think I remember him saying something about it," said the other twin. "Once --"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Or twice --"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "A minute --"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "All summer --"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Oh, shut up," said Percy the Prefect.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "How come Percy gets new robes, anyway?" said one of the twins.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Because he's a prefect," said their mother fondly. "All right, dear, well, have a good term -- send me an owl when you get there."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: She kissed Percy on the cheek and he left. Then she turned to the twins.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Now, you two -- this year, you behave yourselves. If I get one more owl telling me you've -- you've blown up a toilet or --"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Blown up a toilet? We've never blown up a toilet."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Great idea though, thanks, Mom."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "It's not funny. And look after Ron."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Don't worry, ickle Ronniekins is safe with us."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Shut up," said Ron again. He was almost as tall as the twins already and his nose was still pink where his mother had rubbed it.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Hey, Mom, guess what? Guess who we just met on the train?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry leaned back quickly so they couldn't see him looking.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You know that black-haired boy who was near us in the station? Know who he is?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Who?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Harry Potter!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry heard the little girl's voice.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Oh, Mom, can I go on the train and see him, Mom, eh please...."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You've already seen him, Ginny, and the poor boy isn't something you goggle at in a zoo. Is he really, Fred? How do you know?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Asked him. Saw his scar. It's really there - like lightning."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Poor dear - no wonder he was alone, I wondered. He was ever so polite when he asked how to get onto the platform."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Never mind that, do you think he remembers what You-Know-Who looks like?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Their mother suddenly became very stern.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I forbid you to ask him, Fred. No, don't you dare. As though he needs reminding of that on his first day at school."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "All right, keep your hair on."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: A whistle sounded.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Hurry up!" their mother said, and the three boys clambered onto the train. They leaned out of the window for her to kiss them good-bye, and their younger sister began to cry.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Don't, Ginny, we'll send you loads of owls."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "We'll send you a Hogwarts toilet seat."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "George!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Only joking, Mom."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The train began to move. Harry saw the boys' mother waving and their sister, half laughing, half crying, running to keep up with the train until it gathered too much speed, then she fell back and waved.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry watched the girl and her mother disappear as the train rounded the corner. Houses flashed past the window. Harry felt a great leap of excitement. He didn't know what he was going to but it had to be better than what he was leaving behind.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The door of the compartment slid open and the youngest redheaded boy came in.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Anyone sitting there?" he asked, pointing at the seat opposite Harry. "Everywhere else is full."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry shook his head and the boy sat down. He glanced at Harry and then looked quickly out of the window, pretending he hadn't looked. Harry saw he still had a black mark on his nose.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Hey, Ron."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The twins were back.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Listen, we're going down the middle of the train -- Lee Jordan's got a giant tarantula down there."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Right," mumbled Ron.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Harry," said the other twin, "did we introduce ourselves? Fred and George Weasley. And this is Ron, our brother. See you later, then.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Bye," said Harry and Ron. The twins slid the compartment door shut behind them.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Are you really Harry Potter?" Ron blurted out.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry nodded.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Oh -well, I thought it might be one of Fred and George's jokes," said Ron. "And have you really got -- you know..."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He pointed at Harry's forehead.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry pulled back his bangs to show the lightning scar. Ron stared.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "So that's where You-Know-Who

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Yes," said Harry, "but I can't remember it."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Nothing?" said Ron eagerly.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Well -- I remember a lot of green light, but nothing else."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Wow," said Ron. He sat and stared at Harry for a few moments, then, as though he had suddenly realized what he was doing, he looked quickly out of the window again.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Are all your family wizards?" asked Harry, who found Ron just as interesting as Ron found him.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Er -- Yes, I think so," said Ron. "I think Mom's got a second cousin who's an accountant, but we never talk about him."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "So you must know loads of magic already."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The Weasleys were clearly one of those old wizarding families the pale boy in Diagon Alley had talked about.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I heard you went to live with Muggles," said Ron. "What are they like?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Horrible -well, not all of them. My aunt and uncle and cousin are, though. Wish I'd had three wizard brothers."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Five," said Ron. For some reason, he was looking gloomy. "I'm the sixth in our family to go to Hogwarts. You could say I've got a lot to live up to. Bill and Charlie have already left -- Bill was head boy and Charlie was captain of Quidditch. Now Percy's a prefect. Fred and George mess around a lot, but they still get really good marks and everyone thinks they're really funny. Everyone expects me to do as well as the others, but if I do, it's no big deal, because they did it first. You never get anything new, either, with five brothers. I've got Bill's old robes, Charlie's old wand, and Percy's old rat."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Ron reached inside his jacket and pulled out a fat gray rat, which was asleep.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "His name's Scabbers and he's useless, he hardly ever wakes up. Percy got an owl from my dad for being made a prefect, but they couldn't aff -- I mean, I got Scabbers instead."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Ron's ears went pink. He seemed to think he'd said too much, because he went back to staring out of the window.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry didn't think there was anything wrong with not being able to afford an owl. After all, he'd never had any money in his life until a month ago, and he told Ron so, all about having to wear Dudley's old clothes and never getting proper birthday presents. This seemed to cheer Ron up.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "... and until Hagrid told me, I didn't know anything about be ing a wizard or about my parents or Voldemort"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Ron gasped.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What?" said Harry.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You said You-Know-Who's name!" said Ron, sounding both shocked and impressed. "I'd have thought you, of all people --"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I'm not trying to be brave or anything, saying the name," said Harry, I just never knew you shouldn't. See what I mean? I've got loads to learn.... I bet," he added, voicing for the first time something that had been worrying him a lot lately, "I bet I'm the worst in the class."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You won't be. There's loads of people who come from Muggle families and they learn quick enough."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: While they had been talking, the train had carried them out of London. Now they were speeding past fields full of cows and sheep. They were quiet for a time, watching the fields and lanes flick past.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Around half past twelve there was a great clattering outside in the corridor and a smiling, dimpled woman slid back their door and said, "Anything off the cart, dears?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry, who hadn't had any breakfast, leapt to his feet, but Ron's ears went pink again and he muttered that he'd brought sandwiches. Harry went out into the corridor.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He had never had any money for candy with the Dursleys, and now that he had pockets rattling with gold and silver he was ready to buy as many Mars Bars as he could carry -- but the woman didn't have Mars Bars. What she did have were Bettie Bott's Every Flavor Beans, Drooble's Best Blowing Gum, Chocolate Frogs. Pumpkin Pasties, Cauldron Cakes, Licorice Wands, and a number of other strange things Harry had never seen in his life. Not wanting to miss anything, he got some of everything and paid the woman eleven silver Sickles and seven bronze Knuts.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Ron stared as Harry brought it all back in to the compartment and tipped it onto an empty seat.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Hungry, are you?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Starving," said Harry, taking a large bite out of a pumpkin pasty.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Ron had taken out a lumpy package and unwrapped it. There were four sandwiches inside. He pulled one of them apart and said, "She always forgets I don't like corned beef."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Swap you for one of these," said Harry, holding up a pasty. "Go on --"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You don't want this, it's all dry," said Ron. "She hasn't got much time," he added quickly, "you know, with five of us."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Go on, have a pasty," said Harry, who had never had anything to share before or, indeed, anyone to share it with. It was a nice feeling, sitting there with Ron, eating their way through all Harry's pasties, cakes, and candies (the sandwiches lay forgotten).

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What are these?" Harry asked Ron, holding up a pack of Chocolate Frogs. "They're not really frogs, are they?" He was starting to feel that nothing would surprise him.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "No," said Ron. "But see what the card is. I'm missing Agrippa."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Oh, of course, you wouldn't know -- Chocolate Frogs have cards, inside them, you know, to collect -- famous witches and wizards. I've got about five hundred, but I haven't got Agrippa or Ptolemy."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry unwrapped his Chocolate Frog and picked up the card. It showed a man's face. He wore half- moon glasses, had a long, crooked nose, and flowing silver hair, beard, and mustache. Underneath the picture was the name Albus Dumbledore.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "So this is Dumbledore!" said Harry.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Don't tell me you'd never heard of Dumbledore!" said Ron. "Can I have a frog? I might get Agrippa -- thanks

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry turned over his card and read:

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: ALBUS DUMBLEDORE

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: CURRENTLY HEADMASTER OF HOGWARTS

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Considered by many the greatest wizard of modern times, Dumbledore is particularly famous for his defeat of the dark wizard Grindelwald in 1945, for the discovery of the twelve uses of dragon's blood, and his work on alchemy with his partner, Nicolas Flamel. Professor Dumbledore enjoys chamber music and tenpin bowling.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry turned the card back over and saw, to his astonishment, that Dumbledore's face had disappeared.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "He's gone!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Well, you can't expect him to hang around all day," said Ron. "He'll be back. No, I've got Morgana again and I've got about six of her... do you want it? You can start collecting."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Ron's eyes strayed to the pile of Chocolate Frogs waiting to be unwrapped.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Help yourself," said Harry. "But in, you know, the Muggle world, people just stay put in photos."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Do they? What, they don't move at all?" Ron sounded amazed. "weird!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry stared as Dumbledore sidled back into the picture on his card and gave him a small smile. Ron was more interested in eating the frogs than looking at the Famous Witches and Wizards cards, but Harry couldn't keep his eyes off them. Soon he had not only Dumbledore and Morgana, but Hengist of Woodcroft, Alberic Grunnion, Circe, Paracelsus, and Merlin. He finally tore his eyes away from the druidess Cliodna, who was scratching her nose, to open a bag of Bertie Bott's Every Flavor Beans.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You want to be careful with those," Ron warned Harry. "When they say every flavor, they mean every flavor -- you know, you get all the ordinary ones like chocolate and peppermint and mar- malade, but then you can get spinach and liver and tripe. George reckons he had a booger- flavored one once."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Ron picked up a green bean, looked at it carefully, and bit into a corner.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Bleaaargh -- see? Sprouts."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: They had a good time eating the Every Flavor Beans. Harry got toast, coconut, baked bean, strawberry, curry, grass, coffee, sardine, and was even brave enough to nibble the end off a funny gray one Ron wouldn't touch, which turned out to be pepper.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The countryside now flying past the window was becoming wilder. The neat fields had gone. Now there were woods, twisting rivers, and dark green hills.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: There was a knock on the door of their compartment and the round-faced boy Harry had passed on platform nine and threequarters came in. He looked tearful.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Sorry," he said, "but have you seen a toad at all?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: When they shook their heads, he wailed, "I've lost him! He keeps getting

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: away from me!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "He'll turn up," said Harry.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Yes," said the boy miserably. "Well, if you see him..."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He left.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Don't know why he's so bothered," said Ron. "If I'd brought a toad I'd lose it as quick as I could. Mind you, I brought Scabbers, so I can't talk."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The rat was still snoozing on Ron's lap.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "He might have died and you wouldn't know the difference," said Ron in disgust. "I tried to turn him yellow yesterday to make him more interesting, but the spell didn't work. I'll show you, look..."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He rummaged around in his trunk and pulled out a very battered-looking wand. It was chipped in places and something white was glinting at the end.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Unicorn hair's nearly poking out. Anyway

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He had just raised his 'wand when the compartment door slid open again. The toadless boy was back, but this time he had a girl with him. She was already wearing her new Hogwarts robes.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Has anyone seen a toad? Neville's lost one," she said. She had a bossy sort of voice, lots of bushy brown hair, and rather large front teeth.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "We've already told him we haven't seen it," said Ron, but the girl wasn't listening, she was looking at the wand in his hand.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Oh, are you doing magic? Let's see it, then."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: She sat down. Ron looked taken aback.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Er -- all right."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He cleared his throat.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Sunshine, daisies, butter mellow, Turn this stupid, fat rat yellow."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He waved his wand, but nothing happened. Scabbers stayed gray and fast asleep.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Are you sure that's a real spell?" said the girl. "Well, it's not very good, is it? I've tried a few simple spells just for practice and it's all worked for me. Nobody in my family's magic at all, it was ever such a surprise when I got my letter, but I was ever so pleased, of course, I mean, it's the very best school of witchcraft there is, I've heard -- I've learned all our course books by heart, of course, I just hope it will be enough -- I'm Hermione Granger, by the way, who are you.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: She said all this very fast.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry looked at Ron, and was relieved to see by his stunned face that he hadn't learned all the course books by heart either.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I'm Ron Weasley," Ron muttered.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Harry Potter," said Harry.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Are you really?" said Hermione. "I know all about you, of course -- I got a few extra books. for background reading, and you're in Modern Magical History and The Rise and Fall of the Dark Arts and Great Wizarding Events of the Twentieth Century.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Am I?" said Harry, feeling dazed.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Goodness, didn't you know, I'd have found out everything I could if it was me," said Hermione. "Do either of you know what house you'll be in? I've been asking around, and I hope I'm in Gryffindor, it sounds by far the best; I hear Dumbledore himself was in it, but I suppose Ravenclaw wouldn't be too bad.... Anyway, we'd better go and look for Neville's toad. You two had better change, you know, I expect we'll be there soon."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: And she left, taking the toadless boy with her.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Whatever house I'm in, I hope she's not in it," said Ron. He threw his wand back into his trunk. "Stupid spell -- George gave it to me, bet he knew it was a dud."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What house are your brothers in?" asked Harry.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Gryffindor," said Ron. Gloom seemed to be settling on him again. "Mom and Dad were in it, too. I don't know what they'll say if I'm not. I don't suppose Ravenclaw would be too bad, but imagine if they put me in Slytherin."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "That's the house Vol-, I mean, You-Know-Who was in?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Yeah," said Ron. He flopped back into his seat, looking depressed.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You know, I think the ends of Scabbers' whiskers are a bit lighter," said Harry, trying to take Ron's mind off houses. "So what do your oldest brothers do now that they've left, anyway?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry was wondering what a wizard did once he'd finished school.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Charlie's in Romania studying dragons, and Bill's in Africa doing something for Gringotts," said Ron. "Did you hear about

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Gringotts? It's been all over the Daily Prophet, but I don't suppose you get that with the Muggles -- someone tried to rob a high security vault."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry stared.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Really? What happened to them?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Nothing, that's why it's such big news. They haven't been caught. My dad says it must've been a powerful Dark wizard to get round Gringotts, but they don't think they took anything, that's what's odd. 'Course, everyone gets scared when something like this happens in case You-Know-Who's behind it."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry turned this news over in his mind. He was starting to get a prickle of fear every time You- Know-Who was mentioned. He supposed this was all part of entering the magical world, but it had been a lot more comfortable saying "Voldemort" without worrying.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What's your Quidditch team?" Ron asked.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Er -- I don't know any," Harry confessed.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What!" Ron looked dumbfounded. "Oh, you wait, it's the best game in the

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: world --" And he was off, explaining all about the four balls and the positions of the seven players, describing famous games he'd been to with his brothers and the broomstick he'd like to get if he had the money. He was just taking Harry through the finer points of the game when the compartment door slid open yet again, but it wasn't Neville the toadless boy, or Hermione Granger this time.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Three boys entered, and Harry recognized the middle one at once: it was the pale boy from Madam Malkin's robe shop. He was looking at Harry with a lot more interest than he'd shown back in Diagon Alley.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Is it true?" he said. "They're saying all down the train that Harry Potter's in this compartment. So it's you, is it?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Yes," said Harry. He was looking at the other boys. Both of them were thickset and looked extremely mean. Standing on either side of the pale boy, they looked like bodyguards.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Oh, this is Crabbe and this is Goyle," said the pale boy carelessly, noticing where Harry was looking. "And my name's Malfoy, Draco Malfoy."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Ron gave a slight cough, which might have been hiding a snigget. Draco Malfoy looked at him.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Think my name's funny, do you? No need to ask who you are. My father told me all the Weasleys have red hair, freckles, and more children than they can afford."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He turned back to Harry. "You'll soon find out some wizarding families are much better than others, Potter. You don't want to go making friends with the wrong sort. I can help you there."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He held out his hand to shake Harry's, but Harry didn't take it.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I think I can tell who the wrong sort are for myself, thanks," he said coolly.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Draco Malfoy didn't go red, but a pink tinge appeared in his pale cheeks.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I'd be careful if I were you, Potter," he said slowly. "Unless you're a bit politer you'll go the same way as your parents. They didn't know what was good for them, either. You hang around with riffraff like the

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Weasleys and that Hagrid, and it'll rub off on you."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Both Harry and Ron stood up.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Say that again," Ron said, his face as red as his hair.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Oh, you're going to fight us, are you?" Malfoy sneered.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Unless you get out now," said Harry, more bravely than he felt, because Crabbe and Goyle were a lot bigger than him or Ron.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "But we don't feet like leaving, do we, boys? We've eaten all our food and you still seem to have some."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Goyle reached toward the Chocolate Frogs next to Ron - Ron leapt forward, but before he'd so much as touched Goyle, Goyle let out a horrible yell.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Scabbers the rat was hanging off his finger, sharp little teeth sunk deep into Goyle's knuckle - Crabbe and Malfoy backed away as Goyle swung Scabbers round and round, howling, and when Scabbets finally flew off and hit the window, all three of them disappeared at once. Perhaps they thought there were more rats lurking among the sweets, or perhaps they'd heard footsteps, because a second later, Hermione Granger had come in.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What has been going on?" she said, looking at the sweets all over the floor and Ron picking up Scabbers by his tail.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: I think he's been knocked out," Ron said to Harry. He looked closer at Scabbers. "No -- I don't believe it -- he's gone back to sleep-"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: And so he had.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You've met Malfoy before?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry explained about their meeting in Diagon Alley.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I've heard of his family," said Ron darkly. "They were some of the first to come back to our side after You-Know-Who disappeared. Said they'd been bewitched. My dad doesn't believe it. He says Malfoy's father didn't need an excuse to go over to the Dark Side." He turned to Hermione. "Can we help you with something?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You'd better hurry up and put your robes on, I've just been up to the front to ask the conductor, and he says we're nearly there. You haven't been fighting, have you? You'll be in trouble before we even get there!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Scabbers has been fighting, not us," said Ron, scowling at her. "Would you mind leaving while we change?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "All right -- I only came in here because people outside are behaving very childishly, racing up and down the corridors," said Hermione in a sniffy voice. "And you've got dirt on your nose, by the way, did you know?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Ron glared at her as she left. Harry peered out of the window. It was getting dark. He could see mountains and forests under a deep purple sky. The train did seem to be slowing down.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He and Ron took off their jackets and pulled on their long black robes. Ron's were a bit short for him, you could see his sneakers underneath them.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: A voice echoed through the train: "We will be reaching Hogwarts in five minutes' time. Please leave your luggage on the train, it will be taken to the school separately."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry's stomach lurched with nerves and Ron, he saw, looked pale under his freckles. They crammed their pockets with the last of the sweets and joined the crowd thronging the corridor.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The train slowed right down and finally stopped. People pushed their way toward the door and out on to a tiny, dark platform. Harry shivered in the cold night air. Then a lamp came bobbing over the heads of the students, and Harry heard a familiar voice: "Firs' years! Firs' years over here! All right there, Harry?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hagrid's big hairy face beamed over the sea of heads.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "C'mon, follow me -- any more firs' years? Mind yer step, now! Firs' years follow me!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Slipping and stumbling, they followed Hagrid down what seemed to be a steep, narrow path. It was so dark on either side of them that Harry thought there must be thick trees there. Nobody spoke much. Neville, the boy who kept losing his toad, sniffed once or twice.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Ye' all get yer firs' sight o' Hogwarts in a sec," Hagrid called over his shoulder, "jus' round this bend here."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: There was a loud "Oooooh!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The narrow path had opened suddenly onto the edge of a great black take. Perched atop a high mountain on the other side, its windows sparkling in the starry sky, was a vast castle with many turrets and towers.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "No more'n four to a boat!" Hagrid called, pointing to a fleet of little boats sitting in the water by the shore. Harry and Ron were followed into their boat by Neville and Hermione. "Everyone in?" shouted Hagrid, who had a boat to himself. "Right then -- FORWARD!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: And the fleet of little boats moved off all at once, gliding across the lake, which was as smooth as glass. Everyone was silent, staring up at the great castle overhead. It towered over them as they sailed nearer and nearer to the cliff on which it stood.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Heads down!" yelled Hagrid as the first boats reached the cliff; they all bent their heads and the little boats carried them through a curtain of ivy that hid a wide opening in the cliff face. They were carried along a dark tunnel, which seemed to be taking them right underneath the castle, until they reached a kind of underground harbor, where they clambered out onto rocks and pebbles.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Oy, you there! Is this your toad?" said Hagrid, who was checking the boats as people climbed out of them.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Trevor!" cried Neville blissfully, holding out his hands. Then they clambered up a passageway in the rock after Hagrid's lamp, coming out at last onto smooth, damp grass right in the shadow of the castle.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: They walked up a flight of stone steps and crowded around the huge, Oak front door.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Everyone here? You there, still got yer toad?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hagrid raised a gigantic fist and knocked three times on the castle door.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: CHAPTER SEVEN

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: THE SORTING HAT

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The door swung open at once. A tall, black-haired witch in emerald-green robes stood there. She had a very stern face and Harry's first thought was that this was not someone to cross.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "The firs' years, Professor McGonagall," said Hagrid.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Thank you, Hagrid. I will take them from here."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: She pulled the door wide. The entrance hall was so big you could have fit the whole of the Dursleys' house in it. The stone walls were lit with flaming torches like the ones at Gringotts, the ceiling was too high to make out, and a magnificent marble staircase facing them led to the upper floors.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: They followed Professor McGonagall across the flagged stone floor. Harry could hear the drone of hundreds of voices from a doorway to the right -the rest of the school must already be here -- but Professor McGonagall showed the first years into a small, empty chamber off the hall. They crowded in, standing rather closer together than they would usually have done, peering about nervously.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Welcome to Hogwarts," said Professor McGonagall. "The start-of-term banquet will begin shortly, but before you take your seats in the Great Hall, you will be sorted into your houses. The Sorting is a very important ceremony because, while you are here, your house will be something like your family within Hogwarts. You will have classes with the rest of your house, sleep in your house dormitory, and spend free time in your house common room.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "The four houses are called Gryffindor, Hufflepuff, Ravenclaw, and Slytherin. Each house has its own noble history and each has produced outstanding witches and wizards. While you are at Hogwarts, your triumphs will earn your house points, while any rulebreaking will lose house points.
