At the end of the year, the house with the most points is awarded the house cup, a great honor. I hope each of you will be a credit to whichever house becomes yours.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "The Sorting Ceremony will take place in a few minutes in front of the rest of the school. I suggest you all smarten yourselves up as much as

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: you can while you are waiting."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Her eyes lingered for a moment on Neville's cloak, which was fastened under his left ear, and on Ron's smudged nose. Harry nervously tried to flatten his hair.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I shall return when we are ready for you," said Professor McGonagall. "Please wait quietly."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: She left the chamber. Harry swallowed.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "How exactly do they sort us into houses?" he asked Ron.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Some sort of test, I think. Fred said it hurts a lot, but I think he was joking."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry's heart gave a horrible jolt. A test? In front of the whole school? But he didn't know any magic yet -- what on earth would he have to do? He hadn't expected something like this the moment they arrived. He looked around anxiously and saw that everyone else looked terrified, too. No one was talking much except Hermione Granger, who was whispering very fast about all the spells she'd learned and wondering which one she'd need. Harry tried hard not to listen to her. He'd never been more nervous, never, not even when he'd had to take a school report home to the Dursleys saying that he'd somehow turned his teacher's wig blue. He kept his eyes fixed on the door. Any second now, Professor McGonagall would come back and lead him to his doom.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Then something happened that made him jump about a foot in the air -- several people behind him screamed.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What the --?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He gasped. So did the people around him. About twenty ghosts had just streamed through the back wall. Pearly-white and slightly transparent, they glided across the room talking to one another and hardly glancing at the first years. They seemed to be arguing. What looked like a fat little monk was saying: "Forgive and forget, I say, we ought to give him a second chance --"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "My dear Friar, haven't we given Peeves all the chances he deserves? He gives us all a bad name and you know, he's not really even a ghost -- I say, what are you all doing here?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: A ghost wearing a ruff and tights had suddenly noticed the first years.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Nobody answered.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "New students!" said the Fat Friar, smiling around at them. "About to be Sorted, I suppose?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: A few people nodded mutely.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Hope to see you in Hufflepuff!" said the Friar. "My old house, you know."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Move along now," said a sharp voice. "The Sorting Ceremony's about to start."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Professor McGonagall had returned. One by one, the ghosts floated away through the opposite wall.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Now, form a line," Professor McGonagall told the first years, "and follow me."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Feeling oddly as though his legs had turned to lead, Harry got into line behind a boy with sandy hair, with Ron behind him, and they walked out of the chamber, back across the hall, and through a pair of double doors into the Great Hall.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry had never even imagined such a strange and splendid place. It was lit by thousands and thousands of candles that were floating in midair over four long tables, where the rest of the students were sitting. These tables were laid with glittering golden plates and goblets. At the top of the hall was another long table where the teachers were sitting. Professor McGonagall led the first years up here, so that they came to a halt in a line facing the other students, with the teachers behind them. The hundreds of faces staring at them looked like pale lanterns in the flickering candlelight. Dotted here and there among the students, the ghosts shone misty silver. Mainly to avoid all the staring eyes, Harry looked upward and saw a velvety black ceiling dotted with stars. He heard

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hermione whisper, "Its bewitched to look like the sky outside. I read about it in Hogwarts, A History."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: It was hard to believe there was a ceiling there at all, and that the Great Hall didn't simply open on to the heavens.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry quickly looked down again as Professor McGonagall silently placed a four-legged stool in front of the first years. On top of the stool she put a pointed wizard's hat. This hat was patched and frayed and extremely dirty. Aunt Petunia wouldn't have let it in the house.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Maybe they had to try and get a rabbit out of it, Harry thought wildly, that seemed the sort of thing -- noticing that everyone in the hall was now staring at the hat, he stared at it, too. For a few seconds, there was complete silence. Then the hat twitched. A rip near the brim opened wide like a mouth -- and the hat began to sing:

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Oh, you may not think I'm pretty,

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: But don't judge on what you see,

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: I'll eat myself if you can find

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: A smarter hat than me.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: You can keep your bowlers black,

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Your top hats sleek and tall,

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: For I'm the Hogwarts Sorting Hat

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: And I can cap them all.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: There's nothing hidden in your head

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The Sorting Hat can't see,

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: So try me on and I will tell you

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Where you ought to be.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: You might belong in Gryffindor,

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Where dwell the brave at heart,

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Their daring, nerve, and chivalry Set Gryffindors apart;

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: You might belong in Hufflepuff,

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Where they are just and loyal,

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Those patient Hufflepuffis are true And unafraid of toil;

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Or yet in wise old Ravenclaw,

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: if you've a ready mind,

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Where those of wit and learning,

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Will always find their kind;

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Or perhaps in Slytherin

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: You'll make your real friends,

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Those cunning folk use any means

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: To achieve their ends.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: So put me on! Don't be afraid!

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: And don't get in a flap!

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: You're in safe hands (though I have none)

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: For I'm a Thinking Cap!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The whole hall burst into applause as the hat finished its song. It bowed to each of the four tables and then became quite still again.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "So we've just got to try on the hat!" Ron whispered to Harry. "I'll kill Fred, he was going on about wrestling a troll."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry. smiled weakly. Yes, trying on the hat was a lot better than having to do a spell, but he did wish they could have tried it on without everyone watching. The hat seemed to be asking rather alot; Harry didn't feel brave or quick-witted or any of it at the moment. If only the hat had mentioned a house for people who felt a bit queasy, that would have been the one for him.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Professor McGonagall now stepped forward holding a long roll of parchment.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "When I call your name, you will put on the hat and sit on the stool to be sorted," she said. "Abbott, Hannah!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: A pink-faced girl with blonde pigtails stumbled out of line, put on the hat, which fell right down over her eyes, and sat down. A moments pause

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "HUFFLEPUFF!" shouted the hat.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The table on the right cheered and clapped as Hannah went to sit down at the Hufflepuff table. Harry saw the ghost of the Fat Friar waving merrily at her.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Bones, Susan!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "HUFFLEPUFF!" shouted the hat again, and Susan scuttled off to sit next to Hannah.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Boot, Terry!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "RAVENCLAW!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The table second from the left clapped this time; several Ravenclaws stood up to shake hands with Terry as he joined them.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: " Brocklehurst, Mandy" went to Ravenclaw too, but "Brown, Lavender" became the first new Gryffindor, and the table on the far left exploded with cheers; Harry could see Ron's twin brothers catcalling.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Bulstrode, Millicent" then became a Slytherin. Perhaps it was Harry's imagination, after all he'd heard about Slytherin, but he thought they looked like an unpleasant lot. He was starting to feel definitely sick now. He remembered being picked for teams during gym at his old school. He had always been last to be chosen, not because he was no good, but because no one wanted Dudley to think they liked him.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Finch-Fletchley, Justin!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "HUFFLEPUFF!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Sometimes, Harry noticed, the hat shouted out the house at once, but at others it took a little while to decide. "Finnigan, Seamus," the sandy-haired boy next to Harry in the line, sat on the stool for almost a whole minute before the hat declared him a Gryffindor.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Granger, Hermione!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hermione almost ran to the stool and jammed the hat eagerly on her head.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "GRYFFINDOR!" shouted the hat. Ron groaned.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: A horrible thought struck Harry, as horrible thoughts always do when you're very nervous. What if he wasn't chosen at all? What if he just sat there with the hat over his eyes for ages, until Professor McGonagall jerked it off his head and said there had obviously been a mistake and he'd better get back on the train?

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: When Neville Longbottom, the boy who kept losing his toad, was called, he fell over on his way to the stool. The hat took a long time to decide with Neville. When it finally shouted, "GRYFFINDOR," Neville ran off still wearing it, and had to jog back amid gales of laughter to give it to "MacDougal, Morag."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Malfoy swaggered forward when his name was called and got his wish at once: the hat had barely touched his head when it screamed, "SLYTHERIN!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Malfoy went to join his friends Crabbe and Goyle, looking pleased with himself.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: There weren't many people left now. "Moon" "Nott" "Parkinson" then a pair of twin girls, "Patil" and "Patil" then "Perks, Sally-Anne" and then, at last -- "Potter, Harry!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: As Harry stepped forward, whispers suddenly broke out like little hissing fires all over the hall.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Potter, did she say?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The Harry Potter?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The last thing Harry saw before the hat dropped over his eyes was the hall full of people craning to get a good look at him. Next second he

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: was looking at the black inside of the hat. He waited.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hmm," said a small voice in his ear. "Difficult. Very difficult. Plenty of courage, I see. Not a bad mind either. There's talent, A my goodness, yes -- and a nice thirst to prove yourself, now that's interesting.... So where shall I put you?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry gripped the edges of the stool and thought, Not Slytherin, not Slytherin.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Not Slytherin, eh?" said the small voice. "Are you sure? You could be great, you know, it's all here in your head, and Slytherin will help you on the way to greatness, no doubt about that -- no? Well, if you're sure -- better be GRYFFINDOR!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry heard the hat shout the last word to the whole hall. He took off the hat and walked shakily toward the Gryffindor table. He was so relieved to have been chosen and not put in Slytherin, he hardly noticed that he was getting the loudest cheer yet. Percy the Prefect got up and shook his hand vigorously, while the Weasley twins yelled, "We got Potter! We got Potter!" Harry sat down opposite the ghost in the ruff he'd seen earlier. The ghost patted his arm, giving Harry the sudden, horrible feeling he'd just plunged it into a bucket of ice-cold water.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He could see the High Table properly now. At the end nearest him sat Hagrid, who caught his eye and gave him the thumbs up. Harry grinned back. And there, in the center of the High Table, in a large gold chair, sat Albus Dumbledore. Harry recognized him at once from the card he'd gotten out of the Chocolate Frog on the train. Dumbledore's silver hair was the only thing in the whole hall that shone as brightly as the ghosts. Harry spotted Professor Quirtell, too, the nervous young man from the Leaky Cauldron. He was looking very peculiar in a large purple turban.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: And now there were only three people left to be sorted. "Thomas, Dean," a Black boy even taller than Ron, joined Harry at the Gryffindor table. "Turpin, Lisa," became a Ravenclaw and then it was Ron's turn. He was pale green by now. Harry crossed his fingers under the table and a second later the hat had shouted, "GRYFFINDOR!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry clapped loudly with the rest as Ron collapsed into the chair next to him.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Well done, Ron, excellent," said Percy Weasley Pompously across Harry as "Zabini, Blaise," was made a Slytherin. Professor McGonagall rolled up her scroll and took the Sorting Hat away.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry looked down at his empty gold plate. He had only just realized how hungry he was. The pumpkin pasties seemed ages ago.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Albus Dumbledore had gotten to his feet. He was beaming at the students, his arms opened wide, as if nothing could have pleased him more than to see them all there.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Welcome," he said. "Welcome to a new year at Hogwarts! Before we begin our banquet, I would like to say a few words. And here they are: Nitwit! Blubber! Oddment! Tweak!

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Thank you!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He sat back down. Everybody clapped and cheered. Harry didn't know whether to laugh or not.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Is he -- a bit mad?" he asked Percy uncertainly.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Mad?" said Percy airily. "He's a genius! Best wizard in the world! But he is a bit mad, yes. Potatoes, Harry?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry's mouth fell open. The dishes in front of him were now piled with food. He had never seen so many things he liked to eat on one table: roast beef, roast chicken, pork chops and lamb chops, sausages, bacon and steak, boiled potatoes, roast potatoes, fries, Yorkshire pudding, peas, carrots, gravy, ketchup, and, for some strange reason, peppermint humbugs.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The Dursleys had never exactly starved Harry, but he'd never been allowed to eat as much as he liked. Dudley had always taken anything that Harry really wanted, even if It made him sick. Harry piled his plate with a bit of everything except the peppermints and began to eat. It was all delicious.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "That does look good," said the ghost in the ruff sadly, watching Harry cut up his steak,

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Can't you --?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: I haven't eaten for nearly four hundred years," said the ghost. "I don't need to, of course, but one does miss it. I don't think I've in troduced myself? Sir Nicholas de Mimsy-Porpington at your service. Resident ghost of Gryffindor Tower."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I know who you are!" said Ron suddenly. "My brothers told me about you -- you're Nearly Headless Nick!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I would prefer you to call me Sir Nicholas de Mimsy --" the ghost began stiffly, but sandy-haired Seamus Finnigan interrupted.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Nearly Headless? How can you be nearly headless?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Sir Nicholas looked extremely miffed, as if their little chat wasn't going at all the way he wanted.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Like this," he said irritably. He seized his left ear and pulled. His whole head swung off his neck and fell onto his shoulder as if it was on a hinge. Someone had obviously tried to behead him, but not done it properly. Looking pleased at the stunned looks on their faces, Nearly Headless Nick flipped his head back onto his neck, coughed, and said, "So -- new Gryffindors! I hope you're going to help us win the house championship this year? Gryffindors have never gone so long without winning. Slytherins have got the cup six years in a row! The Bloody Baron's becoming almost unbearable -- he's the Slytherin ghost."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry looked over at the Slytherin table and saw a horrible ghost sitting there, with blank staring eyes, a gaunt face, and robes stained with silver blood. He was right next to Malfoy who, Harry was pleased to see, didn't look too pleased with the seating arrangements.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "How did he get covered in blood?" asked Seamus with great interest.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I've never asked," said Nearly Headless Nick delicately.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: When everyone had eaten as much as they could, the remains of the food faded from the plates, leaving them sparkling clean as before. A moment later the desserts appeared. Blocks of ice cream in every flavor you could think of, apple pies, treacle tarts, chocolate eclairs and jam doughnuts, trifle, strawberries, Jell-O, rice pudding -- "

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: As Harry helped himself to a treacle tart, the talk turned to their families.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I'm half-and-half," said Seamus. "Me dad's a Muggle. Mom didn't tell him she was a witch 'til after they were married. Bit of a nasty shock for him."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The others laughed.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What about you, Neville?" said Ron.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Well, my gran brought me up and she's a witch," said Neville, "but the family thought I was all- Muggle for ages. My Great Uncle Algie kept trying to catch me off my guard and force some magic out of me -- he pushed me off the end of Blackpool pier once, I nearly drowned -- but nothing happened until I was eight. Great Uncle Algie came round for dinner, and he was hanging me out of an upstairs window by the ankles when my Great Auntie Enid offered him a meringue and he accidentally let go. But I bounced -- all the way down the garden and into the road. They were all really pleased, Gran was crying, she was so happy. And you should have seen their faces when I got in here -- they thought I might not be magic enough to come, you see. Great Uncle Algie was so pleased he bought me my toad."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: On Harry's other side, Percy Weasley and Hermione were talking about lessons ("I do hope they start right away, there's so much to learn, I'm particularly interested in Transfiguration, you know, turning something into something else, of course, it's supposed to be very difficult-"; "You'll be starting small, just matches into needles and that sort of thing -- ").

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry, who was starting to feel warm and sleepy, looked up at

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: the High Table again. Hagrid was drinking deeply from his goblet. Professor McGonagall was talking to Professor Dumbledore. Professor Quirrell, in his absurd turban, was talking to a teacher with greasy black hair, a hooked nose, and sallow skin.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: It happened very suddenly. The hook-nosed teacher looked past Quirrell's turban straight into Harry's eyes -- and a sharp, hot pain shot across the scar on Harry's forehead.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Ouch!" Harry clapped a hand to his head.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What is it?" asked Percy.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "N-nothing."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The pain had gone as quickly as it had come. Harder to shake off was the feeling Harry had gotten from the teacher's look -- a feeling that he didn't like Harry at all.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Who's that teacher talking to Professor Quirrell?" he asked Percy.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Oh, you know Quirrell already, do you? No wonder he's looking so nervous, that's Professor Snape. He teaches Potions, but he doesn't want to -- everyone knows he's after Quirrell's job. Knows an awful lot about the Dark Arts, Snape."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry watched Snape for a while, but Snape didn't look at him again.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: At last, the desserts too disappeared, and Professor Dumbledore got to his feet again. The hall fell silent.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Ahern -- just a few more words now that we are all fed and watered. I have a few start-of-term notices to give you.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "First years should note that the forest on the grounds is forbidden to all pupils. And a few of our older students would do well to remember that as well."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Dumbledore's twinkling eyes flashed in the direction of the Weasley twins.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I have also been asked by Mr. Filch, the caretaker, to remind you all that no magic should be used between classes in the corridors.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Quidditch trials will be held in the second week of the term. Anyone interested in playing for their house teams should contact Madam Hooch.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "And finally, I must tell you that this year, the third-floor corridor on the right-hand side is out of bounds to everyone who does not wish to die a very painful death."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry laughed, but he was one of the few who did.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "He's not serious?" he muttered to Percy.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Must be," said Percy, frowning at Dumbledore. "It's odd, because he usually gives us a reason why we're not allowed to go somewhere -- the forest's full of dangerous beasts, everyone knows that. I do think he might have told us prefects, at least."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "And now, before we go to bed, let us sing the school song!" cried Dumbledore. Harry noticed that the other teachers' smiles had become rather fixed.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Dumbledore gave his wand a little flick, as if he was trying to get a fly off the end, and a long golden ribbon flew out of it, which rose high above the tables and twisted itself, snakelike, into words.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Everyone pick their favorite tune," said Dumbledore, "and off we go!" And the school bellowed:

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Hogwarts, Hogwarts, Hoggy Warty Hogwarts,

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Teach us something please,

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Whether we be old and bald

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Or young with scabby knees,

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Our heads could do with filling

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: With some interesting stuff,

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: For now they're bare and full of air,

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Dead flies and bits of fluff,

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: So teach us things worth knowing,

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Bring back what we've forgot,

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: just do your best, we'll do the rest,

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: And learn until our brains all rot.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Everybody finished the song at different times. At last, only the Weasley twins were left singing along to a very slow funeral march. Dumbledore conducted their last few lines with his wand and when they

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: had finished, he was one of those who clapped loudest.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Ah, music," he said, wiping his eyes. "A magic beyond all we do here! And now, bedtime. Off you trot!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The Gryffindor first years followed Percy through the chattering crowds, out of the Great Hall, and up the marble staircase. Harry's legs were like lead again, but only because he was so tired and full of food. He was too sleepy even to be surprised that the people in the portraits along the corridors whispered and pointed as they passed, or that twice Percy led them through doorways hidden behind sliding panels and hanging tapestries. They climbed more staircases, yawning and dragging their feet, and Harry was just wondering how much farther they had to go when they came to a sudden halt.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: A bundle of walking sticks was floating in midair ahead of them, and as Percy took a step toward them they started throwing themselves at him.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Peeves," Percy whispered to the first years. "A poltergeist." He raised his voice, "Peeves -- show yourself"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: A loud, rude sound, like the air being let out of a balloon, answered.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Do you want me to go to the Bloody Baron?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: There was a pop, and a little man with wicked, dark eyes and a wide mouth appeared, floating cross- legged in the air, clutching the walking sticks.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Oooooooh!" he said, with an evil cackle. "Ickle Firsties! What fun!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He swooped suddenly at them. They all ducked.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Go away, Peeves, or the Baron'll hear about this, I mean it!" barked Percy.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Peeves stuck out his tongue and vanished, dropping the walking sticks on Neville's head. They heard him zooming away, rattling coats of armor as he passed.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You want to watch out for Peeves," said Percy, as they set off again. "The Bloody Baron's the only one who can control him, he won't even listen to us prefects. Here we are."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: At the very end of the corridor hung a portrait of a very fat woman in a pink silk dress.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Password?" she said. "Caput Draconis," said Percy, and the portrait swung forward to reveal a round hole in the wall. They all scrambled through it -- Neville needed a leg up -- and found themselves in the Gryffindor common room, a cozy, round room full of squashy armchairs.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Percy directed the girls through one door to their dormitory and the boys through another. At the top of a spiral staircase -- they were obviously in one of the towers -- they found their beds at last: five four-posters hung with deep red, velvet curtains. Their trunks had already been brought up. Too tired to talk much, they pulled on their pajamas and fell into bed.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: " Great food, isn't it?" Ron muttered to Harry through the hangings. "Get off, Scabbers! He's chewing my sheets."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry was going to ask Ron if he'd had any of the treacle tart, but he fell asleep almost at once.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Perhaps Harry had eaten a bit too much, because he had a very strange dream. He was wearing Professor Quirrell's turban, which kept talking to him, telling him he must transfer to Slytherin at once, because it was his destiny. Harry told the turban he didn't want to be in Slytherin; it got heavier and heavier; he tried to pull it off but it tightened painfully -- and there was Malfoy, laughing at him as he struggled with it -then Malfoy turned into the hook-nosed teacher, Snape, whose laugh became high and cold -- there was a burst of green light and Harry woke, sweating and shaking.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He rolled over and fell asleep again, and when he woke next day, he didn't remember the dream at all.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: CHAPTER EIGHT

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: THE POTIONS MASTER

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: There, look."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Where?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Next to the tall kid with the red hair."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Wearing the glasses?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Did you see his face?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Did you see his scar?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Whispers followed Harry from the moment he left his dormitory the next day. People lining up outside classrooms stood on tiptoe to get a look at him, or doubled back to pass him in the corridors again, staring. Harry wished they wouldn't, because he was trying to concentrate on finding his way to classes.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: There were a hundred and forty-two staircases at Hogwarts: wide, sweeping ones; narrow, rickety ones; some that led somewhere different on a Friday; some with a vanishing step halfway up that you had to remember to jump. Then there were doors that wouldn't open unless you asked politely, or tickled them in exactly the right place, and doors that weren't really doors at all, but solid walls just pretending. It was also very hard to remember where anything was, because it all seemed to move around a lot. The people in the portraits kept going to visit each other, and Harry was sure the coats of armor could walk.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The ghosts didn't help, either. It was always a nasty shock when one of them glided suddenly through a door you were trying to open. Nearly Headless Nick was always happy to point new Gryffindors in the right direction, but Peeves the Poltergeist was worth two locked doors and a trick staircase if you met him when you were late for class. He would drop wastepaper baskets on your head, pull rugs from under your feet, pelt you with bits of chalk, or sneak up behind you, invisible, grab your nose, and screech, "GOT YOUR CONK!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Even worse than Peeves, if that was possible, was the caretaker, Argus Filch. Harry and Ron managed to get on the wrong side of him on their very first morning. Filch found them trying to force their way through a door that unluckily turned out to be the entrance to the out-of-bounds corridor on the third floor. He wouldn't believe they were lost, was sure they were trying to break into it on purpose, and was threatening to lock them in the dungeons when they were rescued by Professor Quirrell, who was passing.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Filch owned a cat called Mrs. Norris, a scrawny, dust-colored creature with bulging, lamp like eyes just like Filch's. She patrolled the corridors alone. Break a rule in front of her, put just one toe out of line, and she'd whisk off for Filch, who'd appear, wheezing, two seconds later. Filch knew the secret passageways of the school better than anyone (except perhaps the Weasley twins) and could pop up as suddenly as any of the ghosts. The students all hated him, and it was the dearest ambition of many to give Mrs. Norris a good kick.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: And then, once you had managed to find them, there were the classes themselves. There was a lot more to magic, as Harry quickly found out, than waving your wand and saying a few funny words.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: They had to study the night skies through their telescopes every Wednesday at midnight and learn the names of different stars and the movements of the planets. Three times a week they went out to the greenhouses behind the castle to study Herbology, with a dumpy little witch called Professor Sprout, where they learned how to take care of all the strange plants and fungi, and found out what they were used for.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Easily the most boring class was History of Magic, which was the only one taught by a ghost. Professor Binns had been very old

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: indeed when he had fallen asleep in front of the staff room fire and got up next morning to teach, leaving his body behind him. Binns droned on and on while they scribbled down names and dates, and got Emetic the Evil and Uric the Oddball mixed up.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Professor Flitwick, the Charms teacher, was a tiny little wizard who had to stand on a pile of books to see over his desk. At the start of their first class he took the roll call, and when he reached Harry's name he gave an excited squeak and toppled out of sight.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Professor McGonagall was again different. Harry had been quite right to think she wasn't a teacher to cross. Strict and clever, she gave them a talking-to the moment they sat down in her first class.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Transfiguration is some of the most complex and dangerous magic you will learn at Hogwarts," she said. "Anyone messing around in my class will leave and not come back. You have been warned."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Then she changed her desk into a pig and back again. They were all very impressed and couldn't wait to get started, but soon realized they

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: weren't going to be changing the furniture into animals for a long time. After taking a lot of complicated notes, they were each given a match and started trying to turn it into a needle. By the end of the lesson, only Hermione Granger had made any difference to her match; Professor McGonagall showed the class how it had gone all silver and pointy and gave Hermione a rare smile.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The class everyone had really been looking forward to was Defense Against the Dark Arts, but Quirrell's lessons turned out to be a bit of a joke. His classroom smelled strongly of garlic, which everyone said was to ward off a vampire he'd met in Romania and was afraid would be coming back to get him one of these days. His turban, he told them, had been given to him by an African prince as a thank-you for getting rid of a troublesome zombie, but they weren't sure they believed this story. For one thing, when Seamus Finnigan asked eagerly to hear how Quirrell had fought off the zombie, Quirrell went pink and started talking about the weather; for another, they had noticed that a funny smell hung around the turban, and the Weasley twins insisted that it was stuffed full of garlic as well, so that Quirrell was protected wherever he went.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry was very relieved to find out that he wasn't miles behind everyone else. Lots of people had come from Muggle families and, like him, hadn't had any idea that they were witches and wizards. There was so much to learn that even people like Ron didn't have much of a head start.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Friday was an important day for Harry and Ron. They finally managed to find their way down to the Great Hall for breakfast without getting lost once.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What have we got today?" Harry asked Ron as he poured sugar on his porridge.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Double Potions with the Slytherins," said Ron. "Snape's Head of Slytherin House. They say he always favors them -- we'll be able to see if it's true."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Wish McGonagall favored us, " said Harry. Professor McGonagall was head of Gryffindor House, but it hadn't stopped her from giving them a huge pile of homework the day before.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Just then, the mail arrived. Harry had gotten used to this by now, but it had given him a bit of a shock on the first morning, when about a hundred owls had suddenly streamed into the Great Hall during breakfast,

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: circling the tables until they saw their owners, and dropping letters and packages onto their laps.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hedwig hadn't brought Harry anything so far. She sometimes flew in to nibble his ear and have a bit of toast before going off to sleep in the owlery with the other school owls. This morning, however, she fluttered down between the marmalade and the sugar bowl and dropped a note onto Harry's plate. Harry tore it open at once. It said, in a very untidy scrawl:

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Dear Harry,

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: I know you get Friday afternoons off, so would you like to come and have a cup of tea with me around three?

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: I want to hear all about your first week. Send us an answer back with Hedwig.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hagrid

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry borrowed Ron's quill, scribbled Yes, please, see you later on the back of the note, and sent Hedwig off again.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: It was lucky that Harry had tea with Hagrid to look forward to, because the Potions lesson turned out to be the worst thing that had happened to him so far.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: At the start-of-term banquet, Harry had gotten the idea that Professor Snape disliked him. By the end of the first Potions lesson, he knew he'd been wrong. Snape didn't dislike Harry -- he hated him.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Potions lessons took place down in one of the dungeons. It was colder here than up in the main castle, and would have been quite creepy enough without the pickled animals floating in glass jars all around the walls.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Snape, like Flitwick, started the class by taking the roll call, and like Flitwick, he paused at Harry's name.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Ah, Yes," he said softly, "Harry Potter. Our new -- celebrity."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Draco Malfoy and his friends Crabbe and Goyle sniggered behind their

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: hands. Snape finished calling the names and looked up at the class. His eyes were black like Hagrid's, but they had none of Hagrid's warmth. They were cold and empty and made you think of dark tunnels.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You are here to learn the subtle science and exact art of potionmaking," he began. He spoke in barely more than a whisper, but they caught every word -- like Professor McGonagall, Snape had y caught every word -- like Professor McGonagall, Snape had the gift of keeping a class silent without effort. "As there is little foolish wand-waving here, many of you will hardly believe this is magic. I don't expect you will really understand the beauty of the softly simmering cauldron with its shimmering fumes, the delicate power of liquids that creep through human veins, bewitching the mind, ensnaring the senses.... I can teach you how to bottle fame, brew glory, even stopper death -- if you aren't as big a bunch of dunderheads as I usually have to teach."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: More silence followed this little speech. Harry and Ron exchanged looks with raised eyebrows. Hermione Granger was on the edge of her seat and looked desperate to start proving that she wasn't a dunderhead.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Potter!" said Snape suddenly. "What would I get if I added powdered root of asphodel to an infusion of wormwood?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Powdered root of what to an infusion of what? Harry glanced at Ron, who looked as stumped as he was; Hermione's hand had shot into the air.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I don't know, sit," said Harry.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Snape's lips curled into a sneer.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Tut, tut -- fame clearly isn't everything."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He ignored Hermione's hand.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Let's try again. Potter, where would you look if I told you to find me a bezoar?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hermione stretched her hand as high into the air as it would go without her leaving her seat, but Harry didn't have the faintest idea what a bezoar was. He tried not to look at Malfoy, Crabbe, and Goyle, who were shaking with laughter.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I don't know, sit." "Thought you wouldn't open a book before coming,

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: eh, Potter?" Harry forced himself to keep looking straight into those cold eyes. He had looked through his books at the Dursleys', but did Snape expect him to remember everything in One Thousand Magical Herbs and Fungi?

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Snape was still ignoring Hermione's quivering hand.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What is the difference, Potter, between monkshood and wolfsbane?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: At this, Hermione stood up, her hand stretching toward the dungeon ceiling.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I don't know," said Harry quietly. "I think Hermione does, though, why don't you try her?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: A few people laughed; Harry caught Seamus's eye, and Seamus winked. Snape, however, was not pleased.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Sit down," he snapped at Hermione. "For your information, Potter, asphodel and wormwood make a sleeping potion so powerful it is known as the Draught of Living Death. A bezoar is a stone taken from the stomach of a goat and it will save you from most poisons. As for monkshood and wolfsbane, they are the same plant, which also goes by the name of aconite. Well? Why aren't you all copying that down?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: There was a sudden rummaging for quills and parchment. Over the noise, Snape said, "And a point will be taken from Gryffindor House for your cheek, Potter."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Things didn't improve for the Gryffindors as the Potions lesson continued. Snape put them all into pairs and set them to mixing up a simple potion to cure boils. He swept around in his long black cloak, watching them weigh dried nettles and crush snake fangs, criticizing almost everyone except Malfoy, whom he seemed to like. He was just telling everyone to look at the perfect way Malfoy had stewed his horned slugs when clouds of acid green smoke and a loud hissing filled the dungeon. Neville had somehow managed to melt Seamus's cauldron into a twisted blob, and their potion was seeping across the stone floor, burning holes in people's shoes. Within seconds, the whole class was standing on their stools while Neville, who had been drenched in the potion when the cauldron collapsed, moaned in pain as angry red boils sprang up all over his arms and legs.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Idiot boy!" snarled Snape, clearing the spilled potion away with one wave of his wand. "I suppose you added the porcupine quills before taking the cauldron off the fire?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Neville whimpered as boils started to pop up all over his nose.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Take him up to the hospital wing," Snape spat at Seamus. Then he rounded on Harry and Ron, who had been working next to Neville.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You -- Potter -- why didn't you tell him not to add the quills? Thought he'd make you look good if he got it wrong, did you? That's another point you've lost for Gryffindor."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: This was so unfair that Harry opened his mouth to argue, but Ron kicked him behind their cauldron.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Doi* push it," he muttered, "I've heard Snape can turn very nasty."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: As they climbed the steps out of the dungeon an hour later, Harry's mind was racing and his spirits were low. He'd lost two points for Gryffindor in his very first week -- why did Snape hate him so much? "Cheer up," said Ron, "Snape's always taking points off Fred and George. Can I come and meet Hagrid with you?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: At five to three they left the castle and made their way across the grounds. Hagrid lived in a small wooden house on the edge of the forbidden forest. A crossbow and a pair of galoshes were outside the front door.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: When Harry knocked they heard a frantic scrabbling from inside and several booming barks. Then Hagrid's voice rang out, saying, "Back, Fang -- back."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hagrid's big, hairy face appeared in the crack as he pulled the door open.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Hang on," he said. "Back, Fang."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He let them in, struggling to keep a hold on the collar of an enormous black boarhound.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: There was only one room inside. Hams and pheasants were hanging from the ceiling, a copper kettle was boiling on the open fire, and in the corner

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: stood a massive bed with a patchwork quilt over it.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Make yerselves at home," said Hagrid, letting go of Fang, who bounded straight at Ron and started licking his ears. Like Hagrid, Fang was clearly not as fierce as he looked.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "This is Ron," Harry told Hagrid, who was pouring boiling water into a large teapot and putting rock cakes onto a plate.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Another Weasley, eh?" said Hagrid, glancing at Ron's freckles. I spent half me life chasin' yer twin brothers away from the forest."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The rock cakes were shapeless lumps with raisins that almost broke their teeth, but Harry and Ron pretended to be enjoying them as they told Hagrid all about their first -lessons. Fang rested his head on Harry's knee and drooled all over his robes.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry and Ron were delighted to hear Hagrid call Fitch "that old git."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "An' as fer that cat, Mrs. Norris, I'd like ter introduce her to Fang sometime. D'yeh know, every time I go up ter the school, she follows me everywhere? Can't get rid of her -- Fitch puts her up to it."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry told Hagrid about Snape's lesson. Hagrid, like Ron, told Harry not to worry about it, that Snape liked hardly any of the students.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "But he seemed to really hate me."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Rubbish!" said Hagrid. "Why should he?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Yet Harry couldn't help thinking that Hagrid didn't quite meet his eyes when he said that.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "How's yer brother Charlie?" Hagrid asked Ron. "I liked him a lot -- great with animals."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry wondered if Hagrid had changed the subject on purpose. While Ron told Hagrid all about Charlie's work with dragons, Harry picked up a piece of paper that was lying on the table under the tea cozy. It was a cutting from the Daily Prophet:

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: GRINGOTTS BREAK-IN LATEST

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Investigations continue into the break-in at Gringotts on 31 July, widely believed to be the work of Dark wizards or witches unknown.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Gringotts goblins today insisted that nothing had been taken. The vault that was searched had in fact been emptied the same day.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "But we're not telling you what was in there, so keep your noses out if you know what's good for you," said a Gringotts spokesgoblin this afternoon.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry remembered Ron telling him on the train that someone had tried to rob Gringotts, but Ron hadn't mentioned the date.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Hagrid!" said Harry, "that Gringotts break-in happened on my birthday! It might've been happening while we were there!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: There was no doubt about it, Hagrid definitely didn't meet Harry's eyes this time. He grunted and offered him another rock cake. Harry read the story again. The vault that was searched had in fact been emptied earlier that same day. Hagrid had emptied vault seven hundred and thirteen, if you could call it emptying, taking out that grubby little package. Had that been what the thieves were looking for?

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: As Harry and Ron walked back to the castle for dinner, their pockets weighed down with rock cakes they'd been too polite to refuse, Harry thought that none of the lessons he'd had so far had given him as much to think about as tea with Hagrid. Had Hagrid collected that package just in time? Where was it now? And did Hagrid know something about Snape that he didn't want to tell Harry?

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: CHAPTER NINE

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: THE MIDNIGHT DUEL

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry had never believed he would meet a boy he hated more than Dudley, but that was before he met Draco Malfoy. Still, first-year Gryffindors only had Potions with the Slytherins, so they didn't have to put up with Malfoy much. Or at least, they didn't until they spotted a notice pinned up in the Gryffindor common room that made them all groan. Flying lessons would be starting on Thursday -- and Gryffindor and Slytherin would be learning together.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Typical," said Harry darkly. "Just what I always wanted. To make a fool of myself on a broomstick in front of Malfoy."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He had been looking forward to learning to fly more than anything else.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You don't know that you'll make a fool of yourself," said Ron reasonably. "Anyway, I know Malfoy's always going on about how good he is at Quidditch, but I bet that's all talk."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Malfay certainly did talk about flying a lot. He complained loudly about first years never getting on the house Quidditch teams and told long, boastful stories that always seemed to end with him narrowly escaping Muggles in helicopters. He wasn't the only one, though: the way Seamus Finnigan told it, he'd spent most of his childhood zooming around the countryside on his broomstick. Even Ron would tell anyone who'd listen about the time he'd almost hit a hang glider on Charlie's old broom. Everyone from wizarding families talked about Quidditch constantly. Ron had already had a big argument with Dean Thomas, who shared their dormitory, about soccer. Ron couldn't see what was exciting about a game with only one ball where no one was allowed to fly. Harry had caught Ron prodding Dean's poster of West Ham soccer team, trying to make the players move.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Neville had never been on a broomstick in his life, because his grandmother had never let him near one. Privately, Harry felt she'd had good reason, because Neville managed to have an extraordinary number of accidents even with both feet on the ground.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hermione Granger was almost as nervous about flying as Neville was. This was something you couldn't learn by heart out of a book -- not that she hadn't tried. At breakfast on Thursday she bored them all stupid with flying tips she'd gotten out of a library book called Quidditch Through the Ages. Neville was hanging on to her every word, desperate for anything that might help him hang on to his broomstick later, but everybody else was very pleased when Hermione's lecture was interrupted by the arrival of the mail.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry hadn't had a single letter since Hagrid's note, something that Malfoy had been quick to notice, of course. Malfoy's eagle owl was always bringing him packages of sweets from home, which he opened gloatingly at the Slytherin table.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: A barn owl brought Neville a small package from his grandmother. He

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: opened it excitedly and showed them a glass ball the size of a large marble, which seemed to be full of white smoke.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "It's a Remembrall!" he explained. "Gran knows I forget things -- this tells you if there's something you've forgotten to do. Look, you hold it tight like this and if it turns red -- oh..." His face fell, because the Remembrall had suddenly glowed scarlet,

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You've forgotten something..."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Neville was trying to remember what he'd forgotten when Draco Malfoy, who was passing the Gryffindor table, snatched the Remembrall out of his hand.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry and Ron jumped to their feet. They were half hoping for a reason to fight Malfay, but Professor McGonagall, who could spot trouble quicker than any teacher in the school, was there in a flash.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What's going on?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Malfoy's got my Remembrall, Professor."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Scowling, Malfoy quickly dropped the Remembrall back on the table.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Just looking," he said, and he sloped away with Crabbe and Goyle behind him.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: At three-thirty that afternoon, Harry, Ron, and the other Gryffindors hurried down the front steps onto the grounds for their first flying lesson. It was a clear, breezy day, and the grass rippled under their feet as they marched down the sloping lawns toward a smooth, flat lawn on the opposite side of the grounds to the forbidden forest, whose trees were swaying darkly in the distance.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The Slytherins were already there, and so were twenty broomsticks lying in neat lines on the ground. Harry had heard Fred and George Weasley complain about the school brooms, saying that some of them started to vibrate if you flew too high, or always flew slightly to the left.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Their teacher, Madam Hooch, arrived. She had short, gray hair, and yellow eyes like a hawk.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Well, what are you all waiting for?" she barked. "Everyone stand by a

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: broomstick. Come on, hurry up."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry glanced down at his broom. It was old and some of the twigs stuck out at odd angles.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Stick out your right hand over your broom," called Madam Hooch at the front, "and say 'Up!"'

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "UPF everyone shouted.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry's broom jumped into his hand at once, but it was one of the few that did. Hermione Granger's had simply rolled over on the ground, and Neville's hadn't moved at all. Perhaps brooms, like horses, could tell when you were afraid, thought Harry; there was a quaver in Neville's voice that said only too clearly that he wanted to keep his feet on the ground.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Madam Hooch then showed them how to mount their brooms without sliding off the end, and walked up and down the rows correcting their grips. Harry and Ron were delighted when she told Malfoy he'd been doing it wrong for years.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Now, when I blow my whistle, you kick off from the ground, hard," said Madam Hooch. "Keep your brooms steady, rise a few feet, and then come straight back down by leaning forward slightly. On my whistle -- three -- two --"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: But Neville, nervous and jumpy and frightened of being left on the ground, pushed off hard before the whistle had touched Madam Hooch's lips.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Come back, boy!" she shouted, but Neville was rising straight up like a cork shot out of a bottle -- twelve feet -- twenty feet. Harry saw his scared white face look down at the ground falling away, saw him gasp, slip sideways off the broom and --

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: WHAM -- a thud and a nasty crack and Neville lay facedown on the grass in a heap. His broomstick was still rising higher and higher, and started to drift lazily toward the forbidden forest and out of sight.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Madam Hooch was bending over Neville, her face as white as his.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Broken wrist," Harry heard her mutter. "Come on, boy -- it's all right,

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: up you get.".

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: She turned to the rest of the class.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "None of you is to move while I take this boy to the hospital wing! You leave those brooms where they are or you'll be out of Hogwarts before you can say 'Quidditch.' Come on, dear."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Neville, his face tear-streaked, clutching his wrist, hobbled off with Madam Hooch, who had her arm around him.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: No sooner were they out of earshot than Malfoy burst into laughter.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Did you see his face, the great lump?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The other Slytherins joined in.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Shut up, Malfoy," snapped Parvati Patil.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Ooh, sticking up for Longbottom?" said Pansy Parkinson, a hard-faced Slytherin girl. "Never thought you'd like fat little crybabies, Parvati."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Look!" said Malfoy, darting forward and snatching something out of the grass. "It's that stupid thing Longbottom's gran sent him."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The Remembrall glittered in the sun as he held it up.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Give that here, Malfoy," said Harry quietly. Everyone stopped talking to watch.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Malfoy smiled nastily.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I think I'll leave it somewhere for Longbottom to find -- how about -- up a tree?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Give it here!" Harry yelled, but Malfoy had leapt onto his broomstick and taken off. He hadn't been lying, he could fly well. Hovering level with the topmost branches of an oak he called, "Come and get it, Potter!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry grabbed his broom.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "No!" shouted Hermione Granger. "Madam Hooch told us not to move -- you'll get us all into trouble."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry ignored her. Blood was pounding in his ears. He mounted the broom and kicked hard against the ground and up, up he soared; air rushed through his hair, and his robes whipped out behind him -and in a rush of fierce joy he realized he'd found something he could do without being taught -- this was easy, this was wonderful. He pulled his broomstick up a little to take it even higher, and heard screams and gasps of girls back on the ground and an admiring whoop from Ron.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He turned his broomstick sharply to face Malfoy in midair. Malfoy looked stunned.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Give it here," Harry called, "or I'll knock you off that broom!" "Oh, yeah?" said Malfoy, trying to sneer, but looking worried.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry knew, somehow, what to do. He leaned forward and grasped the broom tightly in both hands, and it shot toward Malfay like a javelin. Malfoy only just got out of the way in time; Harry made a sharp about-face and held the broom steady. A few people below were clapping.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "No Crabbe and Goyle up here to save your neck, Malfoy," Harry called.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The same thought seemed to have struck Malfoy.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Catch it if you can, then!" he shouted, and he threw the glass ball high into the air and streaked back toward the ground.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry saw, as though in slow motion, the ball rise up in the air and then start to fall. He leaned forward and pointed his broom handle down -- next second he was gathering speed in a steep dive, racing the ball -- wind whistled in his ears, mingled with the screams of people watching -- he stretched out his hand -- a foot from the ground he caught it, just in time to pull his broom straight, and he toppled gently onto the grass with the Remembrall clutched safely in his fist.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "HARRY POTTER!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: His heart sank faster than he'd just dived. Professor McGonagall was running toward them. He got to his feet, trembling.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Never -- in all my time at Hogwarts --"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Professor McGonagall was almost speechless with shock, and her glasses flashed furiously, "-- how dare you -- might have broken your neck --"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "It wasn't his fault, Professor --"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Be quiet, Miss Patil

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "But Malfoy --"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "That's enough, Mr. Weasley. Potter, follow me, now."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry caught sight of Malfoy, Crabbe, and Goyle's triumphant faces as he left, walking numbly in Professor McGonagall's wake as she strode toward the castle. He was going to be expelled, he just knew it. He wanted to say something to defend himself, but there seemed to be something wrong with his voice. Professor McGonagall was sweeping along without even looking at him; he had to jog to keep up. Now he'd done it. He hadn't even lasted two weeks. He'd be packing his bags in ten minutes. What would the Dursleys say when he turned up on the doorstep?

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Up the front steps, up the marble staircase inside, and still Professor McGonagall didn't say a word to him. She wrenched open doors and marched along corridors with Harry trotting miserably behind her. Maybe she was taking him to Dumbledore. He thought of Hagrid, expelled but allowed to stay on as gamekeeper. Perhaps he could be Hagrid's assistant. His stomach twisted as he imagined it, watching Ron and the others becoming wizards, while he stumped around the grounds carrying Hagrid's bag.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Professor McGonagall stopped outside a classroom. She opened the door and poked her head inside.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Excuse me, Professor Flitwick, could I borrow Wood for a moment?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Wood? thought Harry, bewildered; was Wood a cane she was going to use on him?

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: But Wood turned out to be a person, a burly fifth-year boy who came out of Flitwicles class looking confused.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Follow me, you two," said Professor McGonagall, and they marched on up the corridor, Wood looking curiously at Harry.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "In here."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Professor McGonagall pointed them into a classroom that was empty except for Peeves, who was busy writing rude words on the blackboard.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Out, Peeves!" she barked. Peeves threw the chalk into a bin, which clanged loudly, and he swooped out cursing. Professor McGonagall slammed the door behind him and turned to face the two boys.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Potter, this is Oliver Wood. Wood -- I've found you a Seeker."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Wood's expression changed from puzzlement to delight.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Are you serious, Professor?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Absolutely," said Professor McGonagall crisply. "The boy's a natural. I've never seen anything like it. Was that your first time on a broomstick, Potter?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry nodded silently. He didn't have a clue what was going on, but he didn't seem to be being expelled, and some of the feeling started coming back to his legs.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "He caught that thing in his hand after a fifty-foot dive," Professor McGonagall told Wood. "Didn't even scratch himself. Charlie Weasley couldn't have done it."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Wood was now looking as though all his dreams had come true at once.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Ever seen a game of Quidditch, Potter?" he asked excitedly.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Wood's captain of the Gryffindor team," Professor McGonagall explained.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "He's just the build for a Seeker, too," said Wood, now walking around Harry and staring at him. "Light -- speedy -- we'll have to get him a decent broom, Professor -- a Nimbus Two Thousand or a Cleansweep Seven, I'd say."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: I shall speak to Professor Dumbledore and see if we can't bend the first-year rule. Heaven knows, we need a better team than last year. Flattened in that last match by Slytherin, I couldn't look Severus Snape in the face for weeks...."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Professor McGonagall peered sternly over her glasses at Harry.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
