text: "I want to hear you're training hard, Potter, or I may change my mind about punishing you."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Then she suddenly smiled.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Your father would have been proud," she said. "He was an excellent Quidditch player himself."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You're joking."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: It was dinnertime. Harry had just finished telling Ron what had happened when he'd left the grounds with Professor McGonagall. Ron had a piece of steak and kidney pie halfway to his mouth, but he'd forgotten all about it.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Seeker?" he said. "But first years never -- you must be the youngest house player in about a century, said Harry, shoveling pie into his mouth. He felt particularly hungry after the excitement of the afternoon. "Wood told me."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Ron was so amazed, so impressed, he just sat and gaped at Harry.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I start training next week," said Harry. "Only don't tell anyone, Wood wants to keep it a secret."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Fred and George Weasley now came into the hall, spotted Harry, and hurried over.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Well done," said George in a low voice. "Wood told us. We're on the team too -- Beaters."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I tell you, we're going to win that Quidditch cup for sure this year," said Fred. "We haven't won since Charlie left, but this year's team is going to be brilliant. You must be good, Harry, Wood was almost skipping when he told us."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Anyway, we've got to go, Lee Jordan reckons he's found a new secret passageway out of the school."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Bet it's that one behind the statue of Gregory the Smarmy that we found in our first week. See you."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Fred and George had hardly disappeared when someone far less welcome turned up: Malfoy, flanked by Crabbe and Goyle.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Having a last meal, Potter? When are you getting the train back to the Muggles?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You're a lot braver now that you're back on the ground and you've got your little friends with you," said Harry coolly. There was of course nothing at all little about Crabbe and Goyle, but as the High Table was full of teachers, neither of them could do more than crack their knuckles and scowl.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I'd take you on anytime on my own," said Malfoy. "Tonight, if you want. Wizard's duel. Wands only -- no contact. What's the matter? Never heard of a wizard's duel before, I suppose?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Of course he has," said Ron, wheeling around. "I'm his second, who's yours?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Malfoy looked at Crabbe and Goyle, sizing them up.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Crabbe," he said. "Midnight all right? We'll meet you in the trophy room; that's always unlocked."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: When Malfoy had gone, Ron and Harry looked at each other. "What is a wizard's duel?" said Harry. "And what do you mean, you're my second?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Well, a second's there to take over if you die," said Ron casually, getting started at last on his cold pie. Catching the look on Harry's face, he added quickly, "But people only die in proper duels, you know, with real wizards. The most you and Malfoy'll be able to do is send sparks at each other. Neither of you knows enough magic to do any real damage. I bet he expected you to refuse, anyway."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "And what if I wave my wand and nothing happens?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Throw it away and punch him on the nose," Ron suggested. "Excuse me."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: They both looked up. It was Hermione Granger.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Can't a person eat in peace in this place?" said Ron.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hermione ignored him and spoke to Harry.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I couldn't help overhearing what you and Malfoy were saying --"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Bet you could," Ron muttered.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "--and you mustn't go wandering around the school at night, think of the points you'll lose Gryffindor if you're caught, and you're bound to be. It's really very selfish of you."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "And it's really none of your business," said Harry.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Good-bye," said Ron.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: All the same, it wasn't what you'd call the perfect end to the day, Harry thought, as he lay awake much later listening to Dean and Seamus falling asleep (Neville wasn't back from the hospital wing). Ron had spent all evening giving him advice such as "If he tries to curse you, you'd better dodge it, because I can't remember how to block them." There was a very good chance they were going to get caught by Filch or Mrs. Norris, and Harry felt he was pushing his luck, breaking another school rule today. On the other hand, Malfoys sneering face kept looming up out of the darkness - this was his big chance to beat Malfoy face-to-face. He couldn't miss it.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Half-past eleven," Ron muttered at last, "we'd better go."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: They pulled on their bathrobes, picked up their wands, and crept across the tower room, down the spiral staircase, and into the Gryffindor common room. A few embers were still glowing in the fireplace, turning all the armchairs into hunched black shadows. They had almost reached the portrait hole when a voice spoke from the chair nearest them, "I can't believe you're going to do this, Harry."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: A lamp flickered on. It was Hermione Granger, wearing a pink bathrobe and a frown.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You!" said Ron furiously. "Go back to bed!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I almost told your brother," Hermione snapped, "Percy -- he's a prefect, he'd put a stop to this."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry couldn't believe anyone could be so interfering.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Come on," he said to Ron. He pushed open the portrait of the Fat Lady and climbed through the hole.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hermione wasn't going to give up that easily. She followed Ron through the portrait hole, hissing at them like an angry goose.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Don't you care about Gryffindor, do you only care about yourselves, I don't want Slytherin to win the house cup, and you'll lose all the points I got from Professor McGonagall for knowing about Switching Spells."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Go away." "All right, but I warned you, you just remember what I said when you're on the train home tomorrow, you're so --"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: But what they were, they didn't find out. Hermione had turned to the portrait of the Fat Lady to get back inside and found herself facing an empty painting. The Fat Lady had gone on a nighttime visit and Hermione was locked out of Gryffindor tower.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Now what am I going to do?" she asked shrilly.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "That's your problem," said Ron. "We've got to go, we 3 re going to be late."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: They hadn't even reached the end of the corridor when Hermione caught up with them.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I'm coming with you," she said.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You are not."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "D'you think I'm going to stand out here and wait for Filch to catch me? If he finds all three of us I'll tell him the truth, that I was trying to stop you, and you can back me up."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You've got some nerve --" said Ron loudly.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Shut up, both of you!" said Harry sharply. I heard something."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: It was a sort of snuffling.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Mrs. Norris?" breathed Ron, squinting through the dark.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: It wasn't Mrs. Norris. It was Neville. He was curled up on the floor, fast asleep, but jerked suddenly awake as they crept nearer.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Thank goodness you found me! I've been out here for hours, I couldn't remember the new password to get in to bed."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Keep your voice down, Neville. The password's 'Pig snout' but it won't help you now, the Fat Lady's gone off somewhere."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "How's your arm?" said Harry.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Fine," said Neville, showing them. "Madam Pomfrey mended it in about a minute."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Good - well, look, Neville, we've got to be somewhere, we'll see you later --"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Don't leave me!" said Neville, scrambling to his feet, "I don't want to stay here alone, the Bloody Baron's been past twice already."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Ron looked at his watch and then glared furiously at Hermione and Neville.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "If either of you get us caught, I'll never rest until I've learned that Curse of the Bogies Quirrell told us about, and used it on you.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hermione opened her mouth, perhaps to tell Ron exactly how to use the Curse of the Bogies, but Harry hissed at her to be quiet and beckoned them all forward.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: They flitted along corridors striped with bars of moonlight from the high windows. At every turn Harry expected to run into Filch or Mrs. Norris, but they were lucky. They sped up a staircase to the third floor and tiptoed toward the trophy room.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Malfoy and Crabbe weren't there yet. The crystal trophy cases glimmered where the moonlight caught them. Cups, shields, plates, and statues winked silver and gold in the darkness. They edged along the walls, keeping their eyes on the doors at either end of the room. Harry took out his wand in case Malfoy leapt in and started at once. The minutes crept by.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "He's late, maybe he's chickened out," Ron whispered.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Then a noise in the next room made them jump. Harry had only just raised his wand when they heard someone speak -and it wasn't Malfoy.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Sniff around, my sweet, they might be lurking in a corner."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: It was Filch speaking to Mrs. Norris. Horror-struck, Harry waved madly at the other three to follow him as quickly as possible; they scurried silently toward the door, away from Filch's voice. Neville's robes had barely whipped round the corner when they heard Filch enter the trophy room.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "They're in here somewhere," they heard him mutter, "probably hiding."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "This way!" Harry mouthed to the others and, petrified, they began to creep down a long gallery full of suits of armor. They could hear Filch getting nearer. Neville suddenly let out a frightened squeak and broke into a run -he tripped, grabbed Ron around the waist, and the pair of them toppled right into a suit of armor.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The clanging and crashing were enough to wake the whole castle.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "RUN!" Harry yelled, and the four of them sprinted down the gallery, not looking back to see whether Filch was following -- they swung around the doorpost and galloped down one corridor then another, Harry in the lead, without any idea where they were or where they were going -- they ripped through a tapestry and found themselves in a hidden passageway, hurtled along it and came out near their Charms classroom, which they knew was miles from the trophy room.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I think we've lost him," Harry panted, leaning against the cold wall and wiping his forehead. Neville was bent double, wheezing and spluttering.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: I -- told -you," Hermione gasped, clutching at the stitch in her chest, "I -- told -- you."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "We've got to get back to Gryffindor tower," said Ron, "quickly as possible."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Malfoy tricked you," Hermione said to Harry. "You realize that, don't you? He was never going to meet you -- Filch knew someone was going to

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: be in the trophy room, Malfoy must have tipped him off."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry thought she was probably right, but he wasn't going to tell her that.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Let's go."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: It wasn't going to be that simple. They hadn't gone more than a dozen paces when a doorknob rattled and something came shooting out of a classroom in front of them.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: It was Peeves. He caught sight of them and gave a squeal of delight.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Shut up, Peeves -- please -- you'll get us thrown out."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Peeves cackled.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Wandering around at midnight, Ickle Firsties? Tut, tut, tut. Naughty, naughty, you'll get caughty."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Not if you don't give us away, Peeves, please."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Should tell Filch, I should," said Peeves in a saintly voice, but his eyes glittered wickedly. "It's for your own good, you know."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Get out of the way," snapped Ron, taking a swipe at Peeves this was a big mistake.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "STUDENTS OUT OF BED!" Peeves bellowed, "STUDENTS OUT OF BED DOWN THE

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: CHARMS CORRIDOR"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Ducking under Peeves, they ran for their lives, right to the end of the corridor where they slammed into a door -- and it was locked.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "This is it!" Ron moaned, as they pushed helplessly at the door, "We're done for! This is the end!" They could hear footsteps, Filch running as fast as he could toward Peeves's shouts.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Oh, move over," Hermione snarled. She grabbed Harry's wand, tapped the lock, and whispered, 'Alohomora!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The lock clicked and the door swung open -- they piled through it, shut

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: it quickly, and pressed their ears against it, listening.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Which way did they go, Peeves?" Filch was saying. "Quick, tell me."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Say 'please."'

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Don't mess with me, Peeves, now where did they go?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Shan't say nothing if you don't say please," said Peeves in his annoying singsong voice.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "All right -please."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "NOTHING! Ha haaa! Told you I wouldn't say nothing if you didn't say please! Ha ha! Haaaaaa!" And they heard the sound of Peeves whooshing away and Filch cursing in rage.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "He thinks this door is locked," Harry whispered. "I think we'll be okay -- get off, Neville!" For Neville had been tugging on the sleeve of Harry's bathrobe for the last minute. "What?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry turned around -- and saw, quite clearly, what. For a moment, he was sure he'd walked into a nightmare -- this was too much, on top of everything that had happened so far.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: They weren't in a room, as he had supposed. They were in a corridor. The forbidden corridor on the third floor. And now they knew why it was forbidden.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: They were looking straight into the eyes of a monstrous dog, a dog that filled the whole space between ceiling and floor. It had three heads. Three pairs of rolling, mad eyes; three noses, twitching

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: and quivering in their direction; three drooling mouths, saliva hanging in slippery ropes from yellowish fangs.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: It was standing quite still, all six eyes staring at them, and Harry knew that the only reason they weren't already dead was that their sudden appearance had taken it by surprise, but it was quickly getting over that, there was no mistaking what those thunderous growls meant.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry groped for the doorknob -- between Filch and death, he'd take Filch.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: They fell backward -- Harry slammed the door shut, and they ran, they almost flew, back down the corridor. Filch must have hurried off to look for them somewhere else, because they didn't see him anywhere, but they hardly cared -- all they wanted to do was put as much space as possible between them and that monster. They didn't stop running until they reached the portrait of the Fat Lady on the seventh floor.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Where on earth have you all been?" she asked, looking at their bathrobes hanging off their shoulders and their flushed, sweaty faces.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Never mind that -- pig snout, pig snout," panted Harry, and the portrait swung forward. They scrambled into the common room and collapsed, trembling, into armchairs.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: It was a while before any of them said anything. Neville, indeed, looked as if he'd never speak again.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What do they think they're doing, keeping a thing like that locked up in a school?" said Ron finally. "If any dog needs exercise, that one does."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hermione had got both her breath and her bad temper back again. "You don't use your eyes, any of you, do you?" she snapped. "Didn't you see what it was standing on.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "The floor?" Harry suggested. "I wasn't looking at its feet, I was too busy with its heads."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "No, not the floor. It was standing on a trapdoor. It's obviously guarding something."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: She stood up, glaring at them.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: I hope you're pleased with yourselves. We could all have been killed -- or worse, expelled. Now, if you don't mind, I'm going to bed."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Ron stared after her, his mouth open.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "No, we don't mind," he said. "You'd think we dragged her along, wouldn't you.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: But Hermione had given Harry something else to think about as he climbed

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: back into bed. The dog was guarding something.... What had Hagrid said? Gringotts was the safest place in the world for something you wanted to hide -- except perhaps Hogwarts.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: It looked as though Harry had found out where the grubby littie package from vault seven hundred and thirteen was.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: CHAPTER TEN

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: HALLOWEEN

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Malfoy couldn't believe his eyes when he saw that Harry and Ron were still at Hogwarts the next day, looking tired but perfectly cheerful. Indeed, by the next morning Harry and Ron thought that meeting the three-headed dog had been an excellent adventure, and they were quite keen to have another one. In the meantime, Harry filled Ron in about the package that seemed to have been moved from Gringotts to Hogwarts, and they spent a lot of time wondering what could possibly need such heavy protection. "It's either really valuable or really dangerous," said Ron. "Or both," said Harry.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: But as all they knew for sure about the mysterious object was that it was about two inches long, they didn't have much chance of guessing what it was without further clues.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Neither Neville nor Hermione showed the slightest interest in what lay underneath the dog and the trapdoor. All Neville cared about was never going near the dog again.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hermione was now refusing to speak to Harry and Ron, but she was such a bossy know-it-all that they saw this as an added bonus. All they really wanted now was a way of getting back at Malfoy, and to their great delight, just such a thing arrived in the mail about a week later.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: As the owls flooded into the Great Hall as usual, everyone's attention was caught at once by a long, thin package carried by six large screech owls. Harry was just as interested as everyone else to see what was in this large parcel, and was amazed when the owls soared down and dropped it right in front of him, knocking his bacon to the floor. They had hardly fluttered out of the way when another owl dropped a letter on top of the parcel.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry ripped open the letter first, which was lucky, because it said:

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: DO NOT OPEN THE PARCEL AT THE TABLE.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: It contains your new Nimbus Two Thousand, but I don't want everybody knowing you've got a broomstick or they'll all want one. Oliver Wood will meet you tonight on the Quidditch field at seven o'clock for your first training session.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Professor McGonagall

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry had difficulty hiding his glee as he handed the note to Ron to read.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "A Nimbus Two Thousand!" Ron moaned enviously. "I've never even touched one."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: They left the hall quickly, wanting to unwrap the broomstick in private before their first class, but halfway across the entrance hall they found the way upstairs barred by Crabbe and Goyle. Malfoy seized the package from Harry and felt it.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "That's a broomstick," he said, throwing it back to Harry with a mixture of jealousy and spite on his face. "You'll be in for it this time, Potter, first years aren't allowed them."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Ron couldn't resist it.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "It's not any old broomstick," he said, "it's a Nimbus Two Thousand. What did you say you've got at home, Malfoy, a Comet Two Sixty?" Ron grinned at Harry. "Comets look flashy, but they're not in the same league as the Nimbus."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What would you know about it, Weasley, you couldn't afford half the handle," Malfoy snapped back. "I suppose you and your brothers have to save up twig by twig."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Before Ron could answer, Professor Flitwick appeared at Malfoy's elbow.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Not arguing, I hope, boys?" he squeaked.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Potter's been sent a broomstick, Professor," said Malfoy quickly.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Yes, yes, that's right," said Professor Flitwick, beaming at Harry. "Professor McGonagall told me all about the special circumstances, Potter. And what model is it?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "A Nimbus Two Thousand, sit," said Harry, fighting not to laugh at the look of horror on Malfoy's face. "And it's really thanks to Malfoy here that I've got it," he added.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry and Ron headed upstairs, smothering their laughter at Malfoy's obvious rage and confusion. "Well, it's true," Harry chortled as they reached the top of the marble staircase, "If he hadn't stolen Neville's Remembrall I wouln't be on the team...."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "So I suppose you think that's a reward for breaking rules?" came an angry voice from just behind them. Hermione was stomping up the stairs, looking disapprovingly at the package in Harry's hand.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I thought you weren't speaking to us?" said Harry.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Yes, don't stop now," said Ron, "it's doing us so much good."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hermione marched away with her nose in the air.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry had a lot of trouble keeping his mind on his lessons that day. It kept wandering up to the dormitory where his new broomstick was lying under his bed, or straying off to the Quidditch field where he'd be learning to play that night. He bolted his dinner that evening without noticing what he was eating, and then rushed upstairs with Ron to unwrap the Nimbus Two Thousand at last.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Wow," Ron sighed, as the broomstick rolled onto Harry's bedspread.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Even Harry, who knew nothing about the different brooms, thought it looked wonderful. Sleek and shiny, with a mahogany handle, it had a long tail of neat, straight twigs and Nimbus Two Thousand written in gold near the top.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: As seven o'clock drew nearer, Harry left the castle and set off in the dusk toward the Quidditch field. Held never been inside the stadium before. Hundreds of seats were raised in stands around the field so that the spectators were high enough to see what was going on. At either end

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: of the field were three golden poles with hoops on the end. They reminded Harry of the little plastic sticks Muggle

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: children blew bubbles through, except that they were fifty feet high.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Too eager to fly again to wait for Wood, Harry mounted his broomstick and kicked off from the ground. What a feeling -- he swooped in and out of the goal posts and then sped up and down the field. The Nimbus Two Thousand turned wherever he wanted at his lightest touch.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Hey, Potter, come down!'

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Oliver Wood had arrived. fie was carrying a large wooden crate under his arm. Harry landed next to him.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Very nice," said Wood, his eyes glinting. "I see what McGonagall meant... you really are a natural. I'm just going to teach you the rules this evening, then you'll be joining team practice three times a week."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He opened the crate. Inside were four different-sized balls.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Right," said Wood. "Now, Quidditch is easy enough to understand, even if it's not too easy to play. There are seven players on each side. Three of them are called Chasers."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Three Chasers," Harry repeated, as Wood took out a bright red ball about the size of a soccer ball.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "This ball's called the Quaffle," said Wood. "The Chasers throw the Quaffle to each other and try and get it through one of the hoops to score a goal. Ten points every time the Quaffle goes through one of the hoops. Follow me?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "The Chasers throw the Quaffle and put it through the hoops to score," Harry recited. "So -- that's sort of like basketball on broomsticks with six hoops, isn't it?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What's basketball?" said Wood curiously. "Never mind," said Harry quickly.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Now, there's another player on each side who's called the Keeper -I'm Keeper for Gryffindor. I have to fly around our hoops and stop the other team from scoring."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Three Chasers, one Keeper," said Harry, who was determined to remember it all. "And they play with the Quaffle. Okay, got that. So what are they for?" He pointed at the three balls left inside the box.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I'll show you now," said Wood. "Take this."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He handed Harry a small club, a bit like a short baseball bat.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I'm going to show you what the Bludgers do," Wood said. "These two are the Bludgers."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He showed Harry two identical balls, jet black and slightly smaller than the red Quaffle. Harry noticed that they seemed to be straining to escape the straps holding them inside the box.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Stand back," Wood warned Harry. He bent down and freed one of the Bludgers.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: At once, the black ball rose high in the air and then pelted straight at Harry's face. Harry swung at it with the bat to stop it from breaking his nose, and sent it zigzagging away into the air -- it zoomed around their heads and then shot at Wood, who dived on top of it and managed to pin it to the ground.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "See?" Wood panted, forcing the struggling Bludger back into the crate and strapping it down safely. "The Bludgers rocket around, trying to knock players off their brooms. That's why you have two Beaters on each team -- the Weasley twins are ours -- it's their job to protect their side from the Bludgers and try and knock them toward the other team. So -- think you've got all that?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Three Chasers try and score with the Quaffle; the Keeper guards the goal posts; the Beaters keep the Bludgers away from their team," Harry reeled off.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Very good," said Wood.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Er -- have the Bludgers ever killed anyone?" Harry asked, hoping he sounded offhand.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Never at Hogwarts. We've had a couple of broken jaws but nothing worse than that. Now, the last member of the team is the

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Seeker. That's you. And you don't have to worry about the Quaffle or the Bludgers unless they crack my head open."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Don't worry, the Weasleys are more than a match for the Bludgers -- I mean, they're like a pair of human Bludgers themselves."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Wood reached into the crate and took out the fourth and last ball. Compared with the Quaffle and the Bludgers, it was tiny, about the size of a large walnut. It was bright gold and had little fluttering silver wings.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "This," said Wood, "is the Golden Snitch, and it's the most important ball of the lot. It's very hard to catch because it's so fast and difficult to see. It's the Seeker's job to catch it. You've got to weave in and out of the Chasers, Beaters, Bludgers, and Quaffle to get it before the other team's Seeker, because whichever Seeker catches the Snitch wins his team an extra hundred and fifty points, so they

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: nearly always win. That's why Seekers get fouled so much. A game of Quidditch only ends when the Snitch is caught, so it can go on for ages -- I think the record is three months, they had to keep bringing on substitutes so the players could get some sleep. "Well, that's it -- any questions?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry shook his head. He understood what he had to do all right, it was doing it that was going to be the problem.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "We won't practice with the Snitch yet," said Wood, carefully shutting it back inside the crate, "it's too dark, we might lose it. Let's try you out with a few of these."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He pulled a bag of ordinary golf balls out of his pocket and a few minutes later, he and Harry were up in the air, Wood throwing the golf balls as hard as he could in every direction for Harry to catch.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry didn't miss a single one, and Wood was delighted. After half an hour, night had really fallen and they couldn't carry on.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "That Quidditch cup'll have our name on it this year," said Wood happily as they trudged back up to the castle. "I wouldn't be surprised if you turn out better than Charlie Weasley, and he could have played for England if he hadn't gone off chasing dragons."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Perhaps it was because he was now so busy, what with Quidditch practice three evenings a week on top of all his homework, but Harry could hardly believe it when he realized that he'd already been at Hogwarts two months. The castle felt more like home than Privet Drive ever had. His lessons, too, were becoming more and more interesting now that they had mastered the basics.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: On Halloween morning they woke to the delicious smell of baking pumpkin wafting through the corridors. Even better, Professor Flitwick announced in Charms that he thought they were ready to start making objects fly, something they had all been dying to try since they'd seen him make Neville's toad zoom around the classroom. Professor Flitwick put the class into pairs to practice. Harry's partner was Seamus Finnigan (which was a relief, because Neville had been trying to catch his eye). Ron, however, was to be working with Hermione Granger. It was hard to tell whether Ron or Hermione was angrier about this. She hadn't spoken to either of them since the day Harry's broomstick had arrived.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Now, don't forget that nice wrist movement we've been practicing!" squeaked Professor Flitwick, perched on top of his pile of books as usual. "Swish and flick, remember, swish and flick. And saying the magic words properly is very important, too -- never forget Wizard Baruffio, who said 's' instead of 'f' and found himself on the floor with a buffalo on his chest."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: It was very difficult. Harry and Seamus swished and flicked, but the feather they were supposed to be sending skyward just lay on the desktop. Seamus got so impatient that he prodded it with his wand and set fire to it -- Harry had to put it out with his hat.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Ron, at the next table, wasn't having much more luck.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Wingardium Leviosa!" he shouted, waving his long arms like a windmill.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You're saying it wrong," Harry heard Hermione snap. "It's Wing-gar-dium Levi-o-sa, make the 'gar' nice and long."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You do it, then, if you're so clever," Ron snarled.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hermione rolled up the sleeves of her gown, flicked her wand, and said, "Wingardium Leviosa!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Their feather rose off the desk and hovered about four feet above their heads.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Oh, well done!" cried Professor Flitwick, clapping. "Everyone see here, Miss Granger's done it!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Ron was in a very bad mood by the end of the class. "It's no wonder no one can stand her," he said to Harry as they pushed their way into the crowded corridor, "she's a nightmare, honestly. "

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Someone knocked into Harry as they hurried past him. It was Hermione. Harry caught a glimpse of her face -- and was startled to see that she was in tears.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I think she heard you."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "So?" said Ron, but he looked a bit uncomfortable. "She must've noticed she's got no friends."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hermione didn't turn up for the next class and wasn't seen all afternoon. On their way down to the Great Hall for the Halloween feast, Harry and Ron overheard Parvati Patil telling her friend Lavender that Hermione was crying in the girls' bathroom and wanted to be left alone. Ron looked still more awkward at this, but a moment later they had entered the Great Hall, where the Halloween decorations put Hermione out of their minds.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: A thousand live bats fluttered from the walls and ceiling while a thousand more swooped over the tables in low black clouds, making the candles in the pumpkins stutter. The feast appeared suddenly on the golden plates, as it had at the start-of-term banquet.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry was just helping himself to a baked potato when Professor Quirrell came sprinting into the hall, his turban askew and terror on his face. Everyone stared as he reached Professor Dumbledore's chair, slumped against the table, and gasped, "Troll -- in the dungeons -- thought you ought to know."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He then sank to the floor in a dead faint.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: There was an uproar. It took several purple firecrackers exploding from the end of Professor Dumbledore's wand to bring silence.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Prefects," he rumbled, "lead your Houses back to the dormitories immediately!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Percy was in his element.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Follow me! Stick together, first years! No need to fear the troll if you follow my orders! Stay close behind me, now. Make way, first years coming through! Excuse me, I'm a prefect!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "How could a troll get in?" Harry asked as they climbed the stairs.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Don't ask me, they're supposed to be really stupid," said Ron. "Maybe Peeves let it in for a Halloween joke."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: They passed different groups of people hurrying in different directions. As they jostled their way through a crowd of confused Hufflepuffs, Harry suddenly grabbed Ron's arm.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I've just thought -- Hermione."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What about her?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "She doesn't know about the troll."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Ron bit his lip.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Oh, all right," he snapped. "But Percy'd better not see us."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Ducking down, they joined the Hufflepuffs going the other way, slipped down a deserted side corridor, and hurried off toward the girls' bathroom. They had just turned the corner when they heard quick footsteps behind them.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Percy!" hissed Ron, pulling Harry behind a large stone griffin.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Peering around it, however, they saw not Percy but Snape. He crossed the corridor and disappeared from view.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What's he doing?" Harry whispered. "Why isn't he down in the dungeons with the rest of the teachers?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Search me."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Quietly as possible, they crept along the next corridor after Snape's fading footsteps.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "He's heading for the third floor," Harry said, but Ron held up his hand.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Can you smell something?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry sniffed and a foul stench reached his nostrils, a mixture of old socks and the kind of public toilet no one seems to clean.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: And then they heard it -- a low grunting, and the shuffling footfalls of gigantic feet. Ron pointed -- at the end of a passage to the left, something huge was moving toward them. They shrank into the shadows and watched as it emerged into a patch of moonlight.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: It was a horrible sight. Twelve feet tall, its skin was a dull, granite gray, its great lumpy body like a boulder with its small bald head perched on top like a coconut. It had short legs thick as tree trunks with flat, horny feet. The smell coming from it was incredible. It was holding a huge wooden club, which dragged along the floor because its arms were so long.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The troll stopped next to a doorway and peered inside. It waggled its long ears, making up its tiny mind, then slouched slowly into the room.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "The keys in the lock," Harry muttered. "We could lock it in."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Good idea," said Ron nervously.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: They edged toward the open door, mouths dry, praying the troll wasn't about to come out of it. With one great leap, Harry managed to grab the key, slam the door, and lock it.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: 'Yes!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Flushed with their victory, they started to run back up the passage, but as they reached the corner they heard something that made their hearts stop -- a high, petrified scream -- and it was coming from the chamber they'd just chained up.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Oh, no," said Ron, pale as the Bloody Baron.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "It's the girls' bathroom!" Harry gasped.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Hermione!" they said together.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: It was the last thing they wanted to do, but what choice did they have? Wheeling around, they sprinted back to the door and turned the key, fumbling in their panic. Harry pulled the door open and they ran inside.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hermione Granger was shrinking against the wall opposite, looking as if she was about to faint. The troll was advancing on her, knocking the sinks off the walls as it went.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Confuse it!" Harry said desperately to Ron, and, seizing a tap, he threw it as hard as he could against the wall.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The troll stopped a few feet from Hermione. It lumbered around, blinking stupidly, to see what had made the noise. Its mean little eyes saw Harry. It hesitated, then made for him instead, lifting its club as it went.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Oy, pea-brain!" yelled Ron from the other side of the chamber, and he threw a metal pipe at it. The troll didn't even seem to notice the pipe hitting its shoulder, but it heard the yell and paused again, turning its ugly snout toward Ron instead, giving Harry time to run around it.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Come on, run, run!" Harry yelled at Hermione, trying to pull her toward the door, but she couldn't move, she was still flat against the wall, her mouth open with terror.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The shouting and the echoes seemed to be driving the troll berserk. It roared again and started toward Ron, who was nearest and had no way to escape.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry then did something that was both very brave and very stupid: He took a great running jump and managed to fasten his arms around the troll's neck from behind. The troll couldn't feel Harry hanging there, but even a troll will notice if you stick a long bit of wood up its nose, and Harry's wand had still been in his hand when he'd jumped -- it had gone straight up one of the troll's nostrils.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Howling with pain, the troll twisted and flailed its club, with Harry clinging on for dear life; any second, the troll was going to rip him

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: off or catch him a terrible blow with the club.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hermione had sunk to the floor in fright; Ron pulled out his own wand -- not knowing what he was going to do he heard himself cry the first spell that came into his head: "Wingardium Leviosa!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The club flew suddenly out of the troll's hand, rose high, high up into the air, turned slowly over -- and dropped, with a sickening crack, onto its owner's head. The troll swayed on the spot and then fell flat on its face, with a thud that made the whole room tremble.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry got to his feet. He was shaking and out of breath. Ron was standing there with his wand still raised, staring at what he had done.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: It was Hermione who spoke first.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Is it -- dead?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: I don't think so," said Harry, I think it's just been knocked out."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He bent down and pulled his wand out of the troll's nose. It was covered in what looked like lumpy gray glue.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Urgh -- troll boogers."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He wiped it on the troll's trousers.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: A sudden slamming and loud footsteps made the three of them look up. They hadn't realized what a racket they had been making, but of course, someone downstairs must have heard the crashes and the troll's roars. A moment later, Professor McGonagall had come bursting into the room, closely followed by Snape, with Quirrell bringing up the rear. Quirrell took one look at the troll, let out a faint whimper, and sat quickly down on a toilet, clutching his heart.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Snape bent over the troll. Professor McGonagall was looking at Ron and Harry. Harry had never seen her look so angry. Her lips were white. Hopes of winning fifty points for Gryffindor faded quickly from Harry's mind.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What on earth were you thinking of?" said Professor McGonagall, with cold fury in her voice. Harry looked at Ron, who was still standing with his wand in the air. "You're lucky you weren't killed. Why aren't you in

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: your dormitory?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Snape gave Harry a swift, piercing look. Harry looked at the floor. He wished Ron would put his wand down.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Then a small voice came out of the shadows.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Please, Professor McGonagall -- they were looking for me."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Miss Granger!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hermione had managed to get to her feet at last.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: I went looking for the troll because I -- I thought I could deal with it on my own -- you know, because I've read all about them."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Ron dropped his wand. Hermione Granger, telling a downright lie to a teacher? "If they hadn't found me, I'd be dead now. Harry stuck his wand up its nose and Ron knocked it out with its own club. They didn't have time to come and fetch anyone. It was about to finish me off when they arrived."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry and Ron tried to look as though this story wasn't new to them.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Well -- in that case..." said Professor McGonagall, staring at the three of them, "Miss Granger, you foolish girl, how could you think of tackling a mountain troll on your own?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hermione hung her head. Harry was speechless. Hermione was the last person to do anything against the rules, and here she was, pretending she had, to get them out of trouble. It was as if Snape had started handing out sweets.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Miss Granger, five points will be taken from Gryffindor for this," said Professor McGonagall. "I'm very disappointed in you. If you're not hurt at all, you'd better get off to Gryffindor tower. Students are finishing the feast in their houses."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hermione left.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Professor McGonagall turned to Harry and Ron.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Well, I still say you were lucky, but not many first years could have

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: taken on a full-grown mountain troll. You each win Gryffindor five points. Professor Dumbledore will be informed of this. You may go."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: They hurried out of the chamber and didn't speak at all until they had climbed two floors up. It was a relief to be away from the smell of the troll, quite apart from anything else.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "We should have gotten more than ten points," Ron grumbled.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Five, you mean, once she's taken off Hermione's."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Good of her to get us out of trouble like that," Ron admitted. "Mind you, we did save her."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "She might not have needed saving if we hadn't locked the thing in with her," Harry reminded him.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: They had reached the portrait of the Fat Lady.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Pig snout," they said and entered.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The common room was packed and noisy. Everyone was eating the food that had been sent up. Hermione, however, stood alone by the door, waiting for them. There was a very embarrassed pause. Then, none of them looking at each other, they all said "Thanks," and hurried off to get plates.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: But from that moment on, Hermione Granger became their friend. There are some things you can't share without ending up liking each other, and knocking out a twelve-foot mountain troll is one of them.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: CHAPTER ELEVEN

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: QUIDDITCH

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: As they entered November, the weather turned very cold. The mountains around the school became icy gray and the lake like chilled steel. Every morning the ground was covered in frost. Hagrid could be seen from the upstairs windows defrosting broomsticks on the Quidditch field, bundled up in a long moleskin overcoat, rabbit fur gloves, and enormous beaverskin boots.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The Quidditch season had begun. On Saturday, Harry would be playing in

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: his first match after weeks of training: Gryffindor versus Slytherin. If Gryffindor won, they would move up into second place in the house championship.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hardly anyone had seen Harry play because Wood had decided that, as their secret weapon, Harry should be kept, well, secret. But the news that he was playing Seeker had leaked out somehow, and Harry didn't know which was worse -- people telling him he'd be brilliant or people telling him they'd be running around underneath him holding a mattress.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: It was really lucky that Harry now had Hermlone as a friend. He didn't know how he'd have gotten through all his homework without her, what with all the last-minute Quidditch practice Wood was making them do. She had also tent him Quidditch Through the Ages, which turned out to be a very interesting read.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry learned that there were seven hundred ways of committing a Quidditch foul and that all of them had happened during a World Cup match in 1473; that Seekers were usually the smallest and fastest players, and that most serious Quidditch accidents seemed to happen to them; that although people rarely died playing Quidditch, referees had been known to vanish and turn up months later in the Sahara Desert.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hermione had become a bit more relaxed about breaking rules since Harry and Ron had saved her from the mountain troll, and she was much nicer for it. The day before Harry's first Quidditch match the three of them were out in the freezing courtyard during break, and she had conjured them up a bright blue fire that could be carried around in a jam jar. They were standing with their backs to it, getting warm, when Snape crossed the yard. Harry noticed at once that Snape was limping. Harry, Ron, and Hermione moved closer together to block the fire from view; they were sure it wouldn't be allowed. Unfortunately, something about their guilty faces caught Snape's eye. He limped over. He hadn't seen the fire, but he seemed to be looking for a reason to tell them off anyway.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What's that you've got there, Potter?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: It was Quidditch Through the Ages. Harry showed him.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Library books are not to be taken outside the school," said Snape. "Give it to me. Five points from Gryffindor."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Give it to me. Five points from Gryffindor."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "He's just made that rule up," Harry muttered angrily as Snape limped away. "Wonder what's wrong with his leg?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Dunno, but I hope it's really hurting him," said Ron bitterly.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The Gryffindor common room was very noisy that evening. Harry, Ron, and Hermione sat together next to a window. Hermione was checking Harry and Ron's Charms homework for them. She would never let them copy ("How will you learn?"), but by asking her to read it through, they got the right answers anyway.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry felt restless. He wanted Quidditch Through the Ages back, to take his mind off his nerves about tomorrow. Why should he be afraid of Snape? Getting up, he told Ron and Hermione he was going to ask Snape if he could have it.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Better you than me," they said together, but Harry had an idea that Snape wouldn't refuse if there were other teachers listening.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He made his way down to the staffroom and knocked. There was no answer. He knocked again. Nothing.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Perhaps Snape had left the book in there? It was worth a try. He pushed the door ajar and peered inside -- and a horrible scene met his eyes.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Snape and Filch were inside, alone. Snape was holding his robes above his knees. One of his legs was bloody and mangled. Filch was handing Snape bandages.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Blasted thing*," Snape was saying. "How are you supposed to keep your eyes on all three heads at once?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry tried to shut the door quietly, but --

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "POTTER!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Snape's face was twisted with fury as he dropped his robes quickly to hide his leg. Harry gulped.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I just wondered if I could have my book back."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "GET OUT! OUT!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry left, before Snape could take any more points from Gryffindor. He sprinted back upstairs.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Did you get it?" Ron asked as Harry joined them. "What's the matter?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: In a low whisper, Harry told them what he'd seen.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You know what this means?" he finished breathlessly. "He tried to get past that three-headed dog at Halloween! That's where he was going when we saw him -- he's after whatever it's guarding! And Id bet my broomstick he let that troll in, to make a diversion!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hermione's eyes were wide.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "No -- he wouldn't, she said. "I know he's not very nice, but he wouldn't try and steal something Dumbledore was keeping safe."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Honestly, Hermione, you think all teachers are saints or something," snapped Ron. "I'm with Harry. I wouldn't put anything past Snape. But what's he after? What's that dog guarding?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry went to bed with his head buzzing with the same question. Neville was snoring loudly, but Harry couldn't sleep. He tried to empty his mind -- he needed to sleep, he had to, he had his first Quidditch match in a few hours -- but the expression on Snape's face when Harry had seen his leg wasn't easy to forget.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The next morning dawned very bright and cold. The Great Hall was full of the delicious smell of fried sausages and the cheer ful chatter of everyone looking forward to a good Quidditch match.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You've got to eat some breakfast."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I don't want anything."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Just a bit of toast," wheedled Hermione.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I'm not hungry."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry felt terrible. In an hour's time he'd be walking onto the field.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Harry, you need your strength," said Seamus Finnigan. "Seekers are always the ones who get clobbered by the other team."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Thanks, Seamus," said Harry, watching Seamus pile ketchup on his sausages.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: By eleven o'clock the whole school seemed to be out in the stands around the Quidditch pitch. Many students had binoculars. The seats might be raised high in the air, but it was still difficult to see what was going on sometimes.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Ron and Hermione joined Neville, Seamus, and Dean the West Ham fan up in the top row. As a surprise for Harry, they had painted a large banner on one of the sheets Scabbers had ruined. It said Potter for President, and Dean, who was good at drawing, had done a large Gryffindor lion underneath. Then Hermione had performed a tricky little charm so that the paint flashed different colors.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Meanwhile, in the locker room, Harry and the rest of the team were changing into their scarlet Quidditch robes (Slytherin would be playing in green).

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Wood cleared his throat for silence.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Okay, men," he said.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "And women," said Chaser Angelina Johnson.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "And women," Wood agreed. "This is it."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "The big one," said Fred Weasley.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "The one we've all been waiting for," said George.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "We know Oliver's speech by heart," Fred told Harry, "we were on the team last year."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Shut up, you two," said Wood. "This is the best team Gryffindor's had in years. We're going to win. I know it."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He glared at them all as if to say, "Or else."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Right. It's time. Good luck, all of you."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry followed Fred and George out of the locker room and, hoping his

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: knees weren't going to give way, walked onto the field to loud cheers.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Madam Hooch was refereeing. She stood in the middle of the field waiting for the two teams, her broom in her hand.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Now, I want a nice fair game, all of you," she said, once they were all gathered around her. Harry noticed that she seemed to be speaking particularly to the Slytherin Captain, Marcus Flint, a sixth year. Harry thought Flint looked as if he had some troll blood in him. Out of the corner of his eye he saw the fluttering banner high above, flashing Potter for President over the crowd. His heart skipped. He felt braver.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Mount your brooms, please."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry clambered onto his Nimbus Two Thousand.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Madam Hooch gave a loud blast on her silver whistle.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Fifteen brooms rose up, high, high into the air. They were off. "And the Quaffle is taken immediately by Angelina Johnson of Gryffindor -- what an excellent Chaser that girl is, and rather attractive, too --"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "JORDAN!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Sorry, Professor."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The Weasley twins' friend, Lee Jordan, was doing the commentary for the match, closely watched by Professor McGonagall.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "And she's really belting along up there, a neat pass to Alicia Spinnet, a good find of Oliver Wood's, last year only a reserve -- back to Johnson and -- no, the Slytherins have taken the Quaffle, Slytherin Captain Marcus Flint gains the Quaffle and off he goes -- Flint flying like an eagle up there -- he's going to sc- no, stopped by an excellent move by Gryffindor Keeper Wood and the Gryffindors take the Quaffle -- that's Chaser Katie Bell of Gryffindor there, nice dive around Flint, off up the field and -- OUCH -- that must have hurt, hit in the back of the head by a Bludger -- Quaffle taken by the Slytherins -- that's Adrian Pucey speeding off toward the goal posts, but he's blocked by a second Bludger -- sent his way by Fred or George Weasley, can't tell which -- nice play by the Gryffindor Beater, anyway, and Johnson back in possession of the Quaffle, a clear field ahead and off she goes -- she's really flying -- dodges a speeding Bludger -- the goal posts are ahead

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: -- come on, now, Angelina -- Keeper Bletchley dives -- misses -- GRYFFINDORS SCORE!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Gryffindor cheers filled the cold air, with howls and moans from the Slytherins.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Budge up there, move along."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Hagrid!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Ron and Hermione squeezed together to give Hagrid enough space to join them.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Bin watchin' from me hut," said Hagrid, patting a large pair of binoculars around his neck, "But it isn't the same as bein' in the crowd. No sign of the Snitch yet, eh?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Nope," said Ron. "Harry hasn't had much to do yet."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Kept outta trouble, though, that's somethin'," said Hagrid, raising his binoculars and peering skyward at the speck that was Harry.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Way up above them, Harry was gliding over the game, squinting about for some sign of the Snitch. This was part of his and Wood's game plan.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Keep out of the way until you catch sight of the Snitch," Wood had said. "We don't want you attacked before you have to be."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: When Angelina had scored, Harry had done a couple of loop-the-loops to let off his feelings. Now he was back to staring around for the Snitch. Once he caught sight of a flash of gold, but it was just a reflection from one of the Weasleys' wristwatches, and once a Bludger decided to come pelting his way, more like a cannonball than anything, but Harry dodged it and Fred Weasley came chasing after it.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "All right there, Harry?" he had time to yell, as he beat the Bludger furiously toward Marcus Flint.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Slytherin in possession," Lee Jordan was saying, "Chaser Pucey ducks two Bludgers, two Weasleys, and Chaser Bell, and speeds toward the -- wait a moment -- was that the Snitch?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: A murmur ran through the crowd as Adrian Pucey dropped the Quaffle, too

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: busy looking over his shoulder at the flash of gold that had passed his left ear.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry saw it. In a great rush of excitement he dived downward after the streak of gold. Slytherin Seeker Terence Higgs had seen it, too. Neck and neck they hurtled toward the Snitch -all the Chasers seemed to have forgotten what they were supposed to be doing as they hung in midair to watch.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry was faster than Higgs -- he could see the little round ball, wings fluttering, darting up ahead - - he put on an extra spurt of speed --

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: WHAM! A roar of rage echoed from the Gryffindors below -- Marcus Flint had blocked Harry on purpose, and Harry's broom spun off course, Harry holding on for dear life.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Foul!" screamed the Gryffindors.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Madam Hooch spoke angrily to Flint and then ordered a free shot at the goal posts for Gryffindor. But in all the confusion, of course, the Golden Snitch had disappeared from sight again.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Down in the stands, Dean Thomas was yelling, "Send him off, ref! Red card!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What are you talking about, Dean?" said Ron.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Red card!" said Dean furiously. "In soccer you get shown the red card and you're out of the game!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "But this isn't soccer, Dean," Ron reminded him.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hagrid, however, was on Dean's side.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "They oughta change the rules. Flint coulda knocked Harry outta the air."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Lee Jordan was finding it difficult not to take sides.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "So -- after that obvious and disgusting bit of cheating

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Jordan!" growled Professor McGonagall.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I mean, after that open and revolting foul

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: 'Jordan, I'm warning you --"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "All right, all right. Flint nearly kills the Gryffindor Seeker, which could happen to anyone, I'm sure, so a penalty to Gryffindor, taken by Spinner, who puts it away, no trouble, and we continue play, Gryffindor still in possession."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: It was as Harry dodged another Bludger, which went spinning dangerously past his head, that it happened. His broom gave a sudden, frightening lurch. For a split second, he thought he was going to fall. He gripped the broom tightly with both his hands and knees. He'd never felt anything like that.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
