text: It happened again. It was as though the broom was trying to buck him off. But Nimbus Two Thousands did not suddenly decide to buck their riders off. Harry tried to turn back toward the Gryffindor goal- posts -- he had half a mind to ask Wood to call time-out -- and then he realized that his broom was completely out of his control. He couldn't turn it. He couldn't direct it at all. It was zigzagging through the air, and every now and then making violent swishing movements that almost unseated him.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Lee was still commentating.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Slytherin in possession -- Flint with the Quaffle -- passes Spinnet -- passes Bell -- hit hard in the face by a Bludger, hope it broke his nose -- only joking, Professor -- Slytherins score -- A no...

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The Slytherins were cheering. No one seemed to have noticed that Harry's broom was behaving strangely. It was carrying- him slowly higher, away from the game, jerking and twitching as it went.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Dunno what Harry thinks he's doing," Hagrid mumbled. He stared through his binoculars. "If I didn' know better, I'd say he'd lost control of his broom... but he can't have...."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Suddenly, people were pointing up at Harry all over the stands. His broom had started to roll over and over, with him only just managing to hold on. Then the whole crowd gasped. Harry's broom had given a wild jerk and Harry swung off it. He was now dangling from it, holding on with only one hand.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Did something happen to it when Flint blocked him?" Seamus whispered.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Can't have," Hagrid said, his voice shaking. "Can't nothing interfere with a broomstick except powerful Dark magic -- no kid could do that to a Nimbus Two Thousand."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: At these words, Hermione seized Hagrid's binoculars, but instead of looking up at Harry, she started looking frantically at the crowd.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What are you doing?" moaned Ron, gray-faced.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I knew it," Hermione gasped, "Snape -- look."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Ron grabbed the binoculars. Snape was in the middle of the stands opposite them. He had his eyes fixed on Harry and was muttering nonstop under his breath.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "He's doing something -- jinxing the broom," said Hermione.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What should we do?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Leave it to me."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Before Ron could say another word, Hermione had disappeared. Ron turned the binoculars back on Harry. His broom was vibrating so hard, it was almost impossible for him to hang on much longer. The whole crowd was on its feet, watching, terrified, as the Weasleys flew up to try and pull Harry safely onto one of their brooms, but it was no good -- every time they got near him, the broom would jump higher still. They dropped lower and circled beneath him, obviously hoping to catch him if he fell. Marcus

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Flint seized the Quaffle and scored five times without anyone noticing.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Come on, Hermione," Ron muttered desperately.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hermione had fought her way across to the stand where Snape stood, and was now racing along the row behind him; she didn't even stop to say sorry as she knocked Professor Quirrell headfirst into the row in front. Reaching Snape, she crouched down, pulled out her wand, and whispered a few, well- chosen words. Bright blue flames shot from her wand onto the hem of Snape's robes.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: It took perhaps thirty seconds for Snape to realize that he was on fire. A sudden yelp told her she had done her job. Scooping the fire off him into a little jar in her pocket, she scrambled back along the row -- Snape would never know what had happened.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: It was enough. Up in the air, Harry was suddenly able to clamber back on to his broom.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Neville, you can look!" Ron said. Neville had been sobbing into Hagrid's jacket for the last five minutes.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry was speeding toward the ground when the crowd saw him clap his hand to his mouth as though he was about to be sick -- he hit the field on all fours -- coughed -- and something gold fell into his hand.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I've got the Snitch!" he shouted, waving it above his head, and the game ended in complete confusion.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "He didn't catch it, he nearly swallowed it," Flint was still howling twenty minutes later, but it made no difference -- Harry hadn't broken any rules and Lee Jordan was still happily shouting the results -- Gryffindor had won by one hundred and seventy points to sixty. Harry heard none of this, though. He was being made a cup of strong tea back in Hagrid's hut, with Ron and Hermione.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "It was Snape," Ron was explaining, "Hermione and I saw him. He was cursing your broomstick, muttering, he wouldn't take his eyes off you."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Rubbish," said Hagrid, who hadn't heard a word of what had gone on next to him in the stands. "Why would Snape do somethin' like that?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry, Ron, and Hermione looked at one another, wondering what to tell him. Harry decided on the truth.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I found out something about him," he told Hagrid. "He tried to get past that three-headed dog on Halloween. It bit him. We think he was trying to steal whatever it's guarding."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hagrid dropped the teapot.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "How do you know about Fluffy?" he said.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Fluffy?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Yeah -- he's mine -- bought him off a Greek chappie I met in the pub las' year -- I lent him to Dumbledore to guard the

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Yes?" said Harry eagerly.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Now, don't ask me anymore," said Hagrid gruffly. "That's top secret, that is."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "But Snape's trying to steal it."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Rubbish," said Hagrid again. "Snape's a Hogwarts teacher, he'd do nothin' of the sort."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "So why did he just try and kill Harry?" cried Hermione.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The afternoon's events certainly seemed to have changed her mind about Snape.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: I know a jinx when I see one, Hagrid, I've read all about them!

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: You've got to keep eye contact, and Snape wasn't blinking at all, I saw him!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I'm tellin' yeh, yer wrong!" said Hagrid hotly. "I don' know why Harry's broom acted like that, but Snape wouldn' try an' kill a student! Now, listen to me, all three of yeh -- yer meddlin' in things that don' concern yeh. It's dangerous. You forget that dog, an' you forget what it's guardin', that's between Professor Dumbledore an' Nicolas Flamel --"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Aha!" said Harry, "so there's someone called Nicolas Flamel involved, is there?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hagrid looked furious with himself.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: CHAPTER TWELVE

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: THE MIRROR OF ERISED

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Christmas was coming. One morning in mid-December, Hogwarts woke to find

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: itself covered in several feet of snow. The lake froze solid and the Weasley twins were punished for bewitching several snowballs so that they followed Quirrell around, bouncing off the back of his turban. The few owls that managed to battle their way through the stormy sky to deliver mail had to be nursed back to health by Hagrid before they could fly off again.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: No one could wait for the holidays to start. While the Gryffindor common room and the Great Hall had roaring fires, the drafty corridors had become icy and a bitter wind rattled the windows in the classrooms. Worst of all were Professor Snape's classes down in the dungeons, where their breath rose in a mist before them and they kept as close as possible to their hot cauldrons.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I do feel so sorry," said Draco Malfoy, one Potions class, "for all those people who have to stay at Hogwarts for Christmas because they're not wanted at home."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He was looking over at Harry as he spoke. Crabbe and Goyle chuckled. Harry, who was measuring out powdered spine of lionfish, ignored them. Malfoy had been even more unpleasant than usual since the Quidditch match. Disgusted that the Slytherins had lost, he had tried to get everyone laughing at how a wide-mouthed tree frog would be replacing Harry as Seeker next. Then he'd realized that nobody found this funny, because they were all so impressed at the way Harry had managed to stay on his bucking broomstick. So Malfoy, jealous and angry, had gone back to taunting Harry about having no proper family.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: It was true that Harry wasn't going back to Privet Drive for Christmas. Professor McGonagall had come around the week before, making a list of students who would be staying for the holidays, and Harry had signed up at once. He didn't feel sorry for himself at all; this would probably be the best Christmas he'd ever had. Ron and his brothers were staying, too, because Mr. and Mrs. Weasley were going to Romania to visit Charlie.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: When they left the dungeons at the end of Potions, they found a large fir tree blocking the corridor ahead. Two enormous feet sticking out at the bottom and a loud puffing sound told them that Hagrid was behind it.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Hi, Hagrid, want any help?" Ron asked, sticking his head through the branches.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Nah, I'm all right, thanks, Ron."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Would you mind moving out of the way?" came Malfoys cold drawl from behind them. "Are you trying to earn some extra money, Weasley? Hoping to be gamekeeper yourself when you leave Hogwarts, I suppose -- that hut of Hagrid's must seem like a palace compared to what your family's used to."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Ron dived at Malfoy just as Snape came up the stairs.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "WEASLEY!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Ron let go of the front of Malfoy's robes.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "He was provoked, Professor Snape," said Hagrid, sticking his huge hairy face out from behind the tree. "Malfoy was insultin' his family."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Be that as it may, fighting is against Hogwarts rules, Hagrid," said Snape silkily. "Five points from Gryffindor, Weasley, and be grateful it isn't more. Move along, all of you."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Malfoy, Crabbe, and Goyle pushed roughly past the tree, scattering needles everywhere and smirking.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I'll get him," said Ron, grinding his teeth at Malfoy's back, "one of these days, I'll get him --"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I hate them both," said Harry, "Malfoy and Snape."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Come on, cheer up, it's nearly Christmas," said Hagrid. "Tell yeh what, come with me an' see the Great Hall, looks a treat."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: So the three of them followed Hagrid and his tree off to -the Great Hall, where Professor McGonagall and Professor Flitwick were busy with the Christmas decorations.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Ah, Hagrid, the last tree -- put it in the far corner, would you?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The hall looked spectacular. Festoons of holly and mistletoe hung all around the walls, and no less than twelve towering Christmas trees stood around the room, some sparkling with tiny icicles, some glittering with hundreds of candles.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "How many days you got left until yer holidays?" Hagrid asked.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Just one," said Hermione. "And that reminds me -Harry, Ron, we've got half an hour before lunch, we should be in the library."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Oh yeah, you're right," said Ron, tearing his eyes away from Professor Flitwick, who had golden bubbles blossoming out of his wand and was trailing them over the branches of the new tree.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "The library?" said Hagrid, following them out of the hall. "Just before the holidays? Bit keen, aren't yeh?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Oh, we're not working," Harry told him brightly. "Ever since you mentioned Nicolas Flamel we've been trying to find out who he is."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You what?" Hagrid looked shocked. "Listen here -- I've told yeh -- drop it. It's nothin' to you what that dog's guardin'."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "We just want to know who Nicolas Flamel is, that's all," said Hermione.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Unless you'd like to tell us and save us the trouble?" Harry added. "We must've been through hundreds of books already and we can't find him anywhere -- just give us a hint -- I know I've read his name somewhere."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I'm sayin' nothin, said Hagrid flatly.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Just have to find out for ourselves, then," said Ron, and they left Hagrid looking disgruntled and hurried off to the library.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: They had indeed been searching books for Flamel's name ever since Hagrid had let it slip, because how else were they going to find out what Snape was trying to steal? The trouble was, it was very hard to know where to begin, not knowing what Flamel might have done to get himself into a book. He wasn't in Great Wizards of the Twentieth Century, or Notable Magical Names of Our Time; he was missing, too, from Important Modern Magical Discoveries, and A Study of Recent Developments in Wizardry. And then, of course, there was the sheer size of the library; tens of thousands of books; thousands of shelves; hundreds of narrow rows.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hermione took out a list of subjects and titles she had decided to search while Ron strode off down a row of books and started pulling them off the shelves at random. Harry wandered over to the Restricted Section. He had been wondering for a while if Flamel wasn't somewhere in

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: there. Unfortunately, you needed a specially signed note from one of the teachers to look in any of the restricted books, and he knew he'd never get one. These were the books containing powerful Dark Magic never taught at Hogwarts, and only read by older students studying advanced Defense Against the Dark Arts.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What are you looking for, boy?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Nothing," said Harry.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Madam Pince the librarian brandished a feather duster at him.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You'd better get out, then. Go on -- out!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Wishing he'd been a bit quicker at thinking up some story, Harry left the library. He, Ron, and Hermione had already agreed they'd better not ask Madam Pince where they could find Flamel. They were sure she'd be able to tell them, but they couldn't risk Snape hearing what they were up to.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry waited outside in the corridor to see if the other two had found anything, but he wasn't very hopeful. They had been looking for two weeks, after A, but as they only had odd moments between lessons it wasn't surprising they'd found nothing. What they really needed was a nice long search without Madam Pince breathing down their necks.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Five minutes later, Ron and Hermione joined him, shaking their heads. They went off to lunch.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You will keep looking while I'm away, won't you?" said Hermione. "And send me an owl if you find anything."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "And you could ask your parents if they know who Flamel is," said Ron. "It'd be safe to ask them."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Very safe, as they're both dentists," said Hermione.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Once the holidays had started, Ron and Harry were having too good a time to think much about Flamel. They had the dormitory to themselves and the common room was far emptier than usual, so they were able to get the good armchairs by the fire. They sat by the hour eating anything they could spear on a toasting fork -- bread, English muffins, marshmallows -- and plotting ways of getting Malfoy expelled, which were fun to talk

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: about even if they wouldn't work.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Ron also started teaching Harry wizard chess. This was exactly like Muggle chess except that the figures were alive, which made it a lot like directing troops in battle. Ron's set was very old and battered. Like everything else he owned, it had once belonged to someone else in his family -- in this case, his grandfather. However, old chessmen weren't a drawback at all. Ron knew them so well he never had trouble getting them to do what he wanted.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry played with chessmen Seamus Finnigan had lent him, and they didn't trust him at all. He wasn't a very good player yet and they kept shouting different bits of advice at him, which was confusing. "Don't send me there, can't you see his knight? Send him, we can afford to lose him." On Christmas Eve, Harry went to bed looking forward to the next day for the food and the fun, but not expecting any presents at all. When he woke early in the morning, however, the first thing he saw was a small pile of packages at the foot of his bed.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Merry Christmas," said Ron sleepily as Harry scrambled out of bed and pulled on his bathrobe.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You, too," said Harry. "Will you look at this? I've got some presents!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What did you expect, turnips?" said Ron, turning to his own pile, which was a lot bigger than Harry's.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry picked up the top parcel. It was wrapped in thick brown paper and scrawled across it was To Harry, from Hagrid. Inside was a roughly cut wooden flute. Hagrid had obviously whittled it himself. Harry blew it -- it sounded a bit like an owl.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: A second, very small parcel contained a note.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: We received your message and enclose your Christmas present. From Uncle Vernon and Aunt Petunia. Taped to the note was a fifty-pence piece.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "That's friendly," said Harry.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Ron was fascinated by the fifty pence.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Weird!" he said, 'NMat a shape! This is money?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You can keep it," said Harry, laughing at how pleased Ron was. "Hagrid and my aunt and uncle -- so who sent these?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I think I know who that one's from," said Ron, turning a bit pink and pointing to a very lumpy parcel. "My mom. I told her you didn't expect any presents and -- oh, no," he groaned, "she's made you a Weasley sweater."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry had torn open the parcel to find a thick, hand-knitted sweater in emerald green and a large box of homemade fudge.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Every year she makes us a sweater," said Ron, unwrapping his own, "and mine's always maroon."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "That's really nice of her," said Harry, trying the fudge, which was very tasty.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: His next present also contained candy -- a large box of Chocolate Frogs from Hermione.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: This only left one parcel. Harry picked it up and felt it. It was very light. He unwrapped it.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Something fluid and silvery gray went slithering to the floor where it lay in gleaming folds. Ron gasped.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I've heard of those," he said in a hushed voice, dropping the box of Every Flavor Beans he'd gotten from Hermione. "If that's what I think it is -- they're really rare, and really valuable."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What is it?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry picked the shining, silvery cloth off the floor. It was strange to the touch, like water woven into material.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "It's an invisibility cloak," said Ron, a look of awe on his face. "I'm sure it is -- try it on."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry threw the cloak around his shoulders and Ron gave a yell.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "It is! Look down!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry looked down at his feet, but they were gone. He dashed to the

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: mirror. Sure enough, his reflection looked back at him, just his head suspended in midair, his body completely invisible. He pulled the cloak over his head and his reflection vanished completely.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "There's a note!" said Ron suddenly. "A note fell out of it!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry pulled off the cloak and seized the letter. Written in narrow, loopy writing he had never seen before were the following words: Your father left this in my possession before he died. It is time it was returned to you. Use it well.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: A Very Merry Christmas to you.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: There was no signature. Harry stared at the note. Ron was admiring the cloak.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I'd give anything for one of these," he said. "Anything. What's the matter?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Nothing," said Harry. He felt very strange. Who had sent the cloak? Had it really once belonged to his father?

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Before he could say or think anything else, the dormitory door was flung open and Fred and George Weasley bounded in. Harry stuffed the cloak quickly out of sight. He didn't feel like sharing it with anyone else yet.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Merry Christmas!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Hey, look -- Harry's got a Weasley sweater, too!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Fred and George were wearing blue sweaters, one with a large yellow F on it, the other a G.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Harry's is better than ours, though," said Fred, holding up Harry's sweater. "She obviously makes more of an effort if you're not family."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Why aren't you wearing yours, Ron?" George demanded. "Come on, get it on, they're lovely and warm."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I hate maroon," Ron moaned halfheartedly as he pulled it over his head.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You haven't got a letter on yours," George observed. "I suppose she thinks you don't forget your name. But we're not stupid -- we know we're called Gred and Forge."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What's all th is noise.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Percy Weasley stuck his head through the door, looking disapproving. He had clearly gotten halfway through unwrapping his presents as he, too, carried a lumpy sweater over his arm, which

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Fred seized.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "P for prefect! Get it on, Percy, come on, we're all wearing ours, even Harry got one."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I -- don't -- want said Percy thickly, as the twins forced the sweater over his head, knocking his glasses askew.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "And you're not sitting with the prefects today, either," said

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: George. "Christmas is a time for family."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: They frog-marched Percy from the room, his arms pinned to his side by his sweater.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry had never in all his life had such a Christmas dinner. A hundred fat, roast turkeys; mountains of roast and boiled potatoes; platters of chipolatas; tureens of buttered peas, silver boats of thick, rich gravy and cranberry sauce -- and stacks of wizard crackers every few feet along the table. These fantastic party favors were nothing like the feeble Muggle ones the Dursleys usually bought, with their little plastic toys and their flimsy paper hats inside. Harry pulled a wizard cracker with Fred and it didn't just bang, it went off with a blast like a cannon and engulfed them all in a cloud of blue smoke, while from the inside exploded a rear admiral's hat and several live, white mice. Up at the High Table, Dumbledore had swapped his pointed wizard's hat for a flowered bonnet, and was chuckling merrily at a joke Professor Flitwick had just read him.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Flaming Christmas puddings followed the turkey. Percy nearly broke his teeth on a silver sickle embedded in his slice. Harry watched Hagrid getting redder and redder in the face as he called for more wine, finally kissing Professor McGonagall on the cheek, who, to Harry's

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: amazement, giggled and blushed, her top hat lopsided.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: When Harry finally left the table, he was laden down with a stack of things out of the crackers, including a pack of nonexplodable, luminous balloons, a Grow-Your-Own-Warts kit, and his own new wizard chess set. The white mice had disappeared and Harry had a nasty feeling they were going to end up as Mrs. Norris's Christmas dinner.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry and the Weasleys spent a happy afternoon having a furious snowball fight on the grounds. Then, cold, wet, and gasping for breath, they returned to the fire in the Gryffindor common room, where Harry broke in his new chess set by losing spectacularly to Ron. He suspected he wouldn't have lost so badly if Percy hadn't tried to help him so much.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: After a meal of turkey sandwiches, crumpets, trifle, and Christmas cake, everyone felt too full and sleepy to do much before bed except sit and watch Percy chase Fred and George all over Gryffindor tower because they'd stolen his prefect badge.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: It had been Harry's best Christmas day ever. Yet something had been nagging at the back of his mind all day. Not until he climbed into bed was he free to think about it: the invisibility cloak and whoever had sent it.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Ron, full of turkey and cake and with nothing mysterious to bother him, fell asleep almost as soon as he'd drawn the curtains of his four-poster. Harry leaned over the side of his own bed and pulled the cloak out from under it.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: His father's... this had been his father's. He let the material flow over his hands, smoother than silk, light as air. Use it well, the note had said.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He had to try it, now. He slipped out of bed and wrapped the cloak around himself. Looking down at his legs, he saw only moonlight and shadows. It was a very funny feeling.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Use it well.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Suddenly, Harry felt wide-awake. The whole of Hogwarts was open to him in this cloak. Excitement flooded through him as he stood there in the dark and silence. He could go anywhere in this, anywhere, and Filch would never know.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Ron grunted in his sleep. Should Harry wake him? Something held him back -- his father's cloak -- he felt that this time -- the first time -- he wanted to use it alone.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He crept out of the dormitory, down the stairs, across the common room, and climbed through the portrait hole.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Who's there?" squawked the Fat Lady. Harry said nothing. He walked quickly down the corridor.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Where should he go? He stopped, his heart racing, and thought. And then it came to him. The Restricted Section in the library. He'd be able to read as long as he liked, as long as it took to find out who Flamel was. He set off, drawing the invisibility cloak tight around him as he walked.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The library was pitch-black and very eerie. Harry lit a lamp to see his way along the rows of books. The lamp looked as if it was floating along in midair, and even though Harry could feel his arm supporting it, the sight gave him the creeps.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The Restricted Section was right at the back of the library. Step ping carefully over the rope that separated these books from the rest of the library, he held up his lamp to read the titles.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: They didn't tell him much. Their peeling, faded gold letters spelled words in languages Harry couldn't understand. Some had no title at all. One book had a dark stain on it that looked horribly like blood. The hairs on the back of Harry's neck prickled. Maybe he was imagining it, maybe not, but he thought a faint whispering was coming from the books, as though they knew someone was there who shouldn't be.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He had to start somewhere. Setting the lamp down carefully on the floor, he looked along the bottom shelf for an interestinglooking book. A large black and silver volume caught his eye. He pulled it out with difficulty, because it was very heavy, and, balancing it on his knee, let it fall open.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: A piercing, bloodcurdling shriek split the silence -- the book was screaming! Harry snapped it shut, but the shriek went on and on, one high, unbroken, earsplitting note. He stumbled backward and knocked over his lamp, which went out at once. Panicking, he heard footsteps coming

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: down the corridor outside -- stuffing the shrieking book back on the shelf, he ran for it. He passed Filch in the doorway; Filch's pale, wild eyes looked straight through him, and Harry slipped under Filch's outstretched arm and streaked off up the corridor, the book's shrieks still ringing in his ears.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He came to a sudden halt in front of a tall suit of armor. He had been so busy getting away from the library, he hadn't paid attention to where he was going. Perhaps because it was dark, he didn't recognize where he was at all. There was a suit of armor near the kitchens, he knew, but he must be five floors above there.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You asked me to come directly to you, Professor, if anyone was wandering around at night, and somebody's been in the library Restricted Section."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry felt the blood drain out of his face. Wherever he was, Filch must know a shortcut, because his soft, greasy voice was getting nearer, and to his horror, it was Snape who replied, "The Restricted Section? Well, they can't be far, we'll catch them."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry stood rooted to the spot as Filch and Snape came around the corner ahead. They couldn't see him, of course, but it was a narrow corridor and if they came much nearer they'd knock right into him -- the cloak didn't stop him from being solid.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He backed away as quietly as he could. A door stood ajar to his left. It was his only hope. He squeezed through it, holding his breath, trying not to move it, and to his relief he managed to get inside the room without their noticing anything. They walked straight past, and Harry leaned against the wall, breathing deeply, listening to their footsteps dying away. That had been close, very close. It was a few seconds before he noticed anything about the room he had hidden in.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: It looked like an unused classroom. The dark shapes of desks and chairs were piled against the walls, and there was an upturned wastepaper basket -- but propped against the wall facing him was something that didn't look as if it belonged there, something that looked as if someone had just put it there to keep it out of the way.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: It was a magnificent mirror, as high as the ceiling, with an ornate gold frame, standing on two clawed feet. There was an inscription carved around the top: Erised stra ehru oyt ube cafru oyt on wohsi. His panic

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: fading now that there was no sound of Filch and Snape, Harry moved nearer to the mirror, wanting to look at himself but see no reflection again. He stepped in front of it.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He had to clap his hands to his mouth to stop himself from screaming. He whirled around. His heart was pounding far more furiously than when the book had screamed -- for he had seen not only himself in the mirror, but a whole crowd of people standing right behind him.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: But the room was empty. Breathing very fast, he turned slowly back to the mirror.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: There he was, reflected in it, white and scared-looking, and there, reflected behind him, were at least ten others. Harry looked over his shoulder -- but still, no one was there. Or were they all invisible, too? Was he in fact in a room full of invisible people and this mirror's trick was that it reflected them, invisible or not?

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He looked in the mirror again. A woman standing right behind his reflection was smiling at him and waving. He reached out a hand and felt the air behind him. If she was really there, he'd touch her, their reflections were so close together, but he felt only air -- she and the others existed only in the mirror.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: She was a very pretty woman. She had dark red hair and her eyes -- her eyes are just like mine, Harry thought, edging a little closer to the glass. Bright green -- exactly the same shape, but then he noticed that she was crying; smiling, but crying at the same time. The tall, thin, black-haired man standing next to her put his arm around her. He wore glasses, and his hair was very untidy. It stuck up at the back, just as Harry's did.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry was so close to the mirror now that his nose was nearly touching that of his reflection.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Mom?" he whispered. "Dad?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: They just looked at him, smiling. And slowly, Harry looked into the faces of the other people in the mirror, and saw other pairs of green eyes like his, other noses like his, even a little old man who looked as though he had Harry's knobbly knees -- Harry was looking at his family, for the first time in his life.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The Potters smiled and waved at Harry and he stared hungrily back at them, his hands pressed flat against the glass as though he was hoping to fall right through it and reach them. He had a powerful kind of ache inside him, half joy, half terrible sadness.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: How long he stood there, he didn't know. The reflections did not fade and he looked and looked until a distant noise brought him back to his senses. He couldn't stay here, he had to find his way back to bed. He tore his eyes away from his mother's face, whispered, "I'll come back," and hurried from the room.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You could have woken me up," said Ron, crossly.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You can come tonight, I'm going back, I want to show you the mirror.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I'd like to see your mom and dad," Ron said eagerly.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "And I want to see all your family, all the Weasleys, you'll be able to show me your other brothers and everyone."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You can see them any old time," said Ron. "Just come round my house this summer. Anyway, maybe it only shows dead people. Shame about not finding Flamel, though. Have some bacon or something, why aren't you eating anything?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry couldn't eat. He had seen his parents and would be seeing them again tonight. He had almost forgotten about Flamel. It didn't seem very important anymore. Who cared what the three headed dog was guarding? What did it matter if Snape stole it, really?

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Are you all right?" said Ron. "You look odd."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: What Harry feared most was that he might not be able to find the mirror room again. With Ron covered in the cloak, too, they had to walk much more slowly the next night. They tried retracing Harry's route from the library, wandering around the dark passageways for nearly an hour.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I'm freezing," said Ron. "Let's forget it and go back."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "No!" Harry hissed. I know it's here somewhere."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: They passed the ghost of a tall witch gliding in the opposite direction, but saw no one else. just as Ron started moaning that his feet were dead

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: with cold, Harry spotted the suit of armor.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "It's here -- just here -- yes!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: They pushed the door open. Harry dropped the cloak from around his shoulders and ran to the mirror.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: There they were. His mother and father beamed at the sight of him.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "See?" Harry whispered.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I can't see anything."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Look! Look at them all... there are loads of them...."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I can only see you."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Look in it properly, go on, stand where I am."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry stepped aside, but with Ron in front of the mirror, he couldn't see his family anymore, just Ron in his paisley pajamas.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Ron, though, was staring transfixed at his image.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Look at me!" he said.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Can you see all your family standing around you?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "No -- I'm alone -- but I'm different -- I look older -- and I'm head boy!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I am -- I'm wearing the badge like Bill used to -- and I'm holding the house cup and the Quidditch cup -- I'm Quidditch captain, too.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Ron tore his eyes away from this splendid sight to look excitedly at Harry.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Do you think this mirror shows the future?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "How can it? All my family are dead -- let me have another look --"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You had it to yourself all last night, give me a bit more time."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You're only holding the Quidditch cup, what's interesting about that? I want to see my parents."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Don't push me --"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: A sudden noise outside in the corridor put an end to their discussion. They hadn't realized how loudly they had been talking.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Quick!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Ron threw the cloak back over them as the luminous eyes of Mrs. Norris came round the door. Ron and Harry stood quite still, both thinking the same thing -- did the cloak work on cats? After what seemed an age, she turned and left.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "This isn't safe -- she might have gone for Filch, I bet she heard us. Come on."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: And Ron pulled Harry out of the room.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The snow still hadn't melted the next morning.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Want to play chess, Harry?" said Ron.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "No."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Why don't we go down and visit Hagrid?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "No... you go..."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I know what you're thinking about, Harry, that mirror. Don't go back tonight."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Why not?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I dunno, I've just got a bad feeling about it -- and anyway, you've had too many close shaves already. Filch, Snape, and Mrs. Norris are wandering around. So what if they can't see you? What if they walk into you? What if you knock something over?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You sound like Hermione."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I'm serious, Harry, don't go."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: But Harry only had one thought in his head, which was to get back in front of the mirror, and Ron wasn't going to stop him.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: That third night he found his way more quickly than before. He was walking so fast he knew he was making more noise than was wise, but he didn't meet anyone.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: And there were his mother and father smiling at him again, and one of his grandfathers nodding happily. Harry sank down to sit on the floor in front of the mirror. There was nothing to stop him from staying here all night with his family. Nothing at all.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Except --

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "So -- back again, Harry?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry felt as though his insides had turned to ice. He looked behind him. Sitting on one of the desks by the wall was none other than Albus Dumbledore. Harry must have walked straight past him, so desperate to get to the mirror he hadn't noticed him.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: " -- I didn't see you, sir."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Strange how nearsighted being invisible can make you," said Dumbledore, and Harry was relieved to see that he was smiling.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "So," said Dumbledore, slipping off the desk to sit on the floor with Harry, "you, like hundreds before you, have discovered the delights of the Mirror of Erised."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I didn't know it was called that, Sir."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "But I expect you've realized by now what it does?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "It -- well -- it shows me my family --"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "And it showed your friend Ron himself as head boy."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "How did you know --?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I don't need a cloak to become invisible," said Dumbledore gently. "Now, can you think what the Mirror of Erised shows us all?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry shook his head.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Let me explain. The happiest man on earth would be able to use the Mirror of Erised like a normal mirror, that is, he would look into it and see himself exactly as he is. Does that help?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry thought. Then he said slowly, "It shows us what we want... whatever we want..."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Yes and no," said Dumbledore quietly. "It shows us nothing more or less than the deepest, most desperate desire of our hearts. You, who have never known your family, see them standing around you. Ronald Weasley, who has always been overshadowed by his brothers, sees himself standing alone, the best of all of them. However, this mirror will give us neither knowledge or truth. Men have wasted away before it, entranced by what they have seen, or been driven mad, not knowing if what it shows is real or even possible.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "The Mirror will be moved to a new home tomorrow, Harry, and I ask you not to go looking for it again. If you ever do run across it, you will now be prepared. It does not do to dwell on dreams and forget to live, remember that. Now, why don't you put that admirable cloak back on and get off to bed?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry stood up.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Sir -- Professor Dumbledore? Can I ask you something?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Obviously, you've just done so," Dumbledore smiled. "You may ask me one more thing, however."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What do you see when you look in the mirror?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I? I see myself holding a pair of thick, woolen socks."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry stared.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "One can never have enough socks," said Dumbledore. "Another Christmas has come and gone and I didn't get a single pair. People will insist on giving me books."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: It was only when he was back in bed that it struck Harry that Dumbledore might not have been quite truthful. But then, he thought, as he shoved Scabbers off his pillow, it had been quite a personal question.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: CHAPTER THIRTEEN

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: NICOLAS FLAMEL

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Dumbledore had convinced Harry not to go looking for the Mirror of Erised again, and for the rest of the Christmas holidays the invisibility cloak stayed folded at the bottom of his trunk. Harry wished he could forget what he'd seen in the mirror as easily, but he couldn't. He started having nightmares. Over and over again he dreamed about his parents disappearing in a flash of green light, while a high voice cackled with laughter.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You see, Dumbledore was right, that mirror could drive you mad," said Ron, when Harry told him about these drearns.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hermione, who came back the day before term started, took a different view of things. She was torn between horror at the idea of Harry being out of bed, roaming the school three nights in a row ("If Filch had caught you!"), and disappointment that he hadn't at least found out who Nicolas Flamel was.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: They had almost given up hope of ever finding Flamel in a li- brary book, even though Harry was still sure he'd read the name somewhere. Once term had started, they were back to skimming through books for ten minutes during their breaks. Harry had even less time than the other two, because Quidditch practice had started again.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Wood was working the team harder than ever. Even the endless rain that had replaced the snow couldn't dampen his spirits. The Weasleys complained that Wood was becoming a fanatic, but Harry was on Wood's side. If they won their next match, against Hufflepuff, they would overtake Slytherin in the house championship for the first time in seven years. Quite apart from wanting to win, Harry found that he had fewer nightmares when he was tired out after training.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Then, during one particularly wet and muddy practice session, Wood gave the team a bit of bad news. He'd just gotten very angry with the

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Weasleys, who kept dive-bombing each other and pretending to fall off their brooms.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Will you stop messing around!" he yelled. "That's exactly the sort of thing that'll lose us the match! Snape's refereeing this time, and he'll be looking for any excuse to knock points off Gryffindor!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: George Weasley really did fall off his broom at these words.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Snape's refereeing?" he spluttered through a mouthful of mud. "When's he ever refereed a Quidditch match? He's not going to be fair if we might overtake Slytherin."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The rest of the team landed next to George to complain, too.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "It's not my fault," said Wood. "We've just got to make sure we play a clean game, so Snape hasn't got an excuse to pick on us."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Which was all very well, thought Harry, but he had another reason for not wanting Snape near him while he was playing Quidditch....

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The rest of the team hung back to talk to one another as usual at the end of practice, but Harry headed straight back to the Gryffindor common room, where he found Ron and Hermione playing chess. Chess was the only thing Hermione ever lost at, something Harry and Ron thought was very good for her.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Don't talk to me for a moment," said Ron when Harry sat down next to him, "I need to concen --" He caught sight of Harry's face. "What's the matter with you? You look terrible."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Speaking quietly so that no one else would hear, Harry told the other two about Snape's sudden, sinister desire to be a Quidditch referee.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Don't play," said Hermione at once.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Say you're ill," said Ron.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Pretend to break your leg," Hermione suggested.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Really break your leg," said Ron.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I can't," said Harry. "There isn't a reserve Seeker. If I back out,

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Gryffindor can't play at all."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: At that moment Neville toppled into the common room. How he had managed to climb through the portrait hole was anyone's guess, because his legs had been stuck together with what they recognized at once as the Leg-Locker Curse. He must have had to bunny hop all the way up to Gryffindor tower.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Everyone fell over laughing except Hermione, who leapt up and performed the countercurse. Neville's legs sprang apart and he got to his feet, trembling. "What happened?" Hermione asked him, leading him over to sit with Harry and Ron.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Malfoy," said Neville shakily. "I met him outside the library. He said he'd been looking for someone to practice that on."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Go to Professor McGonagall!" Hermione urged Neville. "Report him!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Neville shook his head.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I don't want more trouble," he mumbled.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You've got to stand up to him, Neville!" said Ron. "He's used to walking all over people, but that's no reason to lie down in front of him and make it easier."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "There's no need to tell me I'm not brave enough to be in Gryffindor, Malfoy's already done that," Neville choked out.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry felt in the pocket of his robes and pulled out a Chocolate Frog, the very last one from the box Hermione had given him for Christmas. He gave it to Neville, who looked as though he might cry.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You're worth twelve of Malfoy," Harry said. "The Sorting Hat chose you for Gryffindor, didn't it? And where's Malfoy? In stinking Slytherin."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Neville's lips twitched in a weak smile as he unwrapped the frog.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Thanks, Harry... I think I'll go to bed.... D'you want the card, you collect them, don't you?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: As Neville walked away, Harry looked at the Famous Wizard card.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Dumbledore again," he said, "He was the first one I ever-"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He gasped. He stared at the back of the card. Then he looked up at Ron and Hermione.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I've found him!" he whispered. "I've found Flamel! I told you I'd read the name somewhere before, I read it on the train coming here -- listen to this: 'Dumbledore is particularly famous for his defeat of the dark wizard Grindelwald in 1945, for the discovery of the twelve uses of dragon's blood, and his work on alchemy with his partner, Nicolas Flamel'!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Hermione jumped to her feet. She hadn't looked so excited since they'd gotten back the marks for their very first piece of homework.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Stay there!" she said, and she sprinted up the stairs to the girls' dormitories. Harry and Ron barely had time to exchange mystified looks before she was dashing back, an enormous old book in her arms.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I never thought to look in here!" she whispered excitedly. "I got this out of the library weeks ago for a bit of light reading."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Light?" said Ron, but Hermione told him to be quiet until she'd looked something up, and started flicking frantically through the pages, muttering to herself.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: At last she found what she was looking for.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I knew it! I knew it!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Are we allowed to speak yet?" said Ron grumpily. Hermione ignored him.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Nicolas Flamel," she whispered dramatically, "is the only known maker of the Sorcerer's Stone!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: This didn't have quite the effect she'd expected.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "The what?" said Harry and Ron.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Oh, honestly, don't you two read? Look -- read that, there."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: She pushed the book toward them, and Harry and Ron read: The ancient study of alchemy is concerned with making the Sorcerer's Stone, a

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: legendary substance with astonishing powers. The stone will transform any metal into pure gold. It also produces the Elixir of Life, which will make the drinker immortal.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: There have been many reports of the Sorcerer's Stone over the centuries, but the only Stone currently in existence belongs to Mr. Nicolas Flamel, the noted alchemist and opera lover. Mr. Flamel, who celebrated his six hundred and sixty-fifth birthday last year, enjoys a quiet life in Devon with his wife, Perenelle (six hundred and fifty-eight).

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "See?" said Hermione, when Harry and Ron had finished. "The dog must be guarding Flamel's Sorcerer's Stone! I bet he asked Dumbledore to keep it safe for him, because they're friends and he knew someone was after it, that's why he wanted the Stone moved out of Gringotts!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "A stone that makes gold and stops you from ever dying!" said Harry. "No wonder Snape's after it! Anyone would want it."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "And no wonder we couldn't find Flamel in that Study of Recent Developments in Wizardry," said Ron. "He's not exactly recent if he's six hundred and sixty-five, is he?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The next morning in Defense Against the Dark Arts, while copying down different ways of treating werewolf bites, Harry and Ron were still discussing what they'd do with a Sorcerer's Stone if they had one. It wasn't until Ron said he'd buy his own Quidditch team that Harry remembered about Snape and the coming match.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I'm going to play," he told Ron and Hermione. "If I don't, all the Slytherins will think I'm just too scared to face Snape. I'll show them... it'll really wipe the smiles off their faces if we win."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Just as long as we're not wiping you off the field," said Hermione.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: As the match drew nearer, however, Harry became more and more nervous, whatever he told Ron and Hermione. The rest of the team wasn't too calm, either. The idea of overtaking Slytherin in the house championship was wonderful, no one had done it for seven years, but would they be allowed to, with such a biased referee?

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry didn't know whether he was imagining it or not, but he seemed to keep running into Snape wherever he went. At times, he even wondered whether Snape was following him, trying to catch him on his own. Potions

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: lessons were turning into a sort of weekly torture, Snape was so horrible to Harry. Could Snape possibly know they'd found out about the Sorcerer's Stone? Harry didn't see how he could -- yet he sometimes had the horrible feeling that Snape could read minds.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry knew, when they wished him good luck outside the locker rooms the next afternoon, that Ron and Hermione were wondering whether they'd ever see him alive again. This wasn't what you'd call comforting. Harry hardly heard a word of Wood's pep talk as he pulled on his Quidditch robes and picked up his Nimbus Two Thousand.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Ron and Hermione, meanwhile, had found a place in the stands next to Neville, who couldn't understand why they looked so grim and worried, or why they had both brought their wands to the match. Little did Harry know that Ron and Hermione had been secretly practicing the Leg-Locker Curse. They'd gotten the idea from Malfoy using it on Neville, and were ready to use it on Snape if he showed any sign of wanting to hurt Harry.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Now, don't forget, it's Locomotor Mortis," Hermione muttered as Ron slipped his wand up his sleeve.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I know," Ron snapped. "Don't nag."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Back in the locker room, Wood had taken Harry aside.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Don't want to pressure you, Potter, but if we ever need an early capture of the Snitch it's now. Finish the game before Snape can favor Hufflepuff too much."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "The whole school's out there!" said Fred Weasley, peering out of the door. "Even -- blimey -- Dumbledore's come to watch!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry's heart did a somersault.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Dumbledore?" he said, dashing to the door to make sure. Fred was right. There was no mistaking that silver beard.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry could have laughed out loud with relief He was safe. There was simply no way that Snape would dare to try to hurt him if Dumbledore was watching.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Perhaps that was why Snape was looking so angry as the teams marched onto the field, something that Ron noticed, too.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I've never seen Snape look so mean," he told Hermione. "Look -they're off Ouch!"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Someone had poked Ron in the back of the head. It was Malfoy.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Oh, sorry, Weasley, didn't see you there."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Malfoy grinned broadly at Crabbe and Goyle.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Wonder how long Potter's going to stay on his broom this time? Anyone want a bet? What about you, Weasley?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Ron didn't answer; Snape had just awarded Hufflepuff a penalty because George Weasley had hit a Bludger at him. Hermione, who had all her fingers crossed in her lap, was squinting fixedly at Harry, who was circling the game like a hawk, looking for the Snitch.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You know how I think they choose people for the Gryffindor team?" said Malfoy loudly a few minutes later, as Snape awarded Hufflepuff another penalty for no reason at all. "It's people they feel sorry for. See, there's Potter, who's got no parents, then there's the Weasleys, who've got no money -- you should be on the team, Longbottom, you've got no brains."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Neville went bright red but turned in his seat to face Malfoy.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I'm worth twelve of you, Malfoy," he stammered.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Malfoy, Crabbe, and Goyle howled with laughter, but Ron, still not daring to take his eyes from the game, said, "You tell him, Neville."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Longbottom, if brains were gold you'd be poorer than Weasley, and that's saying something."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Ron's nerves were already stretched to the breaking point with anxiety about Harry.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I'm warning you, Malfoy -- one more word

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Ron!" said Hermione suddenly, "Harry --"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "What? Where?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry had suddenly gone into a spectacular dive, which drew gasps and cheers from the crowd. Hermione stood up, her crossed fingers in her mouth, as Harry streaked toward the ground like a bullet.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You're in luck, Weasley, Potter's obviously spotted some money on the ground!" said Malfoy.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Ron snapped. Before Malfoy knew what was happening, Ron was on top of him, wrestling him to the ground. Neville hesitated, then clambered over the back of his seat to help.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Come on, Harry!" Hermione screamed, leaping onto her seat to watch as Harry sped straight at Snape -- she didn't even notice Malfoy and Ron rolling around under her seat, or the scuffles and yelps coming from the whirl of fists that was Neville, Crabbe, and Goyle.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Up in the air, Snape turned on his broomstick just in time to see something scarlet shoot past him, missing him by inches -- the next second, Harry had pulled out of the dive, his arm raised in triumph, the Snitch clasped in his hand.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The stands erupted; it had to be a record, no one could ever remember the Snitch being caught so quickly.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Ron! Ron! Where are you? The game's over! Harry's won! We've won! Gryffindor is in the lead!" shrieked Hermione, dancing up and down on her seat and hugging Parvati Patil in the row in front.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry jumped off his broom, a foot from the ground. He couldn't believe it. He'd done it -- the game was over; it had barely lasted five minutes. As Gryffindors came spilling onto the field, he saw Snape land nearby, white-faced and tight-lipped -- then Harry felt a hand on his shoulder and looked up into Dumbledore's smiling face.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Well done," said Dumbledore quietly, so that only Harry could hear. "Nice to see you haven't been brooding about that mirror... been keeping busy... excellent..."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Snape spat bitterly on the ground.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry left the locker room alone some time later, to take his Nimbus Two Thousand back to the broomshed. He couldn't ever remember feeling

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: happier. He'd really done something to be proud of now -- no one could say he was just a famous name any more. The evening air had never smelled so sweet. He walked over the damp grass, reliving the last hour in his head, which was a happy blur: Gryffindors running to lift him onto their shoulders; Ron and Hermione in the distance, jumping up and down, Ron cheering through a heavy nosebleed.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry had reached the shed. He leaned against the wooden door and looked up at Hogwarts, with its windows glowing red in the setting sun. Gryffindor in the lead. He'd done it, he'd shown Snape....

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: And speaking of Snape...

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: A hooded figure came swiftly down the front steps of the castle. Clearly not wanting to be seen, it walked as fast as possible toward the forbidden forest. Harry's victory faded from his mind as he watched. He recognized the figure's prowling walk. Snape, sneaking into the forest while everyone else was at dinner -- what was going on?

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry jumped back on his Nimbus Two Thousand and took off. Gliding silently over the castle he saw Snape enter the forest at a run. He followed.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: The trees were so thick he couldn't see where Snape had gone. He flew in circles, lower and lower, brushing the top branches of trees until he heard voices. He glided toward them and landed noiselessly in a towering beech tree.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: He climbed carefully along one of the branches, holding tight to his broomstick, trying to see through the leaves. Below, in a shadowy clearing, stood Snape, but he wasn't alone. Quirrell was there, too. Harry couldn't make out the look on his face, but he was stuttering worse than ever. Harry strained to catch what they were saying.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "... d-don't know why you wanted t-t-to meet here of all p-places, Severus..."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Oh, I thought we'd keep this private," said Snape, his voice icy. "Students aren't supposed to know about the Sorcerer's Stone, after all."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: Harry leaned forward. Quirrell was mumbling something. Snape interrupted him.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf
Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "Have you found out how to get past that beast of Hagrid's yet?"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "B-b-but Severus, I --"

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You don't want me as your enemy, Quirrell," said Snape, taking a step toward him.

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "I-I don't know what you

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "You know perfectly well what I mean."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: An owl hooted loudly, and Harry nearly fell out of the tree. He steadied himself in time to hear Snape say, "-- your little bit of hocus-pocus. I'm waiting."

metadata.filename: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone.pdf

text: "B-but I d-d-don't --"
